  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Steve Alvin
          Sisk, Petitioner,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Respondent
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Fairfield County
Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge
Â John C. Hayes, III, Post-Conviction
  Relief Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-280
  Submitted April 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 2,
  2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Lanelle C. Durant, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General
          John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
          Attorney General S. Prentiss Counts, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari from the denial of his application for
  post-conviction relief (PCR).
 Because
  there is sufficient evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that petitioner
  did not knowingly and intelligently waive his right to a direct appeal, we
  grant the petition for a writ of certiorari and proceed with a review of the
  direct appeal issue pursuant to Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d
  60 (1986).
Petitioner argues the trial judge erred in denying his motion for
  a mistrial.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 13, 515 S.E.2d 508, 514 (1999) (holding movant
  must show not only error, but resulting prejudice in order to justify a
  mistrial); State v. Johnson, 334 S.C. 78, 89, 512 S.E.2d 795, 801 (1999)
  (â€œA mistrial should not be ordered in every case where incompetent evidence is
  received.â€); State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 227, 522 S.E.2d 845,
  851 (Ct. App. 1999) (stating the granting of the motion for a mistrial is an
  extreme measure that should be taken only where an incident is so grievous that
  prejudicial effect can be removed in no other way); State v. Jones, 325 S.C. 310, 323, 479 S.E.2d 517, 524 (Ct. App. 1996) (holding a curative
  instruction is generally deemed to have cured any alleged error). 
AFFIRMED. Â Â 
HUFF,
  KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in
  resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument
pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        James H. Wright
          A.K.A. James Muhammad, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-281
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 2, 2008Â Â Â  

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for
          Appellant.
        Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, Monique Danielle Montgomery,
          of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: The lower court found by clear and
  convincing evidence that James Wright, A.K.A. James Muhammad, (Wright) was mentally
  ill.Â  Wright appeals, we
  dismiss this appeal. Â 
FACTS
Wright was found not guilty by reason of insanity of assault and
  battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  Wright was committed to the
  Department of Mental Health (the Department).Â  Wright was conditionally
  discharged from the Department in July 1999 and readmitted in June 2004.Â 
  Wright was again conditionally discharged in April 2005 and readmitted in
  November 2005 as a result of noncompliance with prior discharge orders.Â  
A hearing was held to determine whether Wright should remain
  hospitalized or be conditionally discharged.Â  The lower court found by clear
  and convincing evidence that Wright was mentally ill and ordered him to remain
  committed for treatment.Â  Wright argues the lower courtâ€™s decision is in
  error.Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The maximum length of supervision or confinement for an individual
  found not guilty by reason of insanity is limited to the maximum sentence the
  individual could have received for the charged offense.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  17-24-50 (1976).Â  In the present case, Wright was found guilty of assault and
  battery of a high and aggravated nature on June 17, 1997.Â  The maximum sentence
  Wright could have received for this offense was ten years.Â  Thus, the last day
  on which Wright could have been subjected to commitment was June 17, 2007.Â  Id.Â  Wright was released from inpatient hospitalization on October 30, 2006.Â 
  (Appellantâ€™s Br. at 4 and Respâ€™tâ€™s brief at 5)
â€œA moot case exists where a judgment rendered by the court will
  have no practical legal effect upon an existing controversy because an
  intervening event renders any grant of effectual relief impossible for the
  reviewing court.â€Â  Sloan v. Friends of Hunley, Inc., 369 S.C. 20, 26,
  630 S.E.2d 474, 477 (2006). The passage of time has made the issue presented on
  appeal moot because pursuant to section 17-24-50, the last day on which Wright
  could have been hospitalized was June 17, 2007.Â  Appellate courts do not adjudicate
  moot questions.Â  Nolas Trading Co., Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health &
    Envtl. Control, 289 S.C. 345, 347, 345 S.E.2d 507, 508 (Ct. App. 1986)
  (â€œThe function of appellate courts is not to give opinions on abstract
  questions, but to decide actual controversies injuriously affecting the rights
  of some party to the litigation; accordingly, issues which have become moot are
  not a proper subject of review.â€).Â  
APPEAL
  DISMISSED.[1] 
WILLIAMS,
  THOMAS, and, PIEPER, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of
Appeals


  
    
      
        Environmental Solutions International, Inc., Appellant,
        v.
        J.C. Construction, Inc., Wolfe Creek Construction, Inc., and
          Woolpert L.L.P.,
        of whom:
        J.C. Construction, Inc. is Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Colleton County
  Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit
Court Judge

Unpublished
Opinion No. 2008-UP-282
Submitted June
1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 2, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        R. Clenton Campbell and Grahame E.
          Holmes, both of Walterboro, for Appellant.
        Amanda A. Bailey and M. Mark McAdams, both
          of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Environmental
  Solutions International, Inc. appeals the trial judgeâ€™s grant of summary
  judgment, contending the trial judge committed error in finding no issue of
  material fact as to whether ESI was compensated for services rendered to J.C.
  Construction, Inc., thus barring claims under quantum meruit and breach of
  contract.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In
  May 2003, Respondent J.C. Construction, Inc. (JCC), a general construction
  company, successfully submitted a bid for a project to refurbish a waste water
  treatment facility for the Town of St. Matthews, South Carolina.Â  One aspect of
  the workload required JCC to remove and dispose of sludge from the treatment facilityâ€™s
  basins.Â  To effectuate the sludge removal, JCC solicited bids for this portion
  of the work and subcontracted with Appellant Environmental Solutions
  International, Inc. (ESI) in November 2003.Â  ESI agreed to payment of $108.00
  per ton of sludge removed.Â  The scope of the sludge removal was based on an
  estimate by Woolpert, L.L.P. (Woolpert), an engineering consultant hired by the
  town, and was limited by the terms of the contract.Â  Under the subcontract, ESI
  was required to:

  Remove, solidify, transport and dispose
    of approximately 350 tons of waste treatment sludge.Â  Payment to be determined
    by measure of sludge hauled to the landfill.Â  The unit cost rate of $108.00 per
    ton hauled shall apply (as per the project bid form).Â  Approximate total
    commitment for accounting purposes only is $37,800.00.

After
  contracting with JCC, ESI hired Wolfe Creek Construction, Inc. (Wolfe Creek) to
  perform the actual removal.Â  In December 2003, ESI and Wolfe Creek began the
  removal process.Â  A number of delays plagued the project from the beginning
  resulting from leakage in sludge dewatering containers, inclement weather, and
  the lengthy process required to dry the sludge.Â  Additionally, the total amount
  of sludge requiring removal greatly exceeded the scope originally estimated by
  Woolpert.Â  In response to this discovery, ESI submitted a change order to JCC,
  increasing the scope of removal from 350 tons to 5,000 tons to reflect
  Woolpertâ€™s error in the original estimate.
In
  April 2004, ESI quit work and left the jobsite, leaving behind a
  partially-filled dewatering bag of sludge, various equipment, and sawdust used
  in solidifying the sludge.Â  In May 2004, ESI faxed JCC a new agreement demanding
  a price increase from $108.00 per ton to $220.00 per ton for the sludge removal.Â 
  ESI alleged the price increase was in line with the increased costs associated
  with the larger workload which would require more personnel and different
  equipment in order to meet the project deadlines.Â  JCC never accepted this
  agreement and solicited new bids in order to facilitate the removal.Â  Wolfe
  Creek offered to complete the project, subcontracted with JCC, and completed
  all remaining sludge removal.Â  Wolfe Creek compensated ESI for the materials
  left behind at the jobsite by giving ESI a $10,350.00 credit.Â  The credit memo
  sent to ESI by Wolfe Creek noted the credit was for time, materials, and labor
  exhausted in filling the remaining bag and for three loads of ESIâ€™s sawdust.Â  
Thereafter,
  ESI filed suit against several parties including JCC over the subcontract for
  sludge removal.Â  ESI alleged JCC was liable for breach of contract, quantum
  meruit, conversion, and intentional interference with contractual relations.Â 
  JCC moved for summary judgment on all causes of action.Â  At the hearing, ESI
  withdrew its claim of conversion.Â  Subsequently, the trial judge granted JCCâ€™s
  Motion for Summary Judgment as to all of ESIâ€™s claims.Â  
DISCUSSION
ESI alleges there are genuine issues of
  material fact as to whether it was paid under the contract for (1) the total amount
  of sludge hauled to the landfill and (2) for the sludge pumped into dewatering
  bags but left at the jobsite, and therefore, the grant of summary judgment was
  inappropriate as to the claims for quantum meruit and breach of contract.Â  We
  disagree.Â  
In order for a motion of summary
  judgment to warrant denial, a triable issue must exist.Â  Worsley Cos., Inc.
    v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 339 S.C. 51, 55, 528 S.E.2d 657, 660 (2000).Â  â€œA
  court considering summary judgment neither makes factual determinations nor
  considers the merits of competing testimony; however, summary judgment is
  completely appropriate when a properly supported motion sets forth facts that
  remain undisputed or are contested in a deficient manner.â€Â  David v. McLeod
    Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 250, 626 S.E.2d 1, 5 (2006). Â Â Â 
In
  the case at bar, ESI has failed to raise a genuine issue of material fact it
  was not compensated for services provided to JCC.Â  The record is barren of
  evidence to support this contention.Â  Therefore, the trial judgeâ€™s grant of
  summary judgment was appropriate.Â  
ESI
  alleges it was not paid for the amount of sludge it disposed of according to
  the terms of the contract and for the amount of sludge it pumped into
  dewatering bags and left at the jobsite.Â  However, ESI did not properly support
  these claims to the extent necessary to raise a genuine issue of material
  fact.Â  As in this case, summary judgment is completely appropriate when facts
  are contested in a deficient manner.Â  See David, 367 S.C. at 250,
  626 S.E.2d at 5.
1.Â 
  Sludge Removal Fully Performed under the Terms of the Contract
ESI alleges that it was not paid for the
  350 tons of sludge removed, transported, and disposed of at the dump.Â  Based on
  our review of the record, this issue is not preserved.Â  Even if preserved, the
  issue fails on the merits.Â  
This sludge removal was specifically
  covered by the terms of the contract.Â  ESI performed under the contract by
  disposing of approximately 350 tons of sludge and would have a cause of action
  for breach of contract against JCC if JCC failed to pay for these services.Â  However,
  sufficient evidence is not contained in the record to support this contention.Â  
The cause of action for breach of
  contract requires the plaintiff to establish the following elements:Â  (1) the
  existence of a contract, (2) a breach of the contract, and (3) damages to the
  plaintiff proximately resulting from the breach.Â  Fuller v. Eastern Fire
    & Cas. Ins. Co., 240 S.C. 75, 89, 124 S.E.2d 602, 610 (1962).Â  A breach
  occurs when a party to the contract fails to carry out a term, promise, or
  condition of the contract.Â  See Freeman Dodge, Inc. v. Fin. Servs.,
    Inc., 272 S.C. 164, 249 S.E.2d 897 (1978) (finding finance companyâ€™s
  failure to offer car back to dealership as required by the terms of the
  contract was breach).
ESI has failed to produce evidence
  supporting the elements required for a breach of contract action.Â Â Â  Looking to
  â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on
  file, together with the affidavitsâ€ in the record, ESI did not present
  sufficient evidence of a breach by JCC to create an issue for trial.Â  See Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Â 
It
  is undisputed JCC and ESI entered into a mutual contract.Â  By the terms of the
  contract, ESI was required to â€œ[r]emove, solidify, transport and dispose of
  approximately 350 tons of waste treatment sludge.â€Â  After disposal of the
  sludge, JCC was required to pay ESI according to the â€œmeasure of sludge hauled
  to the landfill.â€Â  To establish a breach, ESI was required to prove JCC did not
  pay for sludge removal complying with the terms of the agreement.Â  However, there
  is no evidence in the record suggesting JCC failed to compensate ESI for the
  work it performed.Â  The only evidence offering insight into JCCâ€™s payment for ESIâ€™s
  services is the deposition of Brian Larry Penfield, Jr. (Penfield), the
  president and owner of ESI.Â  In his deposition, Penfield testified:

  Q:Â  Okay.Â  And do you know how much
    money J.C. Construction paid you?
  A:Â  Without pulling it out I do not
    know, sir.
  Q:Â  So you have no idea as you sit here
    today whether they paid you the entire $38,000, do you?
  A:Â  Not right this moment I do not.
  Q:Â  All right.Â  As we sit here today can
    you tell me what services or materials that you provided to my client, J.C.
    Construction that you were not compensated for?
  A:Â  Well, the contract for the first 350
    tons and first $37,800 I would say that that there was falling in line with the
    $108 a ton and then due to circumstances either caused by delays, change orders
    and other nature like that, that the materials that was in the bag on the
    bottom of the hill and the prevention of moving further with the job since we
    were basically . . . when we put a work stoppage in to try and get things
    hashed out it prevented us from making up the rest of the money, particularly
    time, the cost of the bags.Â  We had multitude of down days to where we drove up
    there and we couldnâ€™t do anything, some of which may have been in our error but
    some of which were not, so those are the things that I think that should be
    calculated in regard to that.Â  

In the appellantâ€™s brief, ESIâ€™s counsel
  concedes this testimony confirms ESI was paid for the first 350 tons of sludge
  removal but argues that Penfieldâ€™s testimony was erroneous and inaccurate.Â 
  While counsel maintains that Penfield was mistaken and ESI was not paid for the
  sludge removal fully performed, no additional evidence is offered anywhere in
  the record to support this contention.Â Â Â Â  
Given Penfieldâ€™s uncertain testimony and
  the lack of other supporting evidence, this court does not find a genuine issue
  of material fact as to whether ESI was paid under the contract.Â  Although
  Penfield appears to be unsure as to what amount he received from JCC at the
  time of the deposition, the testimony establishes ESI was paid.Â  When asked
  what services ESI was not compensated for, Penfield seems to suggest ESI wants
  payment for the sludge pumped into the dewatering bags and left at the jobsite
  and the costs associated with delays as opposed to the money due under the
  original terms of the contract.Â  His response to the question is ambiguous at
  best.Â  This ambiguity is not sufficient to raise a genuine issue of material
  fact sufficient for trial on the claim ESI was not paid for work fully
  performed under the contract.Â  Facts contested in a deficient manner cannot
  overcome a properly supported motion for summary judgment.Â  
After JCC established a lack of
  evidentiary support for the case, the burden shifted to ESI to prove the
  existence of a genuine issue of material fact.Â  See Regions Bank v.
    Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 660, 582 S.E.2d 432, 438 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  A party
  opposing a motion for summary judgment must allege facts clearly showing a
  material issue for trial and cannot rely on a mere scintilla of evidence to
  overcome the motion.Â  See Thomas v. Waters, 315 S.C. 524, 526,
  334 S.E.2d 659, 661 (2001).Â  ESI failed to meet this burden.Â  Looking to Rule
  56(c), SCRCP, we are limited to examining the pleadings, depositions, answers
  to interrogatories, admissions on file, and affidavits to find a genuine issue
  of material fact warranting a denial of a grant of summary judgment.Â  Based on
  the record in this case, no such factual dispute exists to support the claim
  ESI was not compensated for the sludge removal fully performed under the
  contract.Â  Therefore, the grant of summary judgment was proper in regards to
  this claim.Â  
2.Â 
  Excess Sludge Pumped into Dewatering Bags without Disposal
Additionally, ESI is seeking recovery
  for sludge removed in excess of the terms of the contract and left in
  dewatering bags at the jobsite without proper disposal.Â  ESI alleges it is
  entitled to recover for this work under a theory of quantum meruit, or in the
  alternative, under a claim for breach of contract.Â  
Quantum meruit is an equitable remedy.Â  Columbia Wholesale v. Scudder May N.V., 312 S.C. 259, 261, 440 S.E.2d 129,
  130 (1994); Landbank Fund VII, LLC v. Dickerson, 369 S.C. 621, 630, 632
  S.E.2d 882, 887 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  â€œ â€˜In a law action, the measure of damages is
  determined by the partiesâ€™ agreement, while in equity, â€˜the measure of the
  recovery is the extent of the duty or obligation imposed by law, and is
  expressed by the amount which the court considers the defendant has been
  unjustly enriched at the expense of the plaintiff.â€™ â€™ â€Â  QHG of Lake City,
    Inc. v. McCutcheon, 360 S.C. 196, 203, 600 S.E.2d 165, 108 (Ct. App. 2004)
  (quoting Myrtle Beach Hosp. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 341 S.C. 1, 8, 532
  S.E.2d 868, 872 (2000) (quoting United States Rubber Prods., Inc. v. Town of
    Batesburg, 183 S.C. 49, 55, 190 S.E. 120, 126 (1937))).Â Â Â  
To prevail on a quantum meruit claim,
  the following elements must be established:Â  (1) the plaintiff conferred a
  benefit to the defendant; (2) the defendant realized the benefit; and (3) the
  defendant retained the benefit under circumstances making it inequitable for
  the defendant to retain the benefit without paying its value.Â  Myrtle Beach Hosp., 341 S.C. at 8-9, 532 S.E.2d at 872; Landbank, 369 S.C. at
  630, 632 S.E.2d at 888; QHG of Lake City, 360 S.C. at 203-204, 600
  S.E.2d at 108; Swanson v. Stratos, 350 S.C. 116, 121, 564 S.E.2d 117,
  119 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  However, â€œ[i]f the tasks the plaintiff is seeking
  compensation for under a quantum meruit theory are encompassed within the terms
  of an express contract which has not been abandoned or rescinded, the plaintiff
  may not recover under quantum meruit.â€Â  Swanson, 350 S.C. at 122, 564
  S.E.2d at 120 (citing 66 Am.Jur.2d Restitution and Implied Contracts Â§
  81 (2001) (â€œ[I]t is a defense to an action in quantum meruit that there is an
  express contract covering the issue of compensation for services or materials
  furnished.â€)); see also Texcon, Inc. v. Anderson Aviation, Inc.,
  284 S.C. 307, 326 S.E.2d 168 (Ct. App. 1985) (finding master erred in allowing
  recovery in quantum meruit where express contract existed).
In Ro-Lo Enterprises v. Hicks Enterprises, Inc., 294 S.C. 111, 113-114, 362
  S.E.2d 888, 889 (Ct. App. 1987), this Court addressed what constitutes
  abandonment of a contract:Â  

  Abandonment of contract by one
    party is the giving up of the right to a benefit due from the other party.Â  Pitcher
      v. Lauritzen, 18 Utah 2d 368, 423 P.2d 491 (1967).Â  A contract will be
    treated as abandoned when the acts of one party inconsistent with its existence
    are acquiesced in by the other party.Â  Sauder v. Dittmar, 118 F.2d 524 (10th
    Cir. 1941); 17 Am.Jur.2d Contracts Section 484 (1964).Â  To constitute
    abandonment of contract by conduct, the actions relied upon must be positive,
    unequivocal, and inconsistent with the existence of a contract.Â  Mood v.
      Methodist Episcopal Church South, 289 S.W. 461 (Tex. Civ. App. 1926).Â  

â€œThe
  abandonment of a contract is a matter of intention to be ascertained from the
  facts and circumstances surrounding the transaction from which the abandonment
  is claimed to have resulted.â€Â  Quality Concrete Products, Inc. v. Thomason,
  253 S.C. 579, 589, 172 S.E.2d 297, 302 (1970).Â  â€œAn abandonment of a contract
  need not be express but may be inferred from the conduct of the parties and the
  attendant circumstances.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œ[A]n abandonment of the contract involves
  a breach of the implied obligation of good faith and fair dealing.â€Â  U.S. ex. rel. William Elec. Co., Inc. v. Metric Constructors, Inc., 325 S.C.
  129, 135, 480 S.E.2d 447, 450 (1997).Â  
ESI
  cannot recover under a theory of quantum meruit if the work they are seeking
  compensation for is covered under the terms of an express contract.Â  However, if
  the express contract has been abandoned, recovery under quantum meruit may be
  possible.Â  In this case, an express contract covered the task for which ESI is
  seeking recovery, but ESI abandoned the contract when it unilaterally decided
  to quit the project.Â  This abandonment cannot allow ESI to recover under
  quantum meruit.Â  ESI left the jobsite, demanded an increase in price, and
  refused to perform any further work until JCC consented.Â  ESI sent a new
  service agreement to JCC stating, along with a price increase to $220.00 per
  ton removed:Â  

  This cost will include all of the
    changes and the clarifications that Woolpert Engineering has imposed for this
    project.Â  No trucks can be loaded until there is an agreement signed and
      returned.Â  ESI will still need to obtain a new purchase order for the
    remaining sludge to reflect the cost changes as well as change orders signed
    and placed by Woolpert to insure it is done by the new specifications.Â  

(emphasis added).
In
  response to this demand, JCC hired another company to complete the remaining
  tasks.Â  ESIâ€™s abandonment was a breach of contract and does not open the door
  to a claim under quantum meruit.Â  Therefore, ESI was barred from recovery.Â  
Furthermore,
  ESI is not entitled to recover for breach of contract until it fully performs
  under the terms of the contract.Â  By failing to properly transport and dispose
  of the sludge pumped into the dewatering bags, ESI did not complete performance.Â 
  Due to this failure, ESI was not yet entitled to compensation under the terms
  of the contract and cannot recover for breach of contract.Â  
3.Â 
  Ambiguity in the Contract
Additionally,
  ESI argues the contract was ambiguous by stating â€œapproximately 350 tons of
  waste treatment sludge.â€Â  Because â€œapproximatelyâ€ could be subject to conflicting
  interpretation, the question of whether the additional sludge removed is
  covered by the terms of an express contract is disputed.Â  If the additional
  sludge removal was not covered by an express contract, recovery under quantum
  meruit may be allowed.Â  
In HK New Plan Exch. Prop. Owner I, LLC v. Coker, 375 S.C. 18, 23, 649
  S.E.2d 181, 184 (Ct. App. 2007), we discussed the effect of an ambiguous contract
  on a motion for summary judgment:Â  

  Generally, the
    construction of a contract is a question of law for the court. Â Soil
      Remediation Co. v. Nu-Way Envtl., Inc., 325 S.C. 231, 234, 482 S.E.2d 554,
    555 (1997). Â Where a motion for summary judgment presents a question as to the
    construction of a written contract, if the language employed by the agreement
    is plain and unambiguous, the question is one of law. Â First-Citizens Bank
      Trust Co. v. Conway Nat'l Bank, 282 S.C. 303, 305, 317 S.E.2d 776,
    777 (Ct. App. 1984). Â â€œIn such a case, summary judgment is proper and a trial
    unnecessary where the intention of the parties as to the legal effect of the
    contract may be gathered from the four corners of the instrument itself.â€ Â Id.
  However, summary
    judgment is improper where the motion presents a question as to the
    construction of a written contract, and the contract is ambiguous because the
    intent of the parties can not be gathered from the four corners of the
    instrument. Â Bishop v. Benson, 297 S.C. 14, 17, 374 S.E.2d 517,
    518-19 (Ct. App. 1988). Â Where a contract is unclear, or is ambiguous and
    capable of more than one construction, the parties' intentions are matters of
    fact to be submitted to a jury. Â Wheeler v. Globe Rutgers Fire Ins. Co. of
      City of N.Y., 125 S.C. 320, 325, 118 S.E. 609, 610 (1923).

Typically, when a contract is ambiguous
  and a question of fact is raised to its interpretation, summary judgment would
  not be appropriate.Â  However, in this case, regardless of the interpretation of
  the contract, ESI would not be entitled to recover.Â  
If an express contract covered the excess
  sludge removed, then ESI would be limited to a recovery in breach of contract.Â 
  However, due to the fact ESI breached the contract and did not fully perform,
  it would be unable to recover.Â  
If the additional sludge removal was not
  covered by the contract because of the ambiguity of the term â€œapproximately,â€
  ESI would still be unable to recover under a theory of quantum meruit.Â  Before
  recovery is allowed, quantum meruit requires the defendant to retain a benefit
  under circumstances that make it inequitable for the defendant to do so without
  paying value.Â  In this case, it would not be inequitable for JCC to retain the
  benefit of ESIâ€™s work because there was no inequitable conduct on the part of
  JCC leading to the removal.Â  ESI submitted a change order requesting an
  increase in tonnage removed to 5000 tons.Â  However, ESI failed to present any
  evidence JCC agreed to this increase.Â  Because it proceeded without a valid
  agreement, ESI bore the risk of not receiving a benefit for its services.Â 
  Therefore, recovery for the excess sludge removal is inappropriate under a
  theory of quantum meruit.Â  
In his deposition, Penfield testified to
  his understanding of the partiesâ€™ agreement regarding the disposal of
  additional sludge:

  Q:Â  Okay.Â  You would agree with me that
    this contract doesnâ€™t give you any more rights than to basically haul away 350
    tons of sludge?
  . . . 
  A:Â  I think there was also a change
    order sent in part to remove it . . . turn it to, I think 1,800 tons or so.Â  
  Q:Â  Was that change order ever signed by
    my client?
  A:Â  That I donâ€™t know, sir.Â  
  Q:Â  Well, Iâ€™ll show it to you.Â  Iâ€™m
    going to hand you what has been marked as Exhibit Number Four to your
    deposition.Â  
  . . . 
  Q:Â  What is that, for the record,
    please?
  A:Â  That is a change in calculation
    after we tried to meet every one of the change orders that had been placed upon
    us. 
  Q:Â  And in that you raised the price,
    you basically gave a quote that sais (sic), â€œHey, weâ€™ll do this for 200 bucks a
    ton,â€ is that correct?
  A:Â  Thatâ€™s correct.
  Q:Â  In the second paragraph it says, â€œNo
    trucks can be loaded until there is an agreement signed and returned.â€
  A:Â  Thatâ€™s correct.
  Q:Â  Okay.Â  So what youâ€™re doing is
    youâ€™re saying my company will do this if we enter into an agreement for this
    price to be $220, is that correct?
  A:Â  Yes, sir.Â  
  . . . 
  Q:Â  Well, they didnâ€™t agree to this did
    they, to Exhibit Number Four?Â  They didnâ€™t agree to pay two and a half times .
    . . 
  A:Â  No, sir, they never signed it and
    sent it back.
  Q:Â  Right so you didnâ€™t have an
    agreement to do any more work out there, did you?
  A:Â  In the terms that youâ€™re putting it,
    no sir.
  Q:Â  Well, you put it right here that you
    werenâ€™t going to load any trucks until they signed the agreement, didnâ€™t you?
  A:Â  Thatâ€™s correct.Â  

The
  deposition of Laverne Anderson (Anderson) establishes JCCâ€™s understanding of
  the agreement regarding any additional sludge removal beyond the terms of the
  contract.Â  Anderson explained:Â  

  [W]e had ESI under contract, which is
    drawn up to meet our needs, and we had won the contract to remove 350 tons and
    thatâ€™s it.Â  And then if we chose to do so, to continue working with him, we
    could issue him a change order at the same unit rate he gave us to complete the
    job.Â  But he left the job because he hadnâ€™t paid his suppliers, he pulled off,
    he couldnâ€™t remove the sludge.Â  

Nothing
  in the record establishes any agreement between JCC and ESI for the removal of
  sludge beyond the terms of the original contract.Â  If the original contract had
  expired, ESI pumped the additional sludge without an agreement with JCC.Â  ESI
  cannot perform work without any agreement in place and then argue it is
  entitled to compensation.Â  Without evidence indicating it would be inequitable
  for JCC to retain this benefit, ESI is not entitled to recover under quantum
  meruit.Â  
Furthermore, we note ESI received a
  credit from its subcontractor, Wolfe Creek, for time, materials, and labor
  exhausted in filling the remaining bag and for three loads of ESIâ€™s sawdust.Â  This
  credit compensated ESI for expenses it incurred in pumping the excess sludge
  into the dewatering bags before ESI abandoned the jobsite.Â  Even though ESI did
  not receive as much as it desired for the excess removal, the credit ensured
  that ESI was repaid for the incurred costs.Â  Therefore, equity does not require
  JCC to further compensate ESI for this work.Â Â  
CONCLUSION
ESI has not presented a theory of
  recovery for which it is entitled to prevail based on the evidence contained in
  the record. Â Regardless of whether the contract is ambiguous, the grant of
  summary judgment is appropriate.Â  Accordingly, the grant of summary judgment is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ.,
  concur.


[1] We decide this case
  without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Gordon Gravelle
          o/a “CodePro Manufacturing,” Appellant,
        v.
        Kenneth
          Roberts, an individual, and Beacon Safe & Lock, Inc. and DOES I through
          V, and Roe Corporations VI through X, inclusive, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Brooks P. Goldsmith, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-283
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 2, 2008 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Gordon Gravelle, of Ontario, Canada, for Appellant.
        Linda Weeks Gangi, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER
  CURIAM:Â  In this libel action, Gordon
  Gravelle (Gravelle) appeals the trial courtâ€™s (1) verdict in favor of Kenneth
  Roberts (Roberts), (2) dismissal of his post-trial motions, (3) denial of a
  motion to represent himself, and (4) exclusion of evidence.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Gravelle filed a lawsuit in Nevada for defamation
  against Jim Webb (Webb) and Jay Long (Long).Â  The suit stemmed from a â€œbuyers
  bewareâ€ letter posted by Webb on ClearStar Security Network (ClearStar), a
  website for locksmiths, following Webbâ€™s purchase of a faulty machine manufactured
  by Gravelle.Â  Long is the creator of ClearStar.Â  The suit was dismissed and
  costs were assessed against Gravelle in the amount of $90,000.Â  Gravelle then
  filed a lawsuit in California against the same individuals.Â  Subsequently, Webb
  was dismissed from the California lawsuit, and Gravelle re-filed his lawsuit
  against Long in Nevada state court and federal court.Â  
Due to Gravelleâ€™s lawsuits against Long, Roberts wrote
  a post on ClearStar asking fellow locksmith members of ClearStar to contribute
  money to help Long defend the suits.Â  Robertsâ€™ post, captioned â€œClearStar under
  Fire (Again) . . . Terrorism of a Different Color,â€ stated in full:

  When we
    can no longer speak openly and freely on Forums such as Clearstar we certainly
    have been terrorized.Â  I think most of us who use Clearstar, for the intent
    that [Long] created it, will agree that it has become one of the most useful
    tools that we have.Â  My hope is that it will continue to mature as one of the
    best technical resources we have as Locksmiths.
  So I ask
    all who pay the 40 bucks a year . . . the 250 or 500 for lifetimeâ€¦to consider
    how much money Clearstar has made and/or saved you this year.Â  Think about it.
  Lets
    [sic] say you have worked hard this year . . . very hard . . . trying to grow
    and improve your business.Â  Then you get hit with a lawsuit (one which you
    donâ€™t deserve to be part of) costly, distracting and depressing.Â  Your friendâ€™s
    [sic] rally for you and the court with its wisdom throws the suit out . . . you
    relax.
  Now in a
    different venue . . . the State of California, the Lawsuit is new again . . . .
  Terrorism
    of a different Color . . . frivolous lawsuits.
  The
    Clearstar Defense Fund is open for business.

[Roberts]
Based
  on this post, Gravelle filed a complaint in South Carolina against Roberts[1] for libel.[2]Â 
  He filed this complaint in South Carolina because Roberts is an officer and
  employee of Beacon Safe & Lock, Inc., which is a South Carolina corporation.Â 
  Gravelle claimed Robertsâ€™ post accused him of â€œfiling frivolous lawsuits and
  carrying out deplorable actions akin to that of Osama Bin Ladin, [imputing
  toward him and his company] a lack of integrity, honesty, trust,
  professionalism . . . which held him up to ridicule, scorn mocking, etc . . .
  and lower[ing] him within his professional community.â€Â  
At
  the close of Gravelleâ€™s case, Roberts moved for a directed verdict and Gravelle
  moved to represent himself pro se, though he wanted to retain his
  current counsel as second chair.Â  The trial court denied Gravelleâ€™s motion for hybrid
  representation and granted Robertsâ€™ motion for a directed verdict, finding the
  publication was not defamatory as a matter of law, and alternatively, even if
  it was defamatory, it was not actionable per se.Â  Gravelle then
  filed a motion for a new trial, which was dismissed as untimely.Â  This appeal
  follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Directed Verdict
Gravelle
  maintains the trial court erred by granting Robertsâ€™ directed verdict motion.Â  We
  disagree.
In
  ruling on a motion for directed verdict, the trial court is required to view
  the evidence and inferences reasonably drawn therefrom in the light most
  favorable to the party opposing the motion and deny the motion when either the
  evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.Â  Law
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).Â  The
  appellate court will reverse the trial courtâ€™s ruling on a directed verdict
  motion only when there is no evidence to support the ruling or when the ruling
  is controlled by an error of law.Â  Id. at 434-35, 629 S.E.2d at 648.Â  When
  considering a directed verdict motion, neither the trial court nor the appellate
  court has authority to determine issues of credibility or to resolve conflicts
  in the testimony or evidence.Â  Erickson v. Jones St. Publishers, L.L.C.,
  368 S.C. 444, 463, 629 S.E.2d 653, 663 (2006).
â€œ[L]ibel
  is a written defamation or one accomplished by actions or conduct.â€Â  Holtzscheiter
    v. Thompson Newspapers, Inc., 332 S.C. 502, 508, 506 S.E.2d 497, 501
  (1998).Â  â€œThe tort of defamation allows a plaintiff to recover for injury to
  his or her reputation as the result of the defendantâ€™s communications to others
  of a false message about the plaintiff.â€Â  Parrish v. Allison, 376 S.C.
  308, 320, 656 S.E.2d 382, 388 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  To recover for defamation, the
  plaintiff must establish: â€œ(1) a false and defamatory statement concerning
  another; (2) an unprivileged publication to a third party; (3) fault on the
  part of the publisher; and (4) either actionability of the statement
  irrespective of special harm or the existence of special harm caused by the
  publication.â€Â  Lynch v. Toys â€œRâ€ Us-Del., Inc., 375 S.C. 604, 619, 654
  S.E.2d 541, 549 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  Pursuant to the first element, the trial
  court must initially determine if the statement is reasonably capable of
  conveying a defamatory meaning.Â  Parrish, 376 S.C. at 321, 656 S.E.2d at
  389.Â  
A
  statement can be defamatory per se or defamatory per quod.Â  Id.Â  Defamation per se occurs when the defamatory
  meaning of a statement is obvious on the face of the statement, whereas
  defamation per quod occurs when extrinsic evidence must be
  introduced in order to prove the defamatory meaning.Â  Holtzscheiter, 332
  S.C. at 508-09, 506 S.E.2d at 501.Â  
Robertsâ€™
  post is not defamatory on its face and, therefore, is not defamatory per se. Â See Whitaker v. Sherbrook Distrib. Co., 189 S.C. 243,
  245, 200 S.E. 848, 849 (1939) (stating for words to be libelous per se,
  the court must be able to presume without extrinsic evidence the plaintiff has
  been degraded or suffered some loss due to these words).Â  Robertsâ€™ post complains
  about frivolous lawsuits but does not name Gravelle as the instigator of the
  suits.Â  While we recognize Gravelleâ€™s name need not be referenced in the
  writing to support a libel action, we find the description in the writing too
  vague and any damage too nebulous to amount to defamation.Â  Cf. Nash
    v. Sharper, 229 S.C. 451, 456, 93 S.E.2d 457, 459 (1956) (â€œTo support an
  action for a libel, the plaintiffâ€™s name need not be mentioned in the writing;
  it is sufficient that there is a description of, or reference to, him, by which
  he may be known.â€).
Further,
  Gravelle failed to present any evidence indicating the statement was defamatory per quod.Â  See Fleming v. Rose, 338 S.C. 524, 532-33,
  526 S.E.2d 732, 737 (Ct. App. 2000), overruled on other grounds by Fleming
    v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 567 S.E.2d 857 (2002) (â€œIf the defamatory meaning is
  not clear unless the hearer knows facts or circumstances not contained in the
  statement itself, then the statement is defamatory per quod.â€).Â  Indeed,
  Gravelle was unable to show that even if additional information was known to
  the reader that the statement was false or that it resulted in harm to his
  reputation.
Moreover,
  even if Robertsâ€™ statement was defamatory, no evidence was presented showing
  the defamation was actionable.Â  See Capps v. Watts, 271 S.C. 276,
  281, 246 S.E.2d 606, 609 (1978) (â€œIf a publication is not both libelous and
  actionable, a cause of action for libel cannot lie.â€).Â  Specifically, Gravelle failed
  to plead and prove common law actual malice and special damages, and the
  statement is not the type from which the law presumes malice.Â  See Holtzscheiter,
  332 S.C. at 510, 506 S.E.2d at 501-02 (stating the law presumes malice and
  general damages with defamation that is actionable per se, but
  plaintiff must plead and prove malice and special damages if it is not
  actionable per se).Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err by
  directing a verdict in favor of Roberts.
II. New Trial Motion
Gravelle
  contends the trial court erred by dismissing his motion for a new trial as
  untimely.Â  We disagree.
Motions
  for new trials are governed by Rule 59 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil
  Procedure.Â  Boone v. Goodwin, 314 S.C. 374, 376, 444 S.E.2d 524, 525
  (1994). Â Rule 59(b), SCRCP, provides:Â  â€œThe motion for a new trial shall be
  made promptly after the jury is discharged, or in the discretion of the court
  not later than 10 days thereafter.â€Â  
The
  trial court granted Robertsâ€™ motion for a directed verdict and discharged the
  jury on May 24, 2005.Â  Gravelle did not serve his motion for a new trial until
  June 9, 2005.Â  Because the motion was not made within the ten days required by
  Rule 59(b), SCRCP, the trial court dismissed the motion as untimely.Â  Gravelle
  does not dispute his motion was served after ten days had elapsed from the time
  the jury was discharged.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not abuse its
  discretion by electing not to entertain Gravelleâ€™s motion.
III. Hybrid Representation
Gravelle
  argues the trial court erred in denying his motion for hybrid representation.Â 
  We find this argument to be abandoned on appeal.
An
  issue is deemed abandoned and will not be considered on appeal if the argument
  is raised in a brief but not supported by authority.Â  Historic Charleston Holdings, LLC v. Mallon, 365 S.C. 524, 533 n.7, 617 S.E.2d 388, 393 n.7 (Ct.
  App. 2005).Â  Gravelle has failed to cite any authority in support of his
  assertion that the trial court erred in denying his motion for hybrid
  representation, and he has, therefore, abandoned this issue on appeal.Â  
IV. Evidence
Gravelle
  maintains the trial court erred by excluding evidence supporting his special
  damages claim and evidence offered to show the effects of Robertsâ€™ alleged
  libel.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe
  admission or exclusion of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial
  court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Todd
    v. Joyner, 376 S.C. 114, 118-19, 654 S.E.2d 862, 864 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  â€œAn
  abuse of discretion occurs when the ruling is based on an error of law or a
  factual conclusion without evidentiary support.â€Â  Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 363 S.C. 460, 467, 611 S.E.2d 905, 908 (2005).

  a. Special Damages

The trial court excluded Gravelleâ€™s special damages
  exhibit because his damages were speculative and not compensable under South Carolina law.Â  South Carolina does not permit recovery for speculative damages.Â  Llewellyn
    v. Atl. Greyhound Corp., 204 S.C. 156, 170, 28 S.E.2d 673, 678 (1944).Â  Gravelle
  argued his special damages amounted to $110,490, which included: (1) deposition
  and trial expenses of airline tickets, hotel accommodations, car rentals, and
  out-of-pocket expenses such as food and gas, (2) loss of business (coinciding
  with deposition and trial dates), (3) prospective advertisement expenditures,
  and (4) expenses associated with attending trade shows.Â  As the trial court
  noted, the damages Gravelle sought were â€œprimarily related to the case.â€Â  The
  only damages not related to his lawsuit were future advertising expenses.Â  The
  evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s conclusion that these damages were
  speculative or not the type of damages compensable under South Carolina law.

  b. Effects of Libel Evidence

The
  trial court excluded the evidence depicting responses by other individuals to Robertsâ€™
  post, finding the evidence was hearsay.Â  Gravelle argues these responses are
  essential to establish the damage his reputation sustained as a direct and
  proximate result of Robertsâ€™ statements.Â  The responses offered, however, were written
  by third parties, not Roberts.Â  These responses were hearsay because they were
  written by third parties not testifying at trial or otherwise under oath and
  offered to prove Gravelleâ€™s reputation was damaged, and no exception applied to
  render this hearsay admissible.Â  SeeÂ  Rule 801(c), SCRE (â€œâ€˜Hearsayâ€™ is a
  statement, other than one made by the declarant while testifying at the trial
  or hearing, offered in evidence to prove the truth of the matter asserted.â€);
  Rule 802, SCRE (stating hearsay is not admissible unless an exception applies).Â 
  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in refusing to admit the responses.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.[3] 
WILLIAMS,
  THOMAS, and PIEPER, JJ., concur.Â 


[1] The action was
  filed against Roberts as an individual and as the
  principle officer of Beacon Safe & Lock, Inc. and DOES I through V, and Roe
  Corporations VI through X.Â  
[2] Gravelle also
  sued for tortious interference with prospective or existing business relations,
  but he abandoned the claim at trial.Â  
[3] We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â Â Â

THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE
  STATE OF
  
      
  SOUTH CAROLINA
  In
  The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The Estate of Rosa Tucker, by and
          through her Personal Representative, Ernest Tucker, Respondent,
        v.
        Roy Tucker, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From
  
  
  Richland
  
County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr.,
Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-284
Heard June 3, 2008 â€“ Filed June 4, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Mark D. Cauthen and T. Jeff Goodwyn, Jr., both of
          
          Columbia, for Appellant.
        Donald E. Rothwell, of Irmo and Jan L.
          Warner and Matthew E. Steinmetz, both of
          Columbia,
          for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Rosa Tucker filed this complaint in 2003 against her
  oldest son, Roy Tucker (Tucker), alleging fraud, conversion, constructive
  trust, intentional infliction of emotional distress, negligence per se for
  violation of the Omnibus Elderly Abuse Statute, and unfair trade practices.Â 
      
  Rosa died in
  2004 and the action was continued on behalf of the Estate of Rosa Tucker (the
  Estate) by the personal representative, Ernest Tucker.Â  After a bench trial, the circuit court issued
  an order finding the Estate was entitled to a constructive trust in the amount
  of $22,000.Â  The court denied the
  Estateâ€™s remaining claims.Â  The circuit
  court thereafter denied Tuckerâ€™s post-trial motion to alter or amend the
  judgment.Â  Tucker appeals.
On
  appeal, Tucker asserts (1) the circuit court erred in imposing a constructive
  trust, (2) even if the constructive trust was properly imposed, the circuit
  court erred in establishing the amount of the trust as $22,000, and (3) the
  circuit court erred in denying his motion for a new trial or a new trial nisi remittitur.
1.Â  Imposition of
  Constructive Trust.
This
  dispute arises out of Tuckerâ€™s purchase of two residences that his mother lived
  in located at
 
  3626 Hydrangea
  Street and
 
  3601 Edmond Drive in
  
  Columbia,
  
  South Carolina.Â  The Estate alleges Tucker used money advanced
  to him by his mother to make the purchases, but he did not repay the amounts
  loaned to him.Â  The circuit court granted
  a constructive trust to the Estate pertaining to the
  
  Hydrangea Street property.Â  
In
  his appeal, Tucker first alleges the circuit court erred in finding a
  constructive trust should be imposed.Â  Tucker contends (a) there has been no finding of fraud, bad faith, abuse
  of confidence, or violation of a fiduciary duty that would give rise to an
  obligation in equity to make restitution, (b) the Estate has not established
  its entitlement to a trust by clear and convincing evidence, and (c) the
  Estateâ€™s complaint did not seek the establishment of a trust for the Hydrangea
  Street property.Â  
"A
  constructive trust arises entirely by operation of law without reference to any
  actual or supposed intentions of creating a trust."Â  McNair v. Rainsford, 330
  S.C. 332, 356, 499 S.E.2d 488, 501 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  "It is resorted to by equity to vindicate
  right and justice or frustrate fraud."Â 
      
      Id.Â  Because an action to declare a constructive
  trust is in equity, this Court may find the facts in accordance with its own
  view of the evidence.Â  Lollis
    v. Lollis, 291 S.C. 525, 530, 354 S.E.2d 559, 561 (1987).
"A
  constructive trust will arise whenever the circumstances under which property
  was acquired make it inequitable that it should be retained by the one holding
  the legal title."Â  Lollis,
  291 S.C. at 529, 354 at 561.Â  "A
  constructive trust results from fraud, bad faith, abuse of confidence, or
  violation of a fiduciary duty which gives rise to an obligation in equity to
  make restitution."Â 
      
      Id.Â  "A
  constructive trust arises whenever a party has obtained money which does not
  equitably belong to him and which he cannot in good conscience retain or
  withhold from another who is beneficially entitled to it as where money has
  been paid by accident, mistake of fact, or fraud, or has been acquired through
  a breach of trust or the violation of a fiduciary duty."Â  SSI Med. Servs., Inc. v.
    Cox, 301 S.C. 493, 500, 392 S.E.2d 789, 793-94 (1990). 
The
  burden is on the plaintiff to establish a constructive trust by clear and
  convincing evidence.Â  McNair, 330
  S.C. at 357, 499 S.E.2d at 501; see also Lollis, 291 S.C. at
  530, 354 S.E.2d at 561 ("In order to establish a constructive trust, the
  evidence must be clear, definite, and unequivocal.").Â  Although fraud is generally cited as an
  element to establish a constructive trust, a party need not show actual
  fraud.Â  McNair, 330 S.C. at 357, 499 S.E.2d at 501.Â  Further, "equity is less than demanding and quite flexible in
  prescribing the elements essential to a constructive trust."Â  Whitmire v. Adams,
  273 S.C. 453, 458, 257 S.E.2d 160, 163 (1979).
Initially,
  we find Tuckerâ€™s argument that the circuit court erred in imposing a
  constructive trust because the Estate did not seek the establishment of a
  constructive trust as to the
 
  Hydrangea
  Street property, but only claimed a constructive
  trust for the
  
  Edmond Drive
  property, is not properly before us.Â  Tucker did not raise this alleged error to the circuit court in a
  post-trial motion.Â  Where a trial court
  grants relief that was not requested, the proper procedure for the party
  alleging error is to make a post-trial motion to the trial court to alter or amend
  the order.Â  See, e.g., Pelican
    Bldg. Ctrs. of Horry-Georgetown, Inc. v. Dutton, 311 S.C. 56, 60, 427
  S.E.2d 673, 675 (1993); Godfrey v. Heller, 311 S.C. 516, 520-21,
  429 S.E.2d 859, 862 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  An
  alleged error may not be raised for the first time on appeal; rather, it must
  be both raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for
  appellate review.Â  Pye v. Estate of
    Fox, 369 S.C. 555, 564, 633 S.E.2d 505, 510 (2006) ("It is well
  settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved."); see Staubes v. City of Folly
    Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) ("Error preservation requirements are intended â€˜to enable the lower
  court to rule properly after it has considered all relevant facts, law, and
  arguments.â€™ " (quoting Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of
    
      
    Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 422, 526
  S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000))).Â  Thus, this
allegation is not preserved.
We
  next consider Tuckerâ€™s argument that a constructive trust was not proper in
  this case because the Estate made no showing of fraud, a confidential
  relationship, or any other qualifying element by clear and convincing
  evidence.Â  The Estate contends the
  circuit court did specifically find "that [Tucker] and his mother were clearly
  in a confidential relationship, [Tucker] was the dominant party in the
  transactions complained of, that [Tuckerâ€™s] mother relied upon him and trusted
  him, and [Tucker] provided little evidence that the transactions were fair or
  equitable."Â Â Â  
We
  have previously noted that "a precise definition of a confidential relationship
  is elusive . . . ."Â  Chapman v. Citizens & S. Natâ€™l Bank, 302 S.C. 469, 475, 395
  S.E.2d 446, 450 (Ct. App. 1990).Â "Confidential relations are deemed to arise whenever two persons have
  come into such a relation that confidence is necessarily reposed by one and the
  influence which naturally grows out of the confidence is possessed by the
  other, and this confidence is abused or the influence is exerted to obtain an
  advantage at expense of confiding party."Â 
      
      Id. at 476, 395 S.E.2d at 451.Â  In Chapman we quoted the following
  definition from Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary:

  Confidential relation.Â  A fiduciary relation.Â  It is a peculiar relation which exists between client and attorney,
    principal and agent, principal and surety, landlord and tenant, parent and
    child . . . .Â  In these and like cases, the law, in order to
    prevent undue advantage from the unlimited confidence or sense of duty which
    the relation naturally creates, requires the utmost degree of good faith in all
    transactions between the parties.Â  It is
    not confined to any specific association of parties.Â  It appears when the circumstances make it
    certain that the parties do not deal on equal terms, but on the one side there
    is an overmastering influence, or, on the other, weakness, dependence, or
      trust, justifiably reposed. The mere existence of kinship does not, of
    itself, give rise to such relation.Â  It
    covers every form of relation between parties wherein confidence is reposed by
    one in another, and [the] former relies and acts upon representations of the
    other and is guilty of no derelictions on his own part.


  
  Id. at 476, 395 S.E.2d at 450-51 (quoting Blackâ€™s Law
    Dictionary 270 (5th ed. 1979)).
We
  agree with the Estate that the circuit court did, in fact, find a confidential
  relationship existed between Tucker and his mother.Â  Although the circuit court did not expressly
  use the phrase "confidential relationship," it is clear the court made this
  determination after reviewing the courtâ€™s findings as follows:Â  (1) Tucker "has benefited from his
  relationship with his mother by taking money from her by way of an $8[,]000.00
  loan, by selling property to her for stated consideration of $14,000.00, and
  then having her re-convey the property for love and affection"; (2) Tucker "was
  the dominant party in these transactions and a businessman who, by his own
  testimony, buys and sells real estate, sells life insurance, and owns rental
  houses"; (3) Tucker "also prepared the deeds that were signed by his
  mother"; and (4) Tuckerâ€™s mother "never graduated from high school and
  relied upon and trusted Roy Tucker in these transactions."Â Â Â  
We
  hold the circuit court did not err in determining the imposition of a
  constructive trust was appropriate under the circumstances.Â Â  Tucker seeks the imposition of a strict
  standard that is not required by our case law.Â  As noted above,
  
  South Carolina
  law provides actual fraud need not be shown to warrant imposition of a
  constructive trust, and the courts are flexible in determining the
  circumstances that justify the imposition of a constructive trust.Â  See Whitmire, 273 S.C. at 458,
  257 S.E.2d at 163 ("[E]quity is less than demanding and quite flexible in
  prescribing the elements essential to a constructive trust.").Â  
In
  this case, Tucker had a confidential relationship with his mother and he was
  able to obtain funds from her based on the reliance and trust she placed in him
  to direct these business transactions.Â  Tuckerâ€™s mother was an older adult in poor health who did not complete her high school education, and she acquiesced in the decisions
  of her son.Â  Tucker prepared the deeds
  and was in control of the transactions.Â  Because Tucker has never repaid these funds, we agree with the circuit
  court that it is only just and equitable that the law provides recovery to his
  motherâ€™s Estate by means of the imposition of a constructive trust.Â  See, e.g., Devlin v. Devlin, 89
  S.C. 268, 271, 71 S.E. 966, 968 (1911) (approving the principle of law
  that "where confidential relations exist between persons, the law looks with
  suspicion upon any transaction between them, whereby the superior gains an
  advantage to himself over the other"). 
2.Â  Amount of Constructive
  Trust.
Tucker
  further contends that, even if the circuit court properly imposed a
  constructive trust, the court erred in finding the trust amount should be
  $22,000.Â  Tucker argues $14,000 of this
  amount, which is the sum that was recited in the deed of the
 
  Hydrangea Street property, was never
  actually paid to him by his mother.Â  He
  also contends he is entitled to an offset for the unpaid rent, mortgage
  payments, taxes, insurance, and the amount he expended for repairs.Â  
In
  his testimony, Tucker admitted he had not repaid his mother the $8,000 she had
  advanced for his purchase of the
  
  Hydrangea
  Street home.Â  Tucker also admitted there is a deed that shows he received $14,000 from
  his mother and transferred the home to her.Â  When asked about his receipt of the $14,000 during his testimony, Tucker
  stated, "Thatâ€™s what it says . . . ."Â  Although Tucker now disputes that he ever received the $14,000 recited
  as consideration in the deed, we cannot say the circuit court erred in its
  determination of the amount of the trust.Â  Under our standard of review, we may take our own view of the evidence,
  but we are also aware that the circuit court was in the best position to hear
  the witnesses and evaluate their credibility in this regard.Â  See Latimer v.
    Farmer, 360 S.C. 375, 380, 602 S.E.2d 32, 34 (2004) ("We are not
  required to disregard the findings of the trial judge who saw
  and heard the witnesses and was in
  a better position to evaluate their credibility.").Â  Accordingly, we are not inclined to disturb the circuit courtâ€™s finding
  that Tucker received the sum of $14,000 as recited in the deed regarding the
  
      
  Hydrangea Street
property.
Additionally,
  we find the issue of an offset has been waived.Â  Tucker did not seek an offset in his pleadings and Tuckerâ€™s counsel
  expressly advised the circuit court at the trial in this matter:Â  "We do not claim an offset for rent, your
  Honor, in this case."Â  Thereafter, the
  court denied counselâ€™s belated, oral motion to amend the pleadings to seek an
  offset.Â  Although Tucker filed a motion
  to reconsider asking for a "remittitur" based on the unpaid rent, we note a
  remittitur is a term of art and it is distinguishable from establishing the
  entitlement to an offset that is proven at trial in the first instance.Â  Moreover, as for the rent, we find any
  calculation for unpaid rent would be speculative as we do not know what the
  rent would be after Tuckerâ€™s mother moved to the
  
  Edmond Street property and Tucker made no
  offer of proof.Â  
Finally,
  we note Tucker is attempting on appeal to expand the items for which he is
  seeking an offset, as he is now claiming an offset for additional items other
  than rent, such as taxes, insurance, and repairs.Â  Consequently, we find no merit to Tuckerâ€™s
  contention that the circuit court erred in failing to grant him an offset
  against the amount awarded for the constructive trust.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330
  S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) ("It is axiomatic that an issue
  cannot be raised for the first time
  on appeal, but must have been raised
  to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved
  for appellate review."); Hurst v. Sumter County, 189 S.C. 376, 381, 1
  S.E.2d 238, 240 (1939) ("Under the settled law of this State, an essential
  preliminary to the allowance of an offset is that the offset claimed must be pleaded, and there must be some
  evidence tending to establish such plea."); Doe v. ATC, Inc., 367 S.C.
  199, 205 n.4, 624 S.E.2d 447, 450 n.4 (Ct. App. 2005) ("Issue preservation
  rules preclude us from expanding the case and issues
  beyond those argued in the trial court."). 
3.Â  New Trial or New Trial Nisi Remittitur.
Based
  on our disposition, we need not reach Tuckerâ€™s remaining issue seeking a new
  trial or a new trial nisi remittitur.
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.
