THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Jack H. Biel
          and Biel &
          Clark, P.A., Respondents,
        v.
        William C.
          Clark and Clark &
          Stevens, P.A., Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Edward D. Buckley, Jr., Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-285
Heard May 7, 2008 â€“ Filed June 4, 2008
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled
September 23, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Attorney Robert L. Widener, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Attorney Drew A. Laughlin, of Hilton Head Island, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action arising out of the dissolution of a law
  practice, William C. Clark (Clark) and Clark & Stevens, P.A. appeal the
  special refereeâ€™s finding that contingency fee cases were an asset of the firm
  subject to distribution in accordance with the partiesâ€™ respective ownership
  interests.Â  Clark further asserts the special referee erred in finding unjust
  enrichment and in granting relief that exceeded the relief requested by
  plaintiffs.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Jack
  H. Biel (Biel) and Clark practiced law together as a professional association
  organized as a professional corporation under the name Biel & Clark, P.A.
  (the Firm).Â  Clark joined the Firm in 1988 and became an equal shareholder
  sometime in late 1989 or early 1990.Â  During the twelve year duration of the
  Firmâ€™s practice, Biel primarily handled real estate, probate, estate planning,
  and business matters, while Clark handled litigation and domestic matters.Â  Biel and Clark shared equally in the profits and expenses of all legal matters handled by
  the Firm, regardless of the originating attorney or the working attorney. Â 
Biel and Clark mutually agreed to cease practicing law
  together as Biel & Clark, P.A., effective December 31, 2000.Â  There was no written agreement governing the termination of the Firmâ€™s practice.Â  The
  professional association remains in existence and has been in the process of
  winding up since the mutual agreement to cease practicing law together.Â  
At
  the time the Firm concluded its operations, Clark was handling several
  significant cases that he retained and continued to manage at his new firm.Â Â Â 
  Among these cases are three contingency fee cases that are the subject of the
  present litigation: (1) McKinley; (2) Southwind II; and (3) Ocean Palms.Â  The
  McKinley case is a personal injury matter involving Grant McKinley, a longtime
  friend and client of Biel.Â  The Southwind II and Ocean Palms cases are complex
  construction matters involving condominium and timeshare projects.Â  There was
  no agreement between Biel and Clark regarding attorneyâ€™s fees that might be
  earned on these cases.Â  
Due
  to his personal relationship with Grant McKinley and his prior legal work for
  the Southwind II property ownersâ€™ association, Biel played a significant role
  in procuring the McKinley and Southwind II cases for the Firm.Â  
With
  regard to the McKinley case, Clark worked a total of 52.7 hours and collected a
  fee of $50,000.00.Â  Of that time, 17.8 hours were expended prior to December 31, 2000.Â  Prior to that date, the Firm advanced $1,233.33 for costs.Â  When the
  case settled, Clark tendered $5,000.00 to Biel as a finderâ€™s fee. 
With
  regard to the Southwind II matter, Clark worked a total of 95.75 hours and
  received a fee of $203,291.91.[1]Â 
  Of the 95.75 hours, Clark worked a total of 16.75 hours prior to December 31, 2000, and the Firm advanced a total of $393.04 for costs.Â  A settlement
  statement dated March 1, 2002, and signed by the president of Southwind IIâ€™s
  governing body shows â€œ[t]otal expenses for Biel & Clark, P.A.â€ of $550.21.Â 
  Clarkâ€™s time and expense records show that those expenses were incurred after December 31, 2000; however, they are attributed to the Firm on the settlement statement.Â 
  The balance of the fee was retained by Clark and Stevens, P.A..[2]
As
  to Ocean Palms, this case was procured by Clark.Â  Prior to December 31, 2000,
  the work performed by the Firm for Ocean Palms was billed on an hourly basis
  and the fees earned and billed on that basis were collected and distributed
  equally between Biel and Clark.Â  In September of 2001, Clark entered into a
  contingency fee agreement with Ocean Palms.Â Â Â  At the time of the hearing
  before the special referee, portions of the Ocean Palms case had settled and a
  fee of $275,000.00 had been collected.Â  Other portions of the case were pending
  settlement at the time of the hearing.
Prior
  to December 31, 2000, the clients in the McKinley, Southwind II, and Ocean
  Palms cases did not receive written notification that Biel and Clark were
  ceasing to practice law together or that the Firm was going to cease
  operations.Â  The Firm appears as counsel for the plaintiffs in pleadings filed
  in all of these cases both before and after December 31, 2000.Â  Clark took no steps to see that the Firm was relieved as counsel in any of the disputed
  cases.Â  
On February 19, 2001, and March 19, 2001, Biel wrote Clark setting forth his understanding
  that the fees generated by the McKinley case would be split equally between the
  two attorneys.Â  In his letter, Biel also set forth his understanding that the
  fees generated by the Southwind II and Ocean Palms cases would be paid 50% to
  the Mullen firm, with the remaining balance shared equally between Biel and Clark.Â  Biel further invited Clark to advise him if his understanding differed
  from Bielâ€™s.Â  Biel received no response from Clark until he settled the McKinley
  case more than one year later and tendered the $5,000.00 finderâ€™s fee to Biel.Â  
On February 3, 2006, a hearing was held on the matter.[3]Â 
  Biel alleged causes of action for dissolution of the Firm, breach of
  contract, breach of fiduciary duty, unjust enrichment, and an accounting.Â 
  Specifically, Biel sought dissolution of the Firm and a distribution of 50% of
  the fees generated by the above-mentioned cases.Â  In an amended order dated February 28, 2006, the special referee held that the disputed fees were assets of the Firm
  to be distributed in accordance with the partiesâ€™ relative ownership
  interests.Â  The special referee rejected Bielâ€™s breach of contract claim
  concluding that plaintiffs failed to prove the existence of a contract
  pertaining to the disputed fees or its breach.Â  As an alternative holding, the special
  referee accepted Bielâ€™s unjust enrichment claim, finding that Biel had a
  reasonable expectation of payment from the contingency cases; that Clark should
  have reasonably expected to pay Biel; and that society would reasonably expect
  payment to Biel under these circumstances.Â  Based on these findings, the
  special referee ordered Clark to pay 25% of the fees generated by the Southwind
  II matter and 25% of the fees generated and to be generated by the Ocean Palms
  matter to Biel.Â  This allocation recognized that the Mullen firm was to receive
  or had received 50% of the fees from these cases.Â  On August 7, 2006, the special referee further ordered that the fees generated by the Ocean Palms matter
  after the issuance of the February 28, 2006, order shall be paid to the Firm
  and that the Firm be reimbursed for all expenses incurred in prosecuting the
  matter.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
This
  case involves both actions in law and in equity. Â â€œWhen legal and equitable
  actions are maintained in one suit, each retains its own identity as legal or
  equitable for purposes of the applicable standard of review on appeal.â€Â  Corley
    v. Ott, 326 S.C. 89, 92, 485 S.E.2d 97, 99 n. 1 (1997) (citing Future Group
      v. Nationsbank, 324 S.C. 89, 478 S.E.2d 45 (1996)).
â€œIn an
  action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact
  of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without
  evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings . . . . The judgeâ€™s
  findings are equivalent to a juryâ€™s findings in a law action.â€ Â Townes
    Assoc., Ltd. v. Cty of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775
  (1976).Â  A special referee, under Rule 53(c), SCRCP, â€œshall exercise all power
  and authority which a circuit [court] sitting without a jury would have in a
  similar matter.â€Â  Accordingly, our review of a special refereeâ€™s decision is
  limited to the correction of errors of law.Â  Id. at 85, 221 S.E.2d at
  775.
A
  corporate dissolution is an action at equity.Â  Jordan v. Holt,
  362 S.C. 201, 205, 608 S.E.2d 129, 131 (2005).Â  In actions at equity, this
  court can find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of
  the evidence.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Clark argues the
  special referee erred in finding the contingency fee cases were assets of the
  Firm subject to marshalling and distribution through the dissolution of the
  Firm.Â  Specifically, Clark contends the contingency cases and fees are not
  assets of the firm because all three cases were transferred to him after the
  break-up of the Firm.[4]Â 
  He further asserts the referee erred because Biel did not allege the cases and
  fees were assets of the Firm in their complaint. Â We disagree.
As
  an initial matter, we note Clark failed to cite supporting authority for the primary
  arguments asserted in his brief on appeal. Â However, to the extent appellant
  asserts the lack of any South Carolina authority regarding the primary issues
  raised, we proceed to review the arguments asserted.
The
  disposition of attorneyâ€™s fees upon the dissolution of a law firm organized as
  a professional corporation in the absence of an agreement governing the
  dissolution is an issue of first impression in South Carolina.Â  Cognizant of
  the reciprocal and continuing obligations of former law partners, a majority of
  courts apply the principles of partnership law to professional corporations
  where withdrawal of attorney-shareholders results in the dissolution of the
  corporate entity. Â See, e.g., Boyd, Payne, Gates, & Farthing,
    P.C. v. Payne, Gates, Farthing & Radd, P.C., 422 S.E.2d 784, 789-90 (Va.
  1992); Fox v. Abrams, 163 Cal. App. 3d 610, 616-17 (1985); Breaking
    Up Is Hard To Do: Allocating Fees From the unfinished Business Of A
    Professional Corporation, 64 U. Chi., L. Rev. 1367, 1368-79 (Fall 1997). Â Â 
Under
  the principles of partnership law as codified in the Uniform Partnership Act
  (UPA), all partners, upon dissolution, have a fiduciary duty to wind up the
  unfinished business of the partnership and to divide the resulting fees based
  upon each partnerâ€™s interest in the former partnership. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  33-41-370 (2006).Â  Likewise, courts applying a partnership analysis to allocate
  fees from the unfinished business of a law firm organized as a professional
  corporation find work in progress at the time of dissolution an asset of the
  firm in which the partners of the former firm have a fiduciary duty to
  complete.Â  See, e.g., First Union Natâ€™l Bank of Maryland v. Meyer,
    Faller, Weisman & Rosenberg, 723 A.2d 899, 905-07 (Md. App. 1999); Marr v. Langhoff, 589 A.2d 470, 475-77 (Md. 1991); Resnick v. Kaplan,
  434 A.2d 582, 586-88 (Md. App. 1981). Â In determining allocation of fees in
  this context, these courts hold the distribution of fees resulting from
  completion of work in progress, absent special agreement, be allocated
  according to each partnerâ€™s interest in the profits of the dissolved firm.Â  See,
    e.g., Sufrin v. Hosier, 896 F.Supp. 766, 768-69 (N.D.ILL. 1995); Boyd, Payne, Gates, & Farthing, P.C., 422 S.E.2d at 789-90; Sullivan,
      Bodney & Hammond v. Bodney, 820 P.2d 1248, 1250-51 (Kan. App. 1991); Fox,
  163 Cal. App. 3d 610, 616-17.
In
  the case at hand, the Firm was organized as a professional corporation
  controlled by two attorney-shareholders, Biel and Clark. Consistent with the
  majority approach stated above, application of a partnership analysis is
  appropriate where the withdrawal of the attorney-shareholders results in the
  dissolution of the corporate entity.Â  Here, it is undisputed that the
  withdrawal of Biel and Clark from the Firm resulted in the dissolution of the
  partnersâ€™ professional corporation.Â  Thus, the work in progress associated with
  the three contingency fee cases constituted unfinished business in which Biel and Clark had a fiduciary duty to complete.Â  As such, the resulting fees generated by
  the completion of these three cases during the winding up process are deemed
  assets of the Firm subject to distribution based upon Biel and Clarkâ€™s ownership interest in the profits of the Firm.Â  Therefore, based upon our review of
  the record, we find the fees generated from the three contingency fee cases in
  dispute are assets of the Firm subject to marshalling and distribution between Biel and Clark.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the manner in which the special referee determined
  the allocation of the fees and expenses.
Because we affirm
  the decision of the special referee as to dissolution and distribution of fees,
  we need not reach the special refereeâ€™s alternative holding regarding unjust
  enrichment.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc.,
  335 S.C. 598, 518 S.E.2d 591 (1999) (holding an appellate court need not review
  remaining issues when its determination of a prior issue is dispositive of the
  appeal); see also Weeks v. McMillan, 291 S.C. 287, 292,
  353 S.E.2d 289, 292 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œWhere a decision is based on alternative
  grounds, either of which independent of the other is sufficient to support it,
  the decision will not be reversed even if one of the grounds is erroneous.â€).Â  Â 
Finally, Clark argues
  the special referee erred in granting relief that exceeded the relief requested
  by Biel.Â  We disagree.
Our
  supreme court has held that where â€œthe facts alleged are broad enough to
  warrant relief, it matters not how narrow the specific prayer may be if the
  bill contains a prayer for general relief.â€Â  McMaster v. Strickland, 322
  S.C. 451, 454, 472 S.E.2d 623, 625 (1996) (citing Mortgage Loan Co. v.
    Townsend, 156 S.C. 203, 152 S.E. 878 (1930)).Â  In addition to a prayer for
  dissolution and winding up of the Firmâ€™s business and affairs, Bielâ€™s complaint also contains a prayer for general relief.Â  Furthermore, the factual
  allegations of the complaint regarding dissolution of the Firm support the
  special refereeâ€™s division of fees in this manner.Â  Thus, we find the relief
  granted was appropriate. 
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing
  reasons, the order of the special referee is 
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS, THOMAS,
and PIEPER, JJ., concur.


[1] The fee for Southwind II was split between Clark and
  the Mullen firm, which was associated by Clark and/or the Firm to assist in
handling the case.Â  The $203,291.91 reflects the amount received by Clark after paying 50% of the fee to the Mullen firm. 
[2] The balance retained reflects the amount of the fee
received after paying the Mullen firmâ€™s fees and expenses.Â  
[3] None of the clients in the three cases at issue
testified at the hearing.Â  
[4] We find it essential to note that pursuant to Rule
  1.16 of the Rules of Professional Conduct, the right to discharge a lawyer at
  any time, with or without cause, lies solely with the client.Â  As such, any
  indication that the clients in these matters did in fact discharge the Firm
  from representation would significantly impact the decision in this case.Â 
  However, the record is deficient of any writing, testimony, or other evidence from
  the client to show the clientâ€™s intent in these three cases.Â  Thus, absent a
  showing that the clients directed otherwise, we cannot find error based on this
  allegation.

PER CURIAM:Â  Elijah Battle appeals his conviction for armed

  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  State
    v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 77, 538 S.E.2d 257, 263 (Ct. App. 2000) (a trial
  courtâ€™s ruling on admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal
  absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error which results in
  prejudice to the defendant); State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 507, 435
  S.E.2d 859, 862 (1993) (stating that any error in admission of evidence
  cumulative to other unobjected-to evidence is harmless); State v. Johnson,
  298 S.C. 496, 499, 381 S.E.2d 732, 733 (1989) ("The admission of improper
  evidence is harmless where it is merely cumulative to other evidence.").Â  
AFFIRMED.[1]
HEARN,
  C.J., and SHORT, J., and KONDUROS, J., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Spartanburg
          County Department of Social Services, Respondent,
        v.
        Cheryl W.,
          Garvin S., and John Doe, Defendants,
        Of Whom Cheryl
          W. is the Appellant.
        In the interests of: T.S., G.S., A.S., A.S.,
  and C.S., minors under the age of 18.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Wesley L. Brown, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-287
  Submitted June 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 4,
2008 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        W. Cory Hughes, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Julie Rau, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
        Michael Todd Thigpen, of Spartanburg, for
          Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Cheryl W. appeals from a family court order terminating her parental rights to
  five minor children. Â Upon a thorough review of the record and the family
  courtâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law, pursuant to Ex Parte
    Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354 S.E.2d 381 (1987), we find no meritorious issues
  warrant briefing.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the family courtâ€™s ruling and grant
  counselâ€™s petition to be relieved. 
AFFIRMED.[1]
HEARN,
  C.J., KONDUROS, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

      & Water Conservation District, Defendants,

John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-292
Submitted June 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 5,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				David L. Thomas, of Greenville, for Appellants.
				N. Ward Lambert and R. Patrick Smith, both of Greenville, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIAM:Â  In this civil action, Robert
  Michael Gaddis (R.M. Gaddis) and Robert S. Gaddis (R.S. Gaddis) appeal the
  trial courtâ€™s dismissal of their claims under section 15-36-100 of the South
  Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) and the alternative ground of res judicata.Â 
  We affirm.[1] 
As to the professional negligence claim, S.C. Code Â§ 15-36-100(E) (Supp. 2007) provides that a defective
  affidavit may result in dismissal for failure to state a claim unless cured by
  amendment within thirty days.Â  Here, the court never addressed in its final
  order the plaintiffsʼ request to amend the affidavit or pleadings to
  allege a supervisory theory of recovery and the court was never asked to do so
  pursuant to a Rule 59(e) motion. Â Therefore, the supervisory theory of recovery was never asserted
  by amended affidavit or further developed in the record. Â See Jones v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins.
    Co., 364 S.C. 222, 235, 612 S.E.2d 719, 726 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œ[A]n issue is
  not preserved where the trial court does not explicitly rule on an argument and
  the appellant does not make a Rule 59 motion to alter or amend the judgment.â€
  (citing Hawkins v. Mullins, 359 S.C. 497, 501-02, 597 S.E.2d 897, 899
  (Ct. App. 2004))).Â  Similarly, the argument presented on appeal as to the
  effective date of the statute was never raised to the trial court.Â  See Wilder
    Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (noting an
  issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised
  to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review). Â Thus,
  these issues are not preserved for our review.Â  
As to the trespass and nuisance causes of action, the trial court
  never explicitly addressed these claims in its final order.Â  Moreover, the
  court was never asked to explicitly address these claims after the written
  order was filed.Â  Accordingly, these issues are not preserved for review.Â  See Jones, 364 S.C. at 235, 612 S.E.2d at 726.
Based on our ruling, we need not address the alternative ground of res judicata as to R.M. Gaddis.Â  See Whiteside v.
  Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 428 S.E.2d 886 (1993)
  (finding the court need not address remaining issue when resolution of prior
  issue is dispositive).
AFFIRMED.
THOMAS,
  J., PIEPER, J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.

	
		
			
				THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
				In The Court of Appeals
				William
      Kissiah, Plaintiff,
				v.
				Respiratory Products,
      Inc., Employer and Bridgefield Casualty Ins. Co., Carrier, Employment
      Staffing, Inc., Companion Property & Casualty Insurance Company, Defendants,
				of whom
      Respiratory Products, Inc., Employer and Bridgefield Casualty Ins. Co.,
      Carrier are the Appellants,
				andÂ  William
      Kissiah and Employment Staffing, Inc., Companion Property & Casualty
      Insurance Company are the Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Anderson County
Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-293
Submitted June 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 5,
  2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Roy Allen Howell, III, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellants.
				Amy V. Cofield, of Lexington and T. Lowndes Pope, Â of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â Respiratory Products, Inc., Employer,
  and Bridgefield Casualty Ins. Co., Carrier (collectively RPI) appeal the
  circuit courtâ€™s affirmance of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s
  determination that RPI was liable for William Kissiahâ€™s claim.[1] 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
The
  only issue in this appeal is whether RPI remained liable for Kissiahâ€™s workersâ€™
  compensation claim after it contracted with Employment Staffing, Inc. (ESI), an
  employee leasing company.Â  On May 12, 2003, Kissiah was injured while working
  in RPIâ€™s Anderson office.Â  Shortly before his accident, RPI had entered into an
  agreement with ESI for ESI to lease to it part-time employees.Â  As part of this
  contract, the employment of RPIâ€™s existing part-time employees was to transfer
  to ESI. Â ESI memorialized their agreement in a letter dated May 2, 2003, which
  provided:

	This is to inform you that as of 5-1-03, per our previous
  agreement, you have been assigned to our company.Â  The employees will be on
  ESIâ€™s payroll effective 7am on 5-11-03. Â All employees who work after this time
  will be the responsibility of ESI.Â  Our company will cover these employees for
  their workmans comp insurance.Â  . . .

Kissiah was not at work on the Friday before the contract date
  when the other employees completed their employment paperwork for ESI.Â  His
  accident occurred the following Monday, the first working day under the
  contract.Â  On the date of the accident, Kissiah had never heard of ESI.Â  He did
  not complete any paperwork for ESI until June 4, 2003.Â  He had not provided ESI
  with a copy of his social security card at the time of the hearing.Â  
ESI employee Lisa Gaines testified that if a person had not filled
  out an application and provided a copy of their photo identification and social
  security card, that person could not be an employee of ESI.Â  She stated ESI
  needed all three items to be able to pay someone.Â  However, she stated that if
  Kissiah provided ESI with his social security card, ESI would pay him for the
  hours he worked on May 12, but he would not be considered an employee until the
  time he submitted the card.Â  
RPI
  paid Kissiah one temporary total disability check after the accident but
  stopped paying without filing or serving a Form 15.Â  Although Kissiah had been
  out of work since the accident, he received no other payments from either RPI
  or ESI. Â When Kissiah filed the present claim, both RPI and ESI denied
  liability and asserted they were not Kissiahâ€™s employer on the date of the
  accident.Â  RPI also asserted Kissiah was injured outside the course and scope
  of his employment and therefore was not entitled to any benefits.Â  
The single commissioner held Kissiah had sustained a compensable
  injury by accident but had not reached maximum medical improvement.Â  She held
  he was entitled to temporary total disability benefits and continuing medical
  treatment.Â  In addition, the single commissioner found he was an employee â€œin
  limboâ€ between RPI and ESI and ordered both employers to split liability
  50/50.Â  She also held RPI must pay a 25% fine on the amount of temporary total
  disability benefits it owed to Kissiah for improperly stopping the payment of
  benefits.Â  Both RPI and ESI appealed to the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  
The Commission affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s ruling that
  Kissiah had sustained an injury by accident arising out of and in the course of
  his employment and was entitled to benefits.Â  However, it reversed the single
  commissionerâ€™s division of liability and held only RPI was liable for the
  claim.Â  
The circuit court affirmed the Commissionâ€™s ruling concerning
  Kissiahâ€™s entitlement to benefits.Â  However, it remanded the case to the
  Commission to rule on Kissiahâ€™s motion to alter or amend.Â  In its amended order,
  the Commission held the proposed agreement between RPI and ESI did not affect
  Kissiahâ€™s employment status.Â  As Kissiah failed to meet the eligibility for
  ESI, he remained in the employ and control of RPI on the date of his accident.Â 
  RPI appealed this ruling to the circuit court, which affirmed.Â  RPI then
  appealed to this court.Â  
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
ESI questions whether the issue before this court is
  jurisdiction.Â  Generally, the issue of whether a claimant is an employee is
  jurisdictional and therefore the question on appeal is one of law.Â  Nelson
    v. Yellow Cab Co., 349 S.C. 589, 594, 564 S.E.2d 110, 112 (2002). Â Thus,
  the appellate court can take its own view of preponderance of the evidence on
  the issue of jurisdiction.Â  Id.Â  However, in the present case, there is
  no question that Kissiah is an employee and is covered by the Workersâ€™
  Compensation Act.Â  The supreme court addressed the issue of whether the
  determination of an employeeâ€™s knowledge of a change in the ownership of the
  body shop where he worked, thus relieving the original employer of liability,
  involved jurisdiction.Â  Addison v. Dixie Chevrolet Co., 246 S.C.
  86, 142 S.E.2d 442 (1965).Â  The court found: 

	In the case at bar there was no factual issue upon which the
  Commissionâ€™s jurisdiction, in the true sense of the word, depended.Â  It is not
  disputed that the respondent was an employee of Dixie Chevrolet Company and
  protected under its workmenâ€™s compensation coverage at the time when Burn, its
  body shop foreman, took over the shop under the oral agreement before mentioned
  and proceeded to operate it himself, and that respondent's employment in the
  body shop, which had commenced, under Burn more than three years before,
  continued without interruption thereafter.Â  Interpretation of the agreement
  between Dixie Chevrolet Company and Burn is not involved; whether or not
  respondent was a statutory employee is not involved.Â  The seriousness of
  respondentâ€™s injuries was not questioned, nor was the fact that those injuries
  were occasioned by accident arising out of and in the course of his
  employment.Â  The vital, and single, factual issue was whether respondent knew
  of and consented to the new employer-employee relationship resulting from the
  take-over of the body shop by Burn under the oral agreement before mentioned.Â 
  That issue was not jurisdictional; its determination by the Commission, being
  adequately supported by the evidence, was conclusive.Â  

Id. at 91-92, 142 S.E.2d at 444.
We find under Dixie, the present case does not
  involve a jurisdictional issue.Â  Accordingly, this court can reverse or
  modify the Commissionâ€™s decision only if the appellantâ€™s substantial rights
  have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is
  clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence
  on the whole record.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 454, 535
  S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2007).Â 
  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed
  from one side, but such evidence, when the whole record is considered, as would
  allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the Full Commission reached.â€Â  Shealy,
  341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
RPI
  argues the circuit court erred in affirming the Commissionâ€™s decision that it
  was solely liable for Kissiahâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  We disagree.Â  
Section 42-1-130 defines an employee as a â€œperson engaged in an
  employment under any appointment [or] contract of hire, . . . expressed or
  implied, oral or written . . . .â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-130 (Supp. 2007).Â  Although
  no formality is required, the contract of employment is established if the
  parties recognize each other as employer and employee. Â Shuler v. Tri-County
    Elec. Co-op., 374 S.C. 516, 521, 649 S.E.2d 98, 100 (Ct. App. 2007). Â â€œEmployment,
  like any other contract, presupposes understanding. Â The new relation cannot be
  thrust upon the servant without knowledge or consent.â€Â  Chavis v. Watkins,
  256 S.C. 30, 34, 180 S.E.2d 648, 650 (1971) (quoting Holloway v. G. O.
    Cooley & Sons, 208 S.C. 234, 243, 37 S.E.2d 666, 670 (1946)). Â Thus,
  the original employer has been held to be liable to the employee when there had
  been a change in the ownership and the employee had not been put on notice of
  the change of employer.Â  Addison v. Dixie Chevrolet Co., 246 S.C.
  86, 91-92, 142 S.E.2d 442, 444-45 (1965); Holloway, 208 S.C. at 243, 37
  S.E.2d at 671 (1946).Â  The employee is not chargeable with the legal
  consequences of the arrangement between the purchaser and seller of the
  business except as is known and approved by him.Â  Allen v. Phinney Oil Co.,
  241 S.C. 173, 178, 127 S.E.2d 448, 451 (1962).Â  The burden rested upon the employer
  denying liability to show that a change in the identity of his employer was
  made known to employee. Â Chavis, 256 S.C. at 34, 180 S.E.2d at 650.Â  
Kissiah
  testified that on the date of the accident, he had never heard of ESI.Â  When he
  was at the hospital he told hospital personnel that he was an employee of RPI.Â 
  He stated no one at RPI ever told him that he was no longer an employee of RPI.Â 
  Thus, under our precedent, RPI remained liable as Kissiahâ€™s employer for his
  workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  
RPI
  argues the statutes governing the regulation of professional employer
  organizations South Carolina Code Annotated Section 40-68-10 et seq. (Supp.
  2007) support its claim that it is not liable for Kissiahâ€™s claim.Â  It asserts
  that as the terms of a professional employer organization services agreement
  must be in writing,[2] ESI could not impose additional requirements not found in the written agreement
  as prerequisites of the transfer of employment.Â  Thus, ESI could not assert
  Kissiah was not its employee because he had not completed his paperwork or
  submitted his social security card before the accident.Â  
The
  issue of the applicability of these statutes was never raised to or ruled on by
  the Commission.Â  Therefore, it is not
  properly before this court.Â  See Smith v. NCII, Inc., 369 S.C. 236, 256, 631 S.E.2d 268, 279 (Ct. App.
  2006) (â€œOnly issues raised
  and ruled upon by the commission are cognizable on appeal.â€).Â  
Furthermore,
  the terms of the agreement between RPI and ESI are extraneous to our decision.Â 
  As stated above, an employee is not chargeable with the legal consequences of
  the arrangement between employers except as is known and approved by him.Â  Allen
    v. Phinney Oil Co., 241 S.C. at 178, 127 S.E.2d at 451.Â  Kissiah had no
  knowledge of the agreement between RPI and ESI and never agreed to become an
  employee of ESI.Â  We find the Commissionâ€™s decision that Kissiah remained in
  the employ of RPI on the date of the accident is supported by the record.Â 
  Accordingly, we find the circuit court did not err in affirming the
  Commissionâ€™s decision that RPI is liable for Kissiahâ€™s claim.Â  
The
  decision of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ. concur.Â  


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-68-60 (A) (Supp. 2007)
  (requiring terms of a professional organization services agreement to be in a
  written contract).

Appeal From Anderson County
Â Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-294
Submitted June 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 5,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Chief Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III , of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Deputy Director Teresa A. Knox, Tommy Evans, Jr. and J. Benjamin
  Aplin of the South Carolina Dept. of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services, all
  of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant,
  Robert Anthony Hawkins, appeals the partial revocation of his probation,
  asserting there was an insufficient evidentiary basis to establish that he
  violated the conditions of his probation.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
Hawkins
  pled guilty in September 2003 to possession of a stolen vehicle and being a
  habitual traffic offender.Â  He was sentenced to concurrent terms of ten years
  suspended upon service of eighteen months with five years of probation for the
  vehicle charge, and five years suspended upon service of eighteen months with
  five years of probation on the habitual offender charge.Â  A probation arrest
  warrant was issued on September 12, 2006, charging Hawkins with failing to
  follow the advice and instructions of his supervising agent by failing to complete
  intake as instructed, as Hawkins left prior to completion of intake and did not
  return.Â  It further charged Hawkins changed addresses without consent from his
  agent, failed to notify his agent of his whereabouts, thereby absconding from
  supervision, and failed to pay his supervision fees, being $160.00 in arrears
  at that time.Â  
A
  probation revocation hearing was held on October 19, 2006, at which time
  Hawkins informed the court he did not agree with the violations.Â  The probation
  agent stated Hawkins reported for his initial intake after being released on a
  previous revocation, but that he left before completing his initial intake.Â 
  His agent followed up by trying to confirm his residence and whereabouts, but
  was not able to do so.Â  Hawkins maintained that on September 5, 2006, he
  reported, signed in, and sat in the auditorium where he waited from 9:15 until
  1:00.Â  He stated he had a job interview scheduled for 2:00, so he had to
  leave.Â  He stated he had been jailed on this matter since September 25, 2006.Â  
As
  to the alleged arrearage in fees, Hawkins stated that he had â€œonly been out [of
  jail] four daysâ€ from his most recent revocation service, and since the fee was
  $40 a month, he could not already be in arrears in the amount of $160.Â  When
  asked by the court to explain the arrearage figures, the probation agent
  stated, â€œthe only thing I can think is on his revocations, he still had
  arrearages,â€ and that when Hawkins went to jail for the prior revocation,
  â€œthose arrearages followed him.â€Â  Hawkinsâ€™ attorney argued Hawkins was
  previously revoked for having an arrearage, and the State was attempting to
  show a violation for the same arrearage on which he had already had his
  probation revoked.Â  The agent then stated they were not charging him with arrearage,
  but with the fact that Hawkins showed up for his intake but decided to leave
  and had no further contact, and that the agent was thereafter unable to track
  him down at a current residence.Â  
The
  circuit court found Hawkins should not have left the auditorium to go check on
  a job.Â  It then revoked twenty-five days of Hawkinsâ€™ suspended sentences on
  both charges, with credit for time served of twenty-five days.Â  
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
â€œThe
  determination of whether to revoke probation in whole or part rests within the
  sound discretion of the trial court.â€Â  State v. Allen, 370 S.C. 88, 94,
  634 S.E.2d 653, 655 (2006).Â  This court will not reverse the trial courtâ€™s
  decision unless that court abused its discretion.Â  Id.Â Â  

	An abuse
  of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based upon an error of
  law, such as application of the wrong legal principle; or, when based upon
  factual conclusions, the ruling is without evidentiary support; or, when the
  trial court is vested with discretion, but the ruling reveals no discretion was
  exercised; or when the ruling does not fall within the range of permissible
  decisions applicable in a particular case, such that it may be deemed arbitrary
  and capricious.

Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Hawkins asserts the circuit court
  committed reversible error in revoking his probation because the probation
  agent failed to provide a sufficient evidentiary basis to establish he violated
  the conditions of his probation.Â  We disagree.
In deciding whether to revoke probation, â€œ[t]he trial
  court must determine whether the State has presented sufficient evidence to
  establish that a probationer has violated the conditions of his probation.â€Â  Allen,
  370 S.C. at 94, 634 S.E.2d at 655.

	Probation is a matter of grace;
  revocation is the means to enforce the conditions of probation.Â  However, the
  authority of the revoking court should always be predicated upon an evidentiary
  showing of fact tending to establish a violation of the conditions.Â  Thus,
  before revoking probation, the circuit judge must determine if there is
  sufficient evidence to establish that the probationer has violated his
  probation conditions.Â  

State v. Hamilton,
  333 S.C. 642, 648-49, 511 S.E.2d 94, 97 (Ct. App. 1999) (citations omitted). 
Hawkins points to the courtâ€™s observation that
  Hawkinsâ€™ case was â€œtoo complicated,â€ as evidence of a lack of evidentiary
  support that Hawkins violated the terms of his probation.Â  However, a review of
  the record indicates the court was speaking to the confusion over the monetary
  figures discussed regarding possible arrearage stating, â€œWeâ€™ve got to have this
  all checked out,â€ and â€œI want a full audit of his money situation.â€Â  Hawkins
  admitted he failed to stay to complete his initial probation intake.Â  Further,
  he offered no explanation for his failure to notify his agent of an address
  change and his whereabouts. Thus, there is sufficient evidence to establish
  that he violated his probation conditions.
For the foregoing reason, the circuit courtâ€™s ruling
  is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Osborne
          Electric, Inc., Respondent,
        v.
        KCC Contractor,
          Inc., John Q. Hammons Hotels, LP., John Q. Hammons Revocable Trust, City of
          North Charleston, and Metropolitan National Bank, Defendants,
        of whom KCC
          Contractor, Inc. is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-296
  Submitted June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed June 5,
2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Stephen L. Brown, Joseph E. DaPore, Russell G. Hines, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Andrew K. Epting, Jr., of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â KCC
  Contractor Inc. appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming an arbitration
  award.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
KCC was the general contractor for the construction of the All
  Suites Hotel on property leased by John Q. Hammons Revocable Trust from the
  City of North Charleston.Â  Osborne Electric entered into a subcontract
  agreement with KCC to provide the electrical work on the project.Â  After a
  disagreement arose between the parties, Osborne filed a notice and certificate
  of mechanicâ€™s lien stating the value of the labor and materials furnished was
  $253,630.82.Â  It subsequently filed an action to foreclose the mechanicâ€™s
  lien.Â  Osborne also asserted claims for breach of contract and quasi-contract.Â 
  KCC answered and counterclaimed for breach of contract and negligence.Â  The
  matter was sent to arbitration.Â  
The
  arbitrator held Osborne was â€œentitled to $165,406.81 for its contract balances
  including change orders after reduction for the appropriate back charges in
  favor of KCC.â€Â  Finding Osborne the prevailing party, the arbitrator also
  awarded Osborne $22,521.20 in pre-judgment interest and attorneyâ€™s fees and
  costs in the amount of $57,592.93.Â  
KCC
  filed an application for a change of arbitration award alleging an â€œevident
  miscalculation of figures or an evident mistake in the description of any
  person, thing or property referred to in the awardâ€ and/or â€œthe award is
  imperfect in a matter of form not affecting the merits of the controversy.â€Â  It
  asserted that inherent in the arbitratorâ€™s ruling that KCC was entitled to a
  credit for â€œappropriate back chargesâ€ was a finding that Osborne breached the
  subcontract agreement.Â  Thus, KCC claimed, it was entitled to recover
  attorneyâ€™s fees and expenses pursuant to the subcontract agreement.Â  
The
  arbitrator held there was no miscalculation or mistake in the award and that
  KCC was simply rearguing its claim that it was entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees
  based on the contract, which was denied in the arbitration award.Â  The
  arbitrator thus denied the application for a change of arbitration award.Â  
KCC
  filed in circuit court a motion for modification or correction of arbitration
  award while Osborne filed a motion seeking to have the arbitration award
  affirmed.Â  The circuit court affirmed the arbitration award.Â  This appeal
  followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
KCC
  argues the circuit erred by confirming the arbitratorâ€™s award and failing to
  grant KCCâ€™s motion to modify or vacate the award.Â  We disagree.Â  
As a general rule, an arbitration award is conclusive and courts
  will refuse to review the merits of an award.Â  Batten v. Howell, 300
  S.C. 545, 547, 389 S.E.2d 170, 171 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  â€œReview of an arbitration
  award is limited and the decision of the arbitrator will be vacated only under
  certain grounds as provided by statute, or upon the non-statutory ground of
  manifest disregard or perverse misconstruction of the law.â€ Â Lauro v.
    Visnapuu, 351 S.C. 507, 516, 570 S.E.2d 551, 556 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
KCC seeks modification of the arbitration award on the following
  statutory grounds:

  (1) There was an evident miscalculation of figures or an evident
    mistake in the description of any person, thing or property referred to in the
    award;
  . . .
  (3) The award is imperfect in a matter of form, not affecting the
    merits of the controversy.

S.C. Code Ann.Â§
  15-48-140 (a) (2005).Â  
KCC
  argues that under the subcontract agreement, it was entitled to attorneyâ€™s
  fees.Â  The agreement provided KCC could recover attorneyâ€™s fees and expenses
  incurred in the prosecution or defense of any action or suit â€œby reason of any
  other breach or failure by [Osborne].â€Â  KCC asserts the arbitratorâ€™s award of
  back charges in favor of KCC established Osborne breached the subcontract
  agreement by failing to perform its obligations under that agreement.Â  Thus,
  because of the arbitratorâ€™s refusal to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the award
  contains an error in the calculation of the amount owed to Osborne and is
  imperfect in its form.Â  
We find
  this courtâ€™s opinion in Lauro v. Visnapuu instructive for the present
  case.Â  In Lauro the circuit court modified the arbitratorâ€™s award
  finding the arbitratorâ€™s failure to award Lauro the difference between the full
  maximum sum of the contract and the amount Visnapuus paid was a
  â€œmiscalculation.â€Â  Lauro, 351 S.C. at 517, 570 S.E.2d at 556.Â  This
  court noted that the arbitrator had â€œrepeatedly expressed that he had not
  overlooked the matter, but had simply concluded that Lauro was not entitled to
  the difference between the original contract sum and the amount paid, because
  Lauro had not completed the contract.â€Â  Id.
We explained:

  Even if the arbitratorâ€™s decision in this regard were erroneous,
    it does not constitute an evident miscalculation of figures as envisioned under
    Â§ 15-48-140. That is, the arbitrator did not commit a mathematical error in
    computing the total amount of the award. Rather, the arbitrator consciously
    declined to award Lauro the full amount of the contract.

Lauro, 351 S.C. at 517, 570 S.E.2d at 556.
Similarly, in the order denying KCCâ€™s application for a change in
  the arbitration award, the arbitrator emphasized that he had not made a
  miscalculation or mistake in the original arbitration award.Â  He clarified,
  â€œThe credit provided to KCC in the Award was for various items including
  credits agreed to by the parties and work not performed by Osborne after KCCâ€™s material breach of the Agreement.Â  KCCâ€™s failure to pay Osborne is the
  reason that KCC incurred legal fees defending the mechanicâ€™s lien action, not
  because of any breach or failure by Osborne.â€ Â (Emphasis added).Â  
The arbitrator never found Osborne had breached the subcontractor
  agreement or failed to perform its obligations under that agreement other than
  due to KCCâ€™s breach.Â  The arbitratorâ€™s refusal to award attorneyâ€™s fees was not
  a miscalculation of figures as provided in section 15-48-140 (a) (1).Â  Rather
  it was based on his determination that KCC was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees
  under the agreement.Â  Similarly, section 14-48-140 (a) (3) is inapplicable to
  grant KCC the relief it seeks.Â  This section allows modification when the award
  is imperfect in a matter of form, not affecting the merits of the
    controversy. Â (Emphasis added).Â  The arbitratorâ€™s decision that KCC was not
  entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees clearly involves the merits of the controversy.Â  
We find
  the circuit court did not err in affirming the arbitration award.Â  Accordingly,
  the order of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.



[1] We decide this case without oral argument
pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        G. Dana Sinkler
          and Anchorage Plantation Home Owners Association, Respondents,
        v.
        County of Charleston, Charleston County
          Council and Theodora Walpole and John D. Walpole, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-297
Heard May 7, 2008 â€“ Filed June 5, 2008Â Â Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Joseph Dawson, III, Bernard E. Ferrara, Jr., Bernice M. Jenkins,
          and Lonnie Hamilton, III, all of North Charleston, and Gerald M. Finkel of Charleston, for Appellants.
        G. Trenholm Walker and Francis M. Ervin, of Charleston, for
          Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This
  case arises from a zoning ordinance, which rezoned a tomato farm to a planned
  development district.Â  Upon review, the circuit court found the ordinance invalid
  due to perceived conflicts with the Enabling Act and local zoning regulations.Â 
  This court finds no such conflicts and defers to the local governing bodyâ€™s
  judgment regarding this zoning decision.Â  We reverse and reinstate the
  ordinance.
1.Â Theodora and John
  Walpole own the property in question and applied to have the property rezoned
  from AG-15 to PD-96, i.e. from agricultural with some houses to a planned
  development district.Â  Charleston County Council approved the application and
  issued an ordinance rezoning the property as PD-96.
Dana
  Sinkler and Anchorage Plantation Homeowners Association (hereinafter â€œSinklerâ€)
  brought a declaratory judgment action challenging County Councilâ€™s rezoning of
  the property.Â  The circuit court found the ordinance was invalid and the
  property was still zoned AG-15.Â  The circuit court found the submitted plan for
  the property did not meet the Enabling Actâ€™s requirements of mixed use,
  improved property design, and specifically designated open space.Â  As an
  additional sustaining ground, the circuit court found the zoning and land
  development regulations (ZLDR) lacked a process to change AG-15 to planned
  development.Â  Charleston County, the Council, and the Walpoles (collectively
  â€œthe County of Charlestonâ€) appealed the circuit courtâ€™s ruling.
2.Â The circuit court
  found the ordinance violated sections 6-29-720 and 740 of the South Carolina
  Codeâ€™s Enabling Act and, therefore, found the ordinance invalid.Â  We disagree
  because of the deference provided local governing bodies and the flexibility
  created through the Enabling Act.
To provide the
  proper framework, this court first recognizes that a holistic reading of the
  Enabling Act indicates its purpose is to provide the flexibility and ability
  for a local governing authority to make local decisions regarding zoning.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 6-29-720(C) & 740 (Supp. 2007); Dunbar v. City of
    Spartanburg, 266 S.C. 113, 119, 221 S.E.2d 848, 850 (1976) (noting a
  predecessor to the Enabling Act of 1994 was broad in its scope and gave
  municipalities much authority in the field of zoning).Â  The narrow reading of
  the Enabling Act by the circuit court is at direct odds with this intent.
Further,
  the circuit court exceeded the applicable scope of review because a reviewing
  court should practice judicial restraint and not supplant its judgment for the
  local governing authorityâ€™s judgment.Â  Specifically, our supreme court stated:

  The
    governing bodies of municipalities clothed with authority to determine
    residential and industrial districts are better qualified by their knowledge of
    the situation to act upon such matters than are the Courts, and they will not
    be interfered with . . . unless there is plain violation of the constitutional
    rights of citizens.Â  There is a strong presumption in favor of the validity of
    municipal zoning ordinances, and in favor of the validity of their application,
    and where the Planning and Zoning Commission and the city council of a
    municipality has acted after considering all the facts, the Court should not
    disturb the finding unless such action is arbitrary, unreasonable, or in
    obvious abuse of its discretion, or unless it has acted illegally and in excess
    of its lawfully delegated authority.Â  Likewise, the
    power to declare an ordinance invalid because it is so unreasonable as to
    impair or destroy constitutional rights is one which will be exercised
    carefully and cautiously, as it is not the function of the Court to pass upon
    the wisdom or expediency of municipal ordinances or regulations.

Bob Jones Univ., Inc. v.
  City of Greenville, 243 S.C. 351,
  360, 133 S.E.2d 843, 847 (1963) (citation omitted).Â  This court additionally
  held, â€œ[w]e cannot insinuate our judgment into a review of the City Councilâ€™s
  decision, but must leave that decision undisturbed if the propriety of that
  decision is even â€˜fairly debatable.â€™â€Â  Lenardis v. City of Greenville,
  316 S.C. 471, 472, 450 S.E.2d 597, 598 (Ct. App. 1994) (citation omitted).
The circuit court
  specifically found the ordinance violated section 6-29-720 of the Enabling Act because
  the ordinance failed to meet the provided definition.Â  Section 6-29-720(C)(4)
  defines a planned development district as:

  [A] development project comprised of housing of different types
    and densities and of compatible commercial uses, or shopping centers, office
    parks, and mixed-use developments.Â  A planned development district is
    established by rezoning prior to development and is characterized by a unified
    site design for a mixed use development.

First, we note the
  prefatory language before the definitions of possible planning techniques,
  including the above definition for a planned development district, states, â€œ[t]he zoning ordinance may utilize the following or any other zoning
  and planning techniques for implementation of the goals specified above. Â Failure
    to specify a particular technique does not cause use of that technique to be
    viewed as beyond the power of the local government choosing to use it.â€Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-720(C) (emphasis added).
At oral argument,
  Sinkler argued the County Council did not avail itself of this curative
  language because the County Council utilized one of the definitions.Â  This
  court need not explore Sinklerâ€™s argument as this court defers to the County
  Councilâ€™s judgment regarding the plan.Â  In the ordinance, the County Council
  found that the plan met Article 3.5 of the ZLDR by:

  Providing
    a greater choice in the type of environment and living units available to the
    public through lot size ranges (minimum of one acre);
  Providing
    more open space land use by 224 acres of common open space land use and an
    additional 345 acres of open space land use on residential lots totaling 569
    acres of the tractâ€™s 747 acres;
  Providing
    a creative approach to the use of land by limiting the total number of
    residential lots to 107, limiting the uses in these areas from that which would
    be allowed in the AG-15 Zoning District, and incorporating existing water
    features into the common open space areas providing for greater wildlife
    habitat area and protecting water quality; and by Providing (sic) an efficient
    use of the land that results in a smaller network of utilities and streets and
    a variety of lot sizes.

Notably, Article 3.5.1 of the
  ZLDR incorporates the definition of planned development district in the
  Enabling Act.Â  Article 3.5.2 provides the intent for planned development
  districts, which is consistent with section 6-29-740.
Therefore, County
  Councilâ€™s above findings square with the planned development district
  definition provided in section 6-29-720(C)(4).Â  Further, these findings address
  the remaining reasons the circuit court found the ordinance conflicted with the
  Enabling Act: the ordinanceâ€™s believed failure to improve design and character
  of the community under section 6-29-740, lack of mixed use and open space, and
  deficient specificity.Â  Thus, we are convinced the planned development district
  satisfies the threshold statutory requirements provided under section 6-29-720
  and 740.
Next,
  we turn to whether County Councilâ€™s decision was arbitrary or capricious, as
  required by the applicable scope of review.Â  See Bear Enters. v. County of Greenville, 319 S.C. 137, 141-42, 459 S.E.2d 883, 886 (Ct. App. 1995)
  (stating the reviewing court will focus on whether the municipal zoning
  authorityâ€™s decision was arbitrary or capricious).Â  County Council reviewed the
  plan for the property multiple times and the county staff recommended rezoning
  the property.Â  Accordingly, County Councilâ€™s decision was neither arbitrary nor
  capricious.
3. As an additional
  ground for declaring the ordinance invalid, the circuit court held that County
  Council did not intend for a property owner to reduce the residential standards
  of property zoned AG-15 through a planned development district process.Â  We
  disagree.
In a case recently
  decided by this Court, owners of property adjacent to rezoned land challenged
  the rezoning ordinance, arguing it conflicted with the local ZLDR.Â  Mikell
    v. County of Charleston, 375 S.C. 552, 654 S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 2007), petition
      for cert. filed (S.C. January 24, 2008).Â  Sinkler acknowledges the uphill
  battle in attempting to distinguish our decision in Mikell.Â  We
  appreciate able counselâ€™s effort to distinguish Mikell, but we find the
  precedent controlling.
In Mikell,
  the master-in-equity found ZLDR restricted County Councilâ€™s authority to rezone
  the property from AG-10 to PD and remanded the ordinance to County Council.Â  Id. at 556-57, 654 S.E.2d at 95.Â  On appeal, this court found the ZLDR supported County Councilâ€™s decision to rezone the property, and we reversed the masterâ€™s
  ruling and reinstated the ordinance.Â  Id. at 560, 654 S.E.2d at 96.Â  This
  court specifically held ZLDR Article 2.1.2 and section 6-29-740 provide â€œCounty
  Council with final decision-making authority in rezoning actions pursuant to a planned
  development [PD] application,â€ and Article 3.5.7 â€œprovides for deviations from
  other zoning designations.â€Â  Id. at 560, 654 S.E.2d at 96-97.Â  As noted
  in Mikell, â€œthere is nothing to suggest that County Council cannot
  change an ordinance that it created.â€Â  Id. at 561, 654 S.E.2d at 97.
In
  the case at hand, the circuit court interpreted the ZLDR as barring the use of
  a planned development district to alter AG-15 zoning standards.Â  The circuit
  court noted that the regulations for AG-8 and AG-10 provide a process to achieve
  the highest allowed density rate, which is to make a request through the planned
  development process.Â  No such process is mentioned for AG-15 and AG-25 areas.Â  Therefore,
  the circuit court concluded that the absence of a planned development process for
  AG-15 barred such an action.Â  However, the plain meaning of the statutory
  language does not indicate the home density cannot be increased given the
  discussed power of County Council.Â  Accordingly, there is no conflict between
  the ordinance and the ZLDR.
4. Sinklerâ€™s challenge
  to County Councilâ€™s legal authority fails to show the enacted ordinance conflicted
  with state law or ZLDR; County Councilâ€™s decision was arbitrary and
  unreasonable; or rezoning violated Sinklerâ€™s constitutional rights.Â  We decline
  to substitute our judgment for that of County Council, and we hold the circuit
  court erred in concluding County Council exceeded its lawfully delegated
  authority.Â  Due to this finding, we need not address the County of Charlestonâ€™s remaining arguments.Â  Accordingly, we reinstate the ordinance rezoning the Walpolesâ€™ property as PD-96 and the order of the circuit court is
REVERSED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				William S.
      Catchings, Jr., Respondent,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Motor Vehicles, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-299
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 9, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				General Counsel Frank L. Valenta, Jr. and Deputy Chief Counsel
  Philip S. Porter, of Blythewood, for Appellant.
				Daniell S. Landers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  This is a judicial review of an administrative action.Â  The circuit judge,
  after hearing the matter without a jury, issued an order rescinding the
  suspension of the driverâ€™s license of Respondent William S. Catchings, Jr.,
  directing the South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles to refund to
  Catchings a $200.00 license reinstatement fee, and assessing attorneyâ€™s fees of
  $5,065.00 against the Department.Â  Following the denial of its post-trial
  motions, the Department filed this appeal.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On February 24,
  2005, Catchingsâ€™s wife requested the familyâ€™s insurance company to drop
  coverage on a 1987 Ford Bronco.Â  The insurance policy itself, however, remained
  in effect, and the Catchings continued to pay the premiums on their other
  vehicles.
On March 24, 2005,
  the Department, having been notified of the lapse in insurance coverage on the
  Bronco, sent Catchings an FR4 Notice.Â  In the body of the notice, the
  Department advised Catchings that it had received notice of cancellation of
  insurance on the vehicle and that he should provide proof of liability
  insurance coverage or surrender the tag and registration on the vehicle.Â  The
  notice further stated, â€œFailure to comply with this notice before the
  suspension date will result in the suspension of your vehicle registration and/or driverâ€™s license.â€Â  (Emphases added.) Â In the top right hand corner of the
  letter appeared the notation â€œDate of Suspension:04/21/2005â€ and references to two
  sections of the South Carolina Code.
Catchings
  surrendered his registration and tag at a Department branch office on April 21,
  2005.Â  The Department customer service representative who waited on him
  accepted these items without incident, and Catchings was not told that he owed
  the Department any money or that his license had been or would be suspended.
On July 29, 2005,
  while driving on I-20 in Augusta, Georgia, Catchings was stopped for speeding.Â 
  When the apprehending officer ran a license and registration check, Catchings
  was handcuffed in front of his wife, arrested, and taken to jail for driving on
  a suspended license.Â  Catchings had to sit in jail until his wife located a
  bail bondsman in the middle of the night to bond him out.Â  The arrest was the
  first notice Catchings received of any unresolved issues regarding his driverâ€™s
  license.
The week after he
  was arrested and jailed, Catchings received a letter from the Department dated
  August 1, 2005, advising that his â€œregistration and/or driving privilege in
  this state will not be suspendedâ€ but also that he had to pay a penalty of
  $200.00.Â  Also, on August 8, 2005, Catchingsâ€™s wife checked the Department
  website to determine the status of Catchingsâ€™s license and found it was listed
  as â€œsuspendedâ€ as of that date. Â Although Catchings retained counsel to attempt
  to resolve the matter, he eventually paid the penalty because his job involved
  driving a company van.
A few days later, Catchings received another letter from the Department.Â  Although this letter
  was dated August 9, 2005, it was essentially a duplicate of the letter dated
  August 1, 2005.Â  In addition, although Catchings never requested reinstatement
  of the registration on the Bronco, the Department sent Catchings a second
  letter, also dated August 9, 2005, indicating this relief had been granted.Â 
  According to yet a third letter from the Department dated August 9, 2005, the
  suspension was cleared as of that date.
Catchingsâ€™s
  attorney wrote to the Department on August 23, 2005, in an effort to have the
  suspension voided.Â  In the letter, counsel pointed out that Catchings was never
  an uninsured driver, had never driven an uninsured vehicle, and did not receive
  notice from the Department that his driverâ€™s license had been suspended or
  definitely would be suspended.Â  The letter also contained a request for
  reconsideration of the Departmentâ€™s actions and an evidentiary hearing under
  the Administrative Procedures Act. Â In the letter, counsel for Catchings
  expressed a desire to resolve the matter amicably and suggested his client
  would be willing to waive or release any claims for damages and attorneyâ€™s fees
  if the suspension could be voided or rescinded and the charges for driving
  under suspension were resolved.[2]Â 
  The record does not indicate that the Department granted any of the requests or
  otherwise responded to the letter.Â  
On August 26, 2005, Catchings filed a petition for judicial review in the Court of Common Pleas for
  Richland County, the county of his residence.Â  In the petition, Catchings
  sought judicial review of an administrative action pursuant to South Carolina
  Code sections 1-23-380(A) and 56-1-410.Â  The Department filed an answer on
  October 24, 2005, essentially denying the allegations in the petition.
The matter was
  placed on the Richland County Common Pleas Non-Jury Docket for the term of
  court beginning July 31, 2006.Â  At the roster meeting on July 31, 2006, Catchingsâ€™s attorney was present, but no one appeared on behalf of the
  Department. Â The case was placed on â€œstandbyâ€ status for that week pending a
  scheduling opportunity, and counsel for Catchings faxed the attorney of record
  for the Department a letter advising of this development.Â  In the same letter,
  counsel further advised that he requested a hearing on August 28, 2006, in case
  the matter could not be heard the week of the roster meeting.Â  On August 1,
  2006, a paralegal for the Department faxed a letter to the Chief Administrative
  Judge for the Fifth Judicial Circuit requesting on behalf of the attorney
  assigned to the case protection on August 1 and August 2, 2006, because of
  hearings scheduled in other locations on those days.
The
  court set the matter for a non-jury hearing to be held at 9:30 a.m. on August
  3, 2006, and on August 1, 2006, attempted to advise counsel for the Department by
  telephone of the upcoming trial.Â  Through miscommunication and oversight,
  however, counsel for the Department did not appear when the case was called.Â 
  After an unsuccessful attempt to reach counsel by telephone and a delay of
  about thirty minutes, the trial proceeded without the Departmentâ€™s participation.
After the trial, Catchingsâ€™s attorney prepared a
  proposed order, which he mailed to the presiding judge on August 7, 2006, and a
  copy of which was also mailed to counsel for the Department.Â  The trial judge
  signed the order on August 14, 2006, and the clerk of court filed it on August
  21, 2006.Â  The Department received the final
  order on August 23, 2006.
Nothing
  more was heard from the Department until September 5, 2006, when it filed a
  motion for rehearing or, in the alternative, relief from the judgment under Rules 59 and 60(b) of the South
  Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â 
  Catchings sent a response to the motion with a memorandum of law and an
  affidavit of counsel dated September 12, 2006.Â  By order dated December 11,
  2006, and filed December 13, 2006, the trial judge denied the motion, and the
  Department filed this appeal.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Regarding the
  Departmentâ€™s appeal of the trial judgeâ€™s decision to proceed with the hearing
  in its absence and denial of its motion for rehearing or relief from judgment,
  the South Carolina Supreme Court has stated, â€œWhether to grant or deny a motion
  under Rule 60(b) lies within the sound discretion of the judge.â€Â  BB&T
    v. Taylor, 369 S.C. 548, 551, 633 S.E.2d 501, 502 (2006).Â  
As
  to the merits of the appealed order, we agree with the trial judge that the
  appropriate standard of review of a driverâ€™s license suspension is set forth in
  South Carolina Code section 1-23-380(A)(5), which allows the circuit court to
  reverse the suspension if it (1) violated constitutional and statutory
  provisions; (2) exceeded the Departmentâ€™s statutory authority; (3) was made
  upon unlawful procedure; (4) was clearly erroneous in view of the record as a
  whole; or (5) was arbitrary and capricious, characterized by abuse of
  discretion or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2007).Â  In addition, in a judicial review of a driverâ€™s
  license suspension, â€œthe burden of proof in any such hearing shall be on the
  department.â€Â  Id. Â§ 56-1-410 (2006).[3]
Catchings was
  awarded attorneyâ€™s fees under South Carolina Code section 15-77-300, which,
  under certain conditions, allows a court to award attorneyâ€™s fees in a civil
  lawsuit to â€œany party who is contesting state action.â€Â  Id. Â§ 15-77-300
  (2005).Â  Review of an award of attorneyâ€™s fees pursuant to this section is
  subject to an abuse of discretion standard.Â  Heath v. County of Aiken, 302 S.C. 178, 182, 394 S.E.2d 709, 711 (1990).
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  We first address the
  Departmentâ€™s argument that the trial judge acted improperly in hearing and
  deciding the case in the absence of the Departmentâ€™s counsel.Â  We find no abuse
  of discretion upon which to base a finding of reversible error.
In its memorandum
  of law in support of its motion for a rehearing of the case, the only argument
  the Department made regarding the trial judgeâ€™s decision to hear the case in
  its absence was that it was not provided appropriate notice of the hearing.Â 
  The facts related in support of that argument, however, evidence only internal
  communication problems within the Department itself, rather than the failure of
  the court to provide adequate notice.Â  A court employee telephoned the contact
  number listed on the pleadings filed by the Department to inform the
  Departmentâ€™s attorney that the hearing was scheduled and was directed by a
  Department employee to that attorneyâ€™s cell phone number, which, apparently
  unbeknownst to the Department employee, was the number for the attorneyâ€™s
  family cell phone, which he had not carried for several months after being
  issued a cell phone by the Department.Â  Moreover, the Department employee did
  not inquire about the specifics of the court employeeâ€™s telephone call and
  never informed the attorney that the court had attempted to reach him.Â  When
  the attorney did not appear at the hearing, the clerk of court attempted to
  reach him at the same family cell phone number provided earlier by the
  Department.Â  Even if the court could have communicated with the Departmentâ€™s
  attorney by another means, this does not excuse the Departmentâ€™s failure to
  â€œmonitor the progress of [its] case.â€Â  Goodson v. Am. Bankers Ins. Co. of Fla., 295 S.C. 400, 403, 368 S.E.2d 687, 689) (Ct. App. 1988).Â  
We agree with the
  Department that South Carolina policy favors â€œthe disposition of issues on
  their merits rather than on technicalities.â€Â  Mictronics, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t
    of Revenue, 345 S.C. 506, 511, 548 S.E.2d 223, 226 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  We
  also agree that dismissal of a case is a harsh sanction that is generally
  resorted to â€œonly in the face of a clear record of delay or contumacious
  conduct by the plaintiff.â€Â  McComas v. Ross, 368 S.C. 59, 63, 626 S.E.2d
  902, 904 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  The outcome of the present case, however, was not a
  dismissal or a default judgment, but rather a decision based on the evidence
  and pleadings, including those filed by the Department.Â  Contrary, then, to the
  Departmentâ€™s suggestion that the trial judge decided against it on a
  â€œtechnicalâ€ ground, the case was decided on the merits after a hearing at
  which, because of mishaps for which only the Department can be held responsible,
  its attorney failed to appear.
2.Â  We further disagree with
  the Departmentâ€™s argument that the trial judge abused his discretion in
  refusing to grant its motion for rehearing or relief from judgment.Â  This
  argument, as presented in the Departmentâ€™s brief on appeal, concerns only the
  application of Rule 60(b), SCRCP, to the present case.
As noted by the
  Department, this Court, in Mictronics, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Revenue, reviewed
  a dismissal of an appeal with prejudice by an administrative law judge after
  the appellant, because of a misunderstanding about the date of the hearing,
  failed to appear at the appointed time.Â  Holding among other things that the
  appellant acted promptly once becoming aware of the mistake, this Court
  reversed the administrative law judgeâ€™s denial of the appellantâ€™s motion to
  reopen the case.Â  Mictronics, 345 S.C. at 511, 548 S.E.2d at 226.Â  
Unlike
  the appellant in Mictronics, the Department did not act diligently under
  the circumstances.Â  At no time did the Department inquire about the hearing,
  even after Catchingsâ€™s attorney sent a proposed order.Â  Furthermore,
  Catchingsâ€™s attorney had advised counsel for the Department that he requested
  to have the matter set for August 28, 2006, if it was not reached the week of
  the roster meeting; however, there is nothing in the record suggesting the
  Department made a prompt attempt to verify if the hearing could take place on
  that later date.Â  Finally, even though the Departmentâ€™s post-trial motion was
  sufficiently timely to be considered by the trial judge, we simply do not
  accept the Departmentâ€™s assertion that the filing of its motion â€œwithin ten
  days of receiving notice of the Order is further evidence of its prompt
  response to its mistakes.â€
3.Â  Regarding the merits of
  the case, the Department cites numerous statutes to support its position that
  suspension of Catchingsâ€™s driverâ€™s license was lawful and suggests that
  Catchings was at least partly responsible for the problems resulting from his
  suspension because he failed to present the suspension notice to the customer
  service representative who waited on him or alert that employee to the issues
  of fines or reinstatement fees.Â  Neither argument was raised to the trial judge
  at the hearing; moreover, the various statutes the Department cited in its
  brief on this issue were not referenced in its answer.Â  We therefore hold these
  arguments were not preserved for appeal and do not address them.Â  See Wilder
    Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the
  first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial
  judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€); Hickman v. Hickman,
  301 S.C. 455, 456, 392 S.E.2d 481, 482 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œA party cannot use
  Rule 59(e) to present to the court an issue the party could have raised prior
  to judgment but did not.â€).
4.Â  Finally, the Department challenges
  the award of attorneyâ€™s fees, arguing (1) Catchings is not entitled to attorneyâ€™s
  fees even if he remains the prevailing party after this appeal; and (2) the
  fees were not reasonable.Â  We decline to disturb the attorneyâ€™s fee award.Â  
Catchingsâ€™s
  attorney presented his fee affidavit at trial, and it was incumbent on the
  Department to present its objections to the affidavit at that time. Â See Taylor v. Medenica, 324 S.C. 200, 212, 479 S.E.2d 35, 41 (1996)
  (holding a party could not raise an issue on appeal because it failed to make
  an appropriate objection at trial).Â  Furthermore, although the Department moved
  for rehearing and relief from the judgment, it raised only the issue of whether
  the court had provided appropriate notice of the hearing.Â  Because the trial
  judge was never presented with any objections from the Department concerning
  the award of attorneyâ€™s fees, we hold any arguments concerning this issue were
  not preserved for appellate review.
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS,
  THOMAS, and PIEPER, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Although Catchings paid a fine for speeding, the
  charges for driving under suspension were nol prossed after counsel sent the
  letter.
[3]Â  We are aware that the South Carolina General
  Assembly repealed this section in 2006. Â 2006 S.C. Acts 381 Â§ 11, at 2935.Â  The
  repeal, however, was accompanied by a savings clause, which provided as
  follows:

	After
  the effective date of this act, all laws repealed or amended by this act must
  be taken and treated as remaining in full force and effect for the purpose of sustaining
  any pending or vested right, civil action, special proceeding, criminal
  prosecution, or appeal existing as of the effective date of this act, and for
  the enforcement of rights, duties, penalties, forfeitures, and liabilities as
  they stood under the repealed or amended laws.

Id. Â§ 13, at 2938.
