  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Steve Layne and
          Jody Layne, Appellants,
        v.
        Gateway
          Construction Company, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-304
  Submitted June 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 11,
2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Brian Pratt Robinson, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Claude E. Hardin, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In
  this breach of contract action, Steve Layne and Jody Layne (the Laynes) appeal
  the trial courtâ€™s partial denial of their motion for a new trial nisi remittitur.Â 
  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The
  Laynes hired Gateway Construction Company, Inc., to build a new house pursuant
  to a written contract. Â After Gateway began construction, the Laynes requested
  that Gateway work outside of the contract and amend the construction schedule so
  the Laynes could obtain a particular interest rate. Â The Laynes requested a
  lien release from Gateway as required for the closing. Â Gateway issued a
  conditional lien release stating $50,711.00 remained due on the project through
  July 25, 2003. Â After the closing, the Laynes failed to pay as set forth
  in the conditional lien release. Â Gateway, therefore, ceased construction on
  the project. Â The Laynes subsequently brought this action against Gateway for
  breach of contract, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act,
  negligence, breach of warranty, and violation of the South Carolina Unfair
  Trade Practices Act. Â Gateway answered and counterclaimed, alleging breach of
  contract. 
At
  trial, Andrew Guliano, Gatewayâ€™s president, testified Gatewayâ€™s damages totaled
  $108,380, including the contract balance of $50,711, $21,073.50 in other
  damages, and $36,595.50 in interest.Â  Gateway reduced the total by $9,000 in
  retainage fees. Â The jury returned a verdict in favor of Gateway in the
  amount of $99,380. Â The Laynes moved for a new trial nisi remittitur,
  arguing the jury awarded compound interest and the verdict included a double
  recovery of damages.Â  The trial court granted the Laynesâ€™ motion as to the
  issue of compound interest and reduced the damages to $92,933.99.Â  The Laynes
  again moved to alter or amend the judgment because the trial courtâ€™s order did
  not address the double recovery of damages issue, and the trial court denied
  the motion.Â  The Laynes appeal.Â  Â 
LAW / ANALYSIS
The
  Laynes argue the trial court erred in denying their motion for a new trial nisi remittitur to the extent that the damages included a double recovery.Â 
  Specifically, the Laynes argue the $21,073.50 Gateway claimed as â€œother
  damagesâ€ was also included in the contract balance of $50,711.00. Â 
In a breach of contract action, the measure of damages is the loss actually suffered as the result of
  the breach.Â  Collins Holding Corp. v. Landrum, 360 S.C. 346, 350, 601
  S.E.2d 332, 333 (2004).Â  The amount of damages remains largely within the
  discretion of the finder of fact, as reviewed by the trial judge.Â  Mishoe v.
    QHG of Lake City, Inc., 366 S.C. 195, 201, 621 S.E.2d 363,
  366 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  A motion for new trial nisi remittitur asks the trial court to reduce the verdict because the verdict is merely excessive.
  Â See Oâ€™Neal v. Bowles, 314 S.C. 525, 527, 431 S.E.2d 555,
  556 (1993). Â The denial of a motion for a new trial nisi is within the trial courtâ€™s discretion and
  will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion. Â Id.Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of the trial court either
  lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of law. State v.
    McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 325, 540 S.E.2d 464, 467 (2000).

Here, evidence
  supports the trial courtâ€™s partial denial of the Layneâ€™s motion for a remittitur.Â 
  The damages awarded by the jury were within the range of evidence presented at
  trial.Â  Guliano stated he
  used Gatewayâ€™s general ledger to calculate the total cost and damages
  attributed to the project.Â  Â He testified Gatewayâ€™s damages totaled $99,380. Â In
  addition, Gateway introduced an exhibit demonstrating that costs, labor, and
  interest totaled $99,380.Â  
AFFIRMED.
SHORT and
KONDUROS, JJ., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.


[1] We decide this
case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-306
  Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 11,
2008

        H. Jeff McLeod,
          of Anderson; for Appellant.
        Carroll H. Roe,
          Jr., of Greenville; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Entec Polymers, LLC (Entec) appeals from the trial courtâ€™s discovery order
  granting Stabl Corp., Inc.â€™s (Stabl) motion to quash subpoenas.Â  We dismiss the
  appeal.[1]
FACTS
This is a post-judgment collection
  action.Â  Entec filed an action against Stabl and won a judgment on May 2, 2006
  for $96,087.71. (R.8)Â  Entec moved for a supplemental hearing and provided
  affidavits that Stabl has assets to satisfy the judgment. (App.br.2)Â  Seven
  Products Plus, Inc. is the successor to Stabl and Bruce McClure is the
  â€œowner/contact personâ€ for both corporations. (R.123)Â  Entec learned just prior
  to the supplemental hearing that Stabl pledged its receivables to Peoples Bank
  for $1.8 million. (R.21, 47, 48)Â  Within a day or two of the supplemental
  hearing, Entec subpoenaed records from Peoples Bank and Seven Products. (R.30,
  Resp.br.3)Â  
Stabl
  moved to quash the subpoenas. (R.30-32)Â  After a hearing, the court granted the
  motion, stating in part:Â  â€œThe testimony of Mr. McClure and the records
  furnished at the hearing are devoid of any direct or circumstantial evidence
  that establishes Seven Products was responsible whatsoever for any of the open
  account invoices upon which [Entec] obtained judgment against Stabl or that [Stabl]
  has engaged in any fraudulent transfer of assets.â€ (R.3)Â  Entec appeals. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Initially,
  Stabl argues the order on appeal is an interlocutory order, not immediately
  appealable.Â  Entec argues the order makes a final determination of the merits
  of the case, thus making the order appealable under South Carolina Code section
  14-3-330.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330 (1977 & Supp. 2007) (restricting
  appellate review of interlocutory orders).Â  We find the order does not make
  findings on the merits.Â  Furthermore, Stabl concedes in its brief that Entec is
  not prejudiced by the order beyond â€œthe small discovery limitationsâ€ imposed by
  the trial court. (Resp.br.10)Â  We conclude the order is not immediately
  appealable.Â  See Ex parte Wilson, 367 S.C. 7, 625 S.E.2d 205
  (2005) (finding an order granting a motion to quash a subpoena duces tecum,
  issued to a nonparty, is not immediately appealable).Â  
Accordingly, the
  order on appeal is
DISMISSED.
 HEARN, C.J.,
SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral
argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ex Parte: State
      Budget and Control Board, Employee Insurance Program, Appellant,
				In Re:
				Doris B.
      Sheffield, Respondent,
				v.
				The State of South Carolina, Defendant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Hampton County
Â Carmen T. Mullen, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-310
Submitted June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed June 18,
  2008
REVERSED


	
		
			
				James T. Hedgepath, of Greenville; and Michael T. Brittingham and Roshella
  James, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Lee Deer Cope, of Hampton, for Respondent.
			
		
	

GOOLSBY, A.J.: Â The State Budget and Control Board Employee Insurance Program (the Insurance
  Program) appeals the trial courtâ€™s award of long-term disability benefits to
  Doris B. Sheffield.Â  We reverse. [1] 
FACTS
Sheffield taught special education in Hampton County School
  District 1 (the District). Â In 2004, Sheffield filed a claim for long-term
  disability benefits, alleging she was unable to work because she suffered
  rheumatoid arthritis and SjÃ¶grenâ€™s syndrome.[2] 
Sheffieldâ€™s
  claim was initially reviewed by Standard Insurance Company (Standard), the
  third-party claims administrator for her long term disability plan. Â Standard
  denied the claim, and Sheffield requested a review. Again, Standard denied the
  claim. Â In addition, Standardâ€™s Quality Assurance Unit denied the claim
  after conducting an independent review. Â Sheffield next appealed to the
  Employee Insurance Programâ€™s Long-Term Disability Appeals Committee (Appeals
  Committee).Â  The Appeals Committee reviewed Sheffieldâ€™s Long-Term Disability
  Income Benefit Plan (the Plan), Sheffieldâ€™s medical records, and all other
  documents contained in the administrative record. 
According to the Plan, employees are disabled if a physical
  disease, injury, pregnancy, or mental disorder renders them â€œunable to perform
  with reasonable continuity the Material Duties of [their] Own Occupation.â€Â  The
  Plan further provides, â€œOwn Occupation means any employment, business, trade,
  profession, calling or vocation that involves Material Duties of the same
  general character as [the employeeâ€™s] regular and ordinary employment with the
  Employer. . . .â€ 
The job description for a â€œClassroom Teacherâ€ in District 1
  contains the following duties:

	
		
			1. 
			Instruct students for specified time and in 
			specified subjects as outlined in the teacherâ€™s contract, the 
			Defined Minimum Program and according to the districtâ€™s and the 
			schoolâ€™s policies.
 
		
		
			2.  
			Supervise students in classroom, in halls, in 
			lunchroom, on playgrounds and in boarding buses and extra-curricular 
			activities.
		
	

Karol Paquette,
  Sheffieldâ€™s vocational case manager, classified Sheffieldâ€™s occupation as
  â€œTeacher, Mentally Impaired.â€Â  Paquette added Sheffieldâ€™s position included
  light physical demands.Â  
The Appeals Committee also reviewed Sheffieldâ€™s medical records.Â  The records included documents from Dr. Welcker, Sheffieldâ€™s
  family physician, and Dr. Nussbaum, Sheffieldâ€™s rheumatologist. Â In
  addition, the Appeals Committee considered the opinions of Dr. Ingram and Dr. Fraback,
  rheumatologists hired by Standard to review Sheffieldâ€™s medical records and
  provide opinions as to her condition. Â Although Sheffield also sought treatment
  with an ear, nose, and throat specialist (ENT), she failed to submit ENT medical
  records to Standard or the Appeals Committee.Â  The Appeals Committee,
  therefore, did not review these medical records, and Dr. Ingram and Dr. Fraback
  were unaware of any diagnosis or treatment by the ENT.Â  Â Â 
Dr.
  Welker, who initially diagnosed Sheffield with rheumatoid arthritis and SjÃ¶grenâ€™s syndrome, opined Sheffield was unable to work due to the
  physical limitations resulting from her conditions. Â He added Sheffield was unable to walk, sit, or stand for any period of time. Â He also noted Sheffield suffered from garbled speech that could prevent public speaking.Â  Dr. Nussbaum noted
  Sheffield suffered joint swelling, stiffness and pain, dry mouth due to
  salivary gland failure, and low back pain.Â  He described Sheffieldâ€™s condition
  as a â€œchronic illness which is unlikely to improve.â€Â  Dr. Nussbaum, however,
  opined by letter dated August 13, 2004, that Sheffield had difficulty with
  prolonged standing and walking, but was otherwise able to work without
  difficulty.Â  Dr. Nussbaum later opined Sheffield could walk or stand for up to
  one hour at a time and Sheffield could walk or stand for four hours during an
  eight hour work day.Â  Dr. Nussbaum added Sheffield could sit for up to two
  hours at a time and she could sit for up to six hours during the work day.Â  Ultimately,
  Dr. Nussbaum concluded Sheffield was not physically able to return to work.Â  
Dr. Ingram and Dr. Fraback opined Sheffieldâ€™s conditions did not preclude her from returning to her occupation. Â Dr.
  Ingram found Sheffieldâ€™s medical records â€œdo not show significant rheumatoid
  arthritis, such that her rheumatologist does not recommend that she begin a
  second-line agent, which is recommended in all but the most minimal rheumatoid
  arthritis.â€Â  Â Â Dr. Fraback agreed, finding her rheumatoid arthritis
  appeared to be mild to moderate.Â  With respect to Sheffieldâ€™s SjÃ¶grenâ€™s syndrome, Dr. Ingram commented as follows:

	The dry oral mucosa is documented, as well as at least two years
  of treatment with agents to increase salivary production.Â  There is no mention
  that she has been advised to use oral wetting agents, the typical
  recommendations of sucking lemon drops or frequent sips of water.Â  Furthermore,
  in the classroom, amplification and microphones are easily available to
  teachers and there is no indication she has requested that modification . . .
  .Â  

Dr. Fraback
  noted, â€œWhile she does have SjÃ¶grenâ€™s syndrome, the most recent note from
  the rheumatologist indicated that [her condition] was somewhat better with a
  new drug Evaxac . . . .â€Â  Dr. Fraback added â€œIt would be unusual for SjÃ¶grenâ€™s syndrome to preclude speaking if the speaker had the
  ability to sip water as needed.â€Â  
The Appeals Committee unanimously denied
  Sheffieldâ€™s claim, finding the administrative record did not indicate Sheffield was unable to perform the duties of her occupation as a teacher for the mentally
  impaired.Â  The Appeals Committee relied on Dr. Nussbaumâ€™s letter of August 13,
  2004 that stated Sheffield had difficulty with prolonged standing and walking,
  but was otherwise able to continue her employment.Â  The Appeals Committee
  further noted Dr. Nussbaumâ€™s opinion that Sheffield could walk or stand for
  four hours and sit for six hours. Â They added Standardâ€™s rheumatologist
  consultants agreed Sheffieldâ€™s claim file did not indicate Sheffield was
  physically unable to perform her Own Occupation. Â 
Sheffield appealed this decision to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court reversed the
  Appeals Committeeâ€™s decision.Â  This appeal followed.Â  

LAW / ANALYSIS
The Insurance Program argues the circuit
  court erred in finding the Appeals Committeeâ€™s denial of Sheffieldâ€™s claim was
  not supported by substantial evidence.Â  We agree.
Section
  1-11-710(C) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) provides:

	[C]laims for benefits under any self-insured plan of insurance offered by 
	the State to state and public school district employees and other
  eligible individuals must be resolved by procedures established by the [South
  Carolina Budget and Control Board], which shall constitute the exclusive remedy
  for these claims, subject only to appellate judicial review consistent with the
  standards provided in Section 1-23-380.

Â Pursuant to section
  1-23-380(A)(5) of the South Carolina Code (Supp 2007), an appellate court, when
  reviewing the final decision of an agency, â€œmay not substitute its judgment for
  the judgment of the agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions of
  fact.â€Â  Rather, the decision of the agency should be affirmed unless it is
  clearly erroneous in light of the substantial evidence on the record, is
  arbitrary or capricious, or is affected by other error of law. Id.; see Wilson v. State Budget & Contol Bd. Employee Ins. Program, 374 S.C.
  300, 648 S.E.2d 310 (Ct. App. 2007) (affirming the agencyâ€™s denial of benefits
  and reversing the circuit courtâ€™s award of benefits when the employee submitted
  evidence supporting her disability claim, but substantial evidence to the
  contrary supported the agencyâ€™s decision).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere
  scintilla of evidence, but evidence which, considering the record as a whole,
  would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the agency reached.â€Â  Tiller
    v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr, 334 S.C. 333, 338, 513 S.E.2d 843, 845 (1999). Â 
Here, Sheffield submitted evidence of her disability. Substantial evidence to the contrary,
  however, supports the decision of the Appeals Committee.Â  As set forth above, Dr.
  Nussbaum stated Sheffield could walk or stand for four hours and sit for six
  hours. Â In addition, Dr. Ingram and Dr. Fraback concluded Sheffieldâ€™s
  conditions did not preclude her from returning to work.Â  Specifically, Dr.
  Ingram and Dr. Fraback agreed Sheffieldâ€™s rheumatoid arthritis was mild to
  moderate and her dry mouth condition was treatable. Â Because substantial
  evidence supports the Appeals Committeeâ€™s decision, the circuit courtâ€™s award
  of benefits is Â Â 
REVERSED. 
KONDUROS, J., concurs.
SHORT, J., dissents
  in a separate opinion.
SHORT,
  J., (dissenting):Â  I respectfully dissent.
I
  recognize the very restrictive standard of review this court must employ when
  reviewing the decision of an agency under the Administrative Procedures Act, as
  noted in the majority opinion.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp.
  2007).Â  After reviewing the Appeals Committeeâ€™s decision with great deference,
  however, I find the Committee erred in denying Sheffieldâ€™s claim.Â  I would
  affirm the circuit court.
Sheffield was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis and SjÃ¶grens syndrome.Â  Sheffieldâ€™s
  family doctor, Glenn Welcker, saw and treated Sheffield.Â  Welcker referred Sheffield to an ENT specialist, Dr. C. Willy Schwenzfeier, who treated her for the SjÃ¶grens
  syndrome.Â  Schwenzfeier referred Sheffield to a rheumatoid arthritis
  specialist, Dr. Alan Nussbaum.Â  Nussbaum saw and treated Sheffield for
  arthritis, concluding: (1) she had a â€œchronic illness which is unlikely to
  improve;â€ and (2) â€œshe is unable to function as a classroom teacher.â€Â  Nussbaum
  found Sheffieldâ€™s arthritis worsening.Â  Furthermore, Nussbaum responded â€œNeverâ€
  to the insurance form question asking when he expected a fundamental change in
  condition.Â  Welcker likewise concluded Sheffield was unable to continue
  working.Â  
In
  comparison, the medical opinions relied upon by the Committee to deny benefits
  were made by two physicians, Shirley Ingram and Ronald Fraback, hired by the
  disability plan.Â  Neither of these physicians ever examined Sheffield.Â  Ingram
  opined Sheffieldâ€™s arthritis was not â€œsignificantâ€ because Nussbaum did not
  recommend a particular treatment.Â  Ingram also questioned the impact of Sheffieldâ€™s SjÃ¶grens syndrome because she could not review records of an ENT.Â  However, Sheffield was referred to and treated by an ENT and thereafter by Welcker.Â  Furthermore,
  Ingram concluded she was â€œunable to assess [Sheffieldâ€™s] limitationsâ€ as to her
  SjÃ¶grens syndrome.Â  Fraback apparently incorrectly believed Sheffield was never
  referred to an ENT stating his belief â€œan [ENT] consultation would be
  expected.â€Â  Fraback otherwise concluded Sheffieldâ€™s arthritis was only â€œmild to
  moderateâ€ because she was being treated with â€œminimal medication.â€Â  As found by
  the circuit court, these reviewing doctors did not specifically dispute
  Sheffieldâ€™s condition or the physical limitations imposed by Sheffieldâ€™s
  treating physicians.Â  Rather, they advocated different treatment methods.Â 
  Accordingly, I agree with the circuit courtâ€™s finding that the Committeeâ€™s
  decision to deny the claim was erroneous.Â  I would affirm.

  resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

  dry mouth.

text:

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Adam S. Roberts, Appellant,
				v.
				Marcia M. Roberts, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Georgetown County
H. E. Bonnoitt, Jr., Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-311
Submitted June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed June 18,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				David Hart Breen, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
				Toni Lee Tack Pennington, of Pawleys Island, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  In this child custody action, Adam S. Roberts (Father) appeals the family
  courtâ€™s dismissal for lack of jurisdiction.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
Father and Marcia M. Roberts (Mother) married on July 29, 2000,
  and separated in 2001.Â  Child was born April 26, 2001.Â  Mother and Child moved
  from New York to South Carolina in January 2002.Â  Father remained in New York, where he was incarcerated for an unspecified period of time.Â  Father maintained
  regular telephone contact with Child and sent money to support Mother and
  Child.Â Â  
Father assisted Mother in purchasing a home on Pawleys Island.Â  Although the parties remained married, Mother purchased the home in her name
  only, followed by the notation â€œan unmarried woman.â€Â  Mother notified Father by
  letter that she and Child had moved from South Carolina to California as of
  June 1, 2006.Â  
On June 19, 2006, Father filed suit in South Carolina seeking
  divorce, equitable distribution of property, and child custody.Â  In August, Mother
  filed suit in California seeking the same relief.Â  The South Carolina family
  court heard Fatherâ€™s motion for temporary relief on September 12, 2006.Â  At that
  hearing, Mother argued South Carolina lacked jurisdiction to hear this matter because
  she and Child had moved from South Carolina to California on February 5, 2006.Â Â Â  
The family court found neither party lived in South Carolina at
  the time Father filed suit.Â  Furthermore, the family court found jurisdiction
  was proper in California and stated even if South Carolina had jurisdiction,
  the family court â€œwould waive that jurisdiction to the State of California.â€Â  Consequently, the family court dismissed Fatherâ€™s case for lack of
  jurisdiction.Â Â  
On October 18, 2006, Father filed a motion for reconsideration of
  the child custody and visitation issues.Â  At the hearing on November 28, 2006,
  Father proffered the testimony of Childâ€™s teacher, Leslie Lane Whitley, who was
  also the director of the Montessori school Child attended in Pawleys Island.Â  Whitley testified Child attended her school for at least two years.Â  Child was
  absent from school for three weeks during February 2006 and for five additional
  days between the end of February and May 12, 2006.Â  Child did not return to
  school after May 12, 2006.Â  Whitley further stated Mother had informed her that
  Mother and Child traveled to California in February to assist Motherâ€™s
  boyfriend in cleaning out his house and that Mother and Child would relocate to
  California permanently in mid-May 2006.Â Â Â  
On January 18, 2007, the family court entered an order finding a
  dispute existed as to the date Mother and Child relocated to California.Â  The
  order also denied Fatherâ€™s motion for reconsideration and required Father to
  pay $500.00 toward Motherâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When
  reviewing a decision by the family court, the appellate court has the authority
  to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 61, 624 S.E.2d 649,
  652 (2006).Â  This broad scope of review does not require the appellate
  court to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Wooten v. Wooten,
  364 S.C. 532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102 (2005).Â  A family court has
  discretion to decline jurisdiction of a child custody matter on the basis of
  inconvenient forum.Â  Mansour v. Mansour, 296 S.C. 215, 217, 371 S.E.2d
  537, 538 (1998).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of the
  family court either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of
  law.Â  Bryson v. Bryson, 347 S.C. 221, 224, 553 S.E.2d 493, 495 (Ct. App.
  2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS

Initially,
  we note this matter potentially involves South Carolina, California, and
  federal child custody laws.Â  The timing of this action further complicates the
  interaction of laws, because during the pendency of the appeal, South Carolinaâ€™s new uniform act governing child custody matters became effective.Â  
In South Carolina, requests for relief made prior to June 8, 2007, in child custody
  proceedings are governed by the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act (UCCJA)[2] instead of the more recently enacted Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and
  Enforcement Act (UCCJEA).Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-6094 (Supp. 2007).Â  Child
  custody actions in California are governed by the California UCCJEA.Â  Cal. Fam. Code Â§ 3400 (West 2008).[3]Â  
All
  motions or requests for relief in this matter were made and ruled upon during
  or before January of 2007.Â  Accordingly, the South Carolina UCCJA governed the
  family courtâ€™s decision from which Father appeals.Â  
I.  Inconvenient
  Forum
Father
  argues the family court abused its discretion by declining jurisdiction because
  South Carolina had the closest connection with Child.Â  We disagree.Â  
The
  family court is the proper forum for child custody disputes in South Carolina.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-400 (1985).Â  However, a South Carolina court may
  decline to exercise jurisdiction â€œif it finds that it is an inconvenient forum
  to make a custody determination under the circumstances of the case and that a
  court of another state is a more appropriate forum.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-7-796(a) (1985).Â  In determining whether South Carolina is an inconvenient
  forum, the family court must examine factors including, but not limited to, the
  following:

	
		
			(1) 
			if another state was recently the childâ€™s home 
			state; 
 
		
		
			(2) 
			if another state has a closer connection with the 
			child and his family or with the child and one or more of the 
			contestants; [and]
 
		
		
			(3)
			if substantial evidence concerning the childâ€™s 
			present or future care, protection, training and personal 
			relationship [is] more readily available in another state.
		
	

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-7-796(c).Â  Under the UCCJA, South Carolina defined â€œhome stateâ€ as the state
  in which â€œthe child immediately preceding the time involved lived with . . . a
  parent . . . for at least six consecutive months . . . .Â  Periods of temporary
  absence of any of the named persons are counted as part of the six-month or
  other period.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-786(5).[4]Â  
We
  find the family court did not err in finding a California court was the
  appropriate forum for trial of this matter.Â  The family court had discretion
  under the UCCJA to decline jurisdiction on the basis that South Carolina was an
  inconvenient forum and that another state would be more appropriate.Â  S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-796(a).Â  In doing so, the family court weighed several factors and
  found facts favoring trial in California.Â  The family court found neither the
  parties nor Child lived in South Carolina on or after the date Father filed
  this action, both Mother and Child had become residents of California, and California was the proper jurisdiction for determination of divorce and child custody
  issues.Â  Furthermore, under its UCCJEA, California could accept jurisdiction
  upon South Carolinaâ€™s declination thereof.[5]Â 
  Accordingly, the family court did not abuse its discretion in finding California was a more appropriate jurisdiction for trial of child custody issues in this
  case.Â  
We disagree
  with the family courtâ€™s finding that South Carolina lacked subject matter jurisdiction.Â 
  Nonetheless, because the family court had both the discretion and a factual
  basis to decline jurisdiction, this finding was harmless error.Â  See Davis v. Davis, 372 S.C. 64, 87, 641 S.E.2d 446, 458 (Ct. App. 2006) (finding
  error is only reversible if material and prejudicial to appellantâ€™s substantial
  rights).Â  Both South Carolina law and California law required six monthsâ€™
  residency before a state could become a childâ€™s â€œhome state.â€Â  Under the laws
  of both states, South Carolina was Childâ€™s home state when Father filed suit.Â 
  Mother asserted she and Child moved from South Carolina to California in
  February 2006, four months before Father filed suit.Â  Father asserted, with the
  support of Motherâ€™s letter and Childâ€™s teacherâ€™s testimony, that Mother and
  Child moved from South Carolina in June 2006, just two weeks before Father
  filed suit.Â  However, when Father filed suit, South Carolina was the only state
  in which Child had lived for six months or more.Â  Regardless of whether Mother
  moved in February or June, South Carolina did not lose â€œhome stateâ€
  jurisdiction because of Motherâ€™s move to California.Â  
Therefore,
  the family court erroneously concluded South Carolina lacked jurisdiction.Â 
  However, this error was harmless, because the family court possessed authority
  to decline jurisdiction in this matter.Â  The family court correctly concluded
  jurisdiction was proper in California.Â  
II.  Fraud
Father
  also argues declining jurisdiction was an abuse of discretion because Mother
  removed Child from South Carolina unilaterally and committed fraud on the court
  in an effort to defeat South Carolina jurisdiction.Â  We disagree.Â  
South
  Carolina recognizes fraud on the court as â€œâ€˜that species of fraud which does,
  or attempts to, subvert the integrity of the Court itself, or is a fraud
  perpetrated by officers of the court so that the judicial machinery cannot
  perform in the usual manner its impartial task of adjudging cases that are
  presented for adjudication.â€™â€Â  Chewning v. Ford Motor Co., 354 S.C. 72,
  78, 579 S.E.2d 605, 608 (2003) (quoting Evans v. Gunter, 294 S.C. 525,
  529, 366 S.E.2d 44, 46 (Ct. App. 1988)).Â  To merit vacating a judgment, the
  fraud alleged must be extrinsic.Â  Id. at 80, 579 S.E.2d at 610 (citing Bryan
    v. Bryan, 220 S.C. 164, 168, 66 S.E.2d 609, 610 (1951)).Â  The fundamental
  difference between extrinsic fraud and intrinsic fraud is that extrinsic fraud
  denies the opposing party his day in court.Â  Id. at 82, 579 S.E.2d at
  611.Â  Extrinsic fraud: 

	â€œ[I]nduces
  a person not to present a case or deprives a person of the opportunity to be
  heard.Â  Relief is granted for extrinsic fraud on the theory that because the
  fraud prevented a party from fully exhibiting and trying his case, there has
  never been a real contest before the court on the subject matter of the action.â€

Id. at 81, 579 S.E.2d at 610 (quoting Hilton Head Ctr.
  of S.C. v. Public Serv. Commâ€™n, 294 S.C. 9, 11, 362 S.E.2d 176, 177
  (1987)).Â  Extrinsic fraud includes subornation of perjury or intentional
  concealment of documents by an attorney, but not by a witness.Â  Id. at 82, 579 S.E.2d at 610-11.Â  
By
  contrast, equitable relief from a judgment is not available on the basis of
  intrinsic fraud.Â  Id. at 82, 579 S.E.2d at 610 (citing Bryan, 220
  S.C. at 168, 66 S.E.2d at 610).Â  Intrinsic fraud â€œmisleads a court in
  determining issues and induces the court to find for the party perpetrating the
  fraud.â€Â  Id. at 81, 579 S.E.2d at 610 (quoting Hilton Head Ctr.,
  294 S.C. at 11, 362 S.E.2d at 177).Â  Intrinsic fraud includes perjury by a
  party or a witness.Â  Id. at 81, 579 S.E.2d at 610.Â  Â Â 
The
  family court did not err in declining to accept jurisdiction on the basis of
  Motherâ€™s alleged fraud.Â  Motherâ€™s misrepresentation of the date she and Child
  moved to California is, at worst, perjury by a party.Â  Perjury by a party is
  intrinsic fraud.Â  Because relief from judgment is not available for intrinsic
  fraud, the family court correctly declined to reconsider its decision.Â  Furthermore,
  the family court had discretion to waive jurisdiction even if Mother had
  admitted to moving in June rather than in February.Â  Motherâ€™s alleged fraud did
  not affect the outcome of the case.Â  Consequently, the family court did not err
  in declining jurisdiction despite Motherâ€™s alleged fraud.
CONCLUSION

We
  find the family court did not abuse its discretion in declining jurisdiction,
  regardless of Motherâ€™s alleged fraud in misrepresenting the date she and Child
  moved to California.Â  Accordingly, the order of the family court in this matter
  is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
SHORT
  and KONDUROS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-782 to -830 (repealed 2007).Â  
[3] If state and federal laws on child custody
  jurisdiction conflict, both South Carolina and California courts defer to the
  provisions of the federal Parental Kidnapping Prevention Act (PKPA), 28 U.S.C.
  Â§ 1738A (2000).Â  Clay v. Burckle, 369 S.C. 651, 656, 633 S.E.2d 173, 176
  (Ct. App. 2006); In re Marriage of Pedowitz, 179 Cal. App. 3d 992, 999
  (5th Dist. 1986).Â  We see no such conflict in this matter.Â  Consequently, we
  rely on state law to resolve the questions raised herein.
[4] The South Carolina UCCJAâ€™s definition of â€œhome stateâ€
  is substantially similar to the definitions in the PKPA and the California
  UCCJEA.Â  See 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(b)(4) (2000); Cal. Fam. Code Â§ 3402(g) (West
  2008).
[5] Under certain circumstances, a California court may
  make an initial child custody determination concerning a child whose home state
  is elsewhere.Â  For example, a California court may accept jurisdiction if all
  other courts having jurisdiction â€œhave declined to exercise jurisdiction on the
  ground that a court of this state is the more appropriate forum to determine
  the custody of the childâ€ either because each other state is an inconvenient
  forum or because the party seeking California jurisdiction has engaged in
  â€œunjustified conduct.â€Â  Cal. Fam. Code Â§ 3421(a) (West 2008).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				In the Interest
      of Gavin N., a minor under the age of eighteen, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Florence County
Â A. E. â€œGeneâ€ Morehead, III, Family Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-312
Submitted April 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 20,
  2008
AFFIRMED 


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender LaNelle C. DuRant, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior
  Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., of Columbia; and Solicitor Edgar
  Lewis Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Appellant
  appeals the family courtâ€™s order finding him guilty of two counts of assault
  with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct (ACSC) in the first degree.Â  We
  affirm.[1]
FACTS
On August 10, 2006, Appellant was brought before the family court
  for trial on the following charges:Â  (1) two counts of first degree burglary;
  (2) two counts of first degree ACSC; (3) two counts of third degree ACSC; (4)
  three counts of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN); (5)
  two counts of strong arm robbery; (6) three counts of petit larceny; (7) one
  count of attempted strong arm robbery; and (8) three counts of kidnapping.Â  Before
  the trial commenced, Appellant pled guilty to all charges except the four ACSC
  charges.Â  The family court accepted Appellantâ€™s pleas, postponed sentencing
  Appellant on the pleaded offenses until after the trial on the remaining
  offense concluded, and proceeded to conduct Appellantâ€™s trial on the remaining
  offenses.
At the conclusion of the Stateâ€™s case in chief, Appellantâ€™s
  attorney moved to dismiss the remaining charges on the ground of double
  jeopardy.Â  Appellantâ€™s attorney argued â€œsome of these counts â€“ the testimony
  offered and the allegations made in the counts seem to [mirror] what heâ€™s (sic)
  already pled to . . . .â€Â  The family court ruled â€œ[d]ouble jeopardy is not
  attached.â€Â  Ultimately, the family court found Appellant guilty of both counts
  of first degree ACSC and dismissed both counts of third degree ACSC.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellant argues
  the trial court violated the double jeopardy clause by finding him guilty of
  two counts of ACSC because he had pleaded guilty to ABHAN under the same set of facts.Â  We disagree.
In State
  v. Coleman, 365 S.C. 258, 262-63, 616 S.E.2d 444, 446 (Ct. App. 2005)
  (citation omitted), this court stated the purpose of the double jeopardy clause:

	The Double Jeopardy Clauses of the United States and South Carolina Constitutions protect citizens from being twice placed in
  jeopardy of life or liberty. See U.S. Const. amend. V (â€œNo person shall
  be . . . subject for the same offence to be twice put in jeopardy of life or
  limb . . . .â€); S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 12 (â€œNo person shall be subject for the
  same offense to be twice put in
  jeopardy of life or liberty . . . .â€). Under the law of double jeopardy,
  a defendant may not be prosecuted for the same offense after an acquittal, a
  conviction, or an improvidently granted mistrial.

The
  Supreme Court of the United States has held the Double Jeopardy Clause affords
  defendants three protections:

	[It] â€˜protects
  against a second prosecution for the same offense after acquittal. Â It protects
  against a second prosecution for the same offense after conviction. Â And it
  protects against multiple punishments for the same offense.â€™Â  Where consecutive
  sentences are imposed at a single criminal trial, the role of the
  constitutional guarantee is limited to assuring that the court does not exceed
  its legislative authorization by imposing multiple punishments for the same
  offense.Â  Where successive prosecutions are at stake, the guarantee serves â€˜a
  constitutional policy of finality for the defendantâ€™s benefit.â€™ That policy
  protects the accused from attempts to relitigate the facts underlying a prior
  acquittal, [] and from attempts to secure additional punishment after a prior
  conviction and sentence.

Brown v. Ohio, 432 U.S. 161, 165-66 (1977) (internal citations
  omitted).Â  It is well established that ABHAN is a
  lesser included offense of ACSC.Â  See State v. Elliott,
  346 S.C. 603, 607, 552 S.E.2d 727, 729 (2001) (overruled on other
  grounds).
In Ohio v. Johnson, 467 U.S. 493 (1984), the Supreme Court of the United States
  addressed the implications of the Double Jeopardy Clause when a defendant
  pleads guilty to a lesser included offense.Â  The court stated â€œ[t]he acceptance
  of a guilty plea to lesser included offenses while charges on the greater
  offenses remain pending, moreover, has none of the implications of an â€˜implied
  acquittalâ€™ which results from a verdict convicting a defendant on lesser
  included offenses rendered by a jury charged to consider both greater and
  lesser included offenses.â€Â  Id. at 501-2.Â  The court found that
  prosecution of the greater offenses was not barred by the Double Jeopardy
  Clause and, specifically held â€œ[w]hile the Double Jeopardy Clause may protect a
  defendant against cumulative punishments for convictions on the same offense,
  the Clause does not prohibit the State from prosecuting [a defendant] for such
  multiple offenses in a single prosecution.â€Â  Id. at 500.Â  
Here,
  Appellant pleaded guilty to lesser offenses.Â  The trial court accepted the
  pleas and held the matter of sentencing in abeyance until Appellant was tried
  for the remaining offenses. Â Immediately following the acceptance of the guilty
  pleas, the trial for the remaining charges was conducted.Â  At the conclusion of
  the trial, the trial court found Appellant guilty of both counts of first degree ACSC, dismissed
  both counts of third degree ACSC, and committed Appellant to the custody of the
  Department of Juvenile Justice not to exceed his twenty-first birthday.Â  Appellant was not subjected to cumulative punishments
  for convictions on the same offenses.Â  Accordingly, we find no violation of the
  Double Jeopardy Clause.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated above, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON,
  SHORT, and THOMAS JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Thomas Dewey
          Wise and Island Preservation Company, Limited Partnership, a South Carolina
          Limited Partnership, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        South Fenwick, LLC and Lavington Associates, LLC, Respondents
      
    
  


Appeal From Colleton County
Marvin D. Infinger, Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-314
Submitted June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed June 25,
2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				David K. Haller, of Charleston, for Appellants.
				Richard L. Tapp, Jr., and Stephen P. Groves, of Charleston, for
  Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Thomas
  Dewey Wise and Island Preservation Company[1] (collectively referred to as Wise) appeal from the special refereeâ€™s
  determination that: Â (1) an unpaved pathway running along the north-south
  corridor of the west side of South Fenwick Island (referred to as the Main
  Road) was impliedly dedicated to the public or a neighborhood road; (2) Wise
  does not possess a prescriptive easement over any portion of the Main Road; (3)
  Wise does not possess a prescriptive easement or an easement by necessity
  across Tract 19 on what is referred to as the Spur Road; and (5) Wise can
  access his landlocked property on Tract 3 from a relocated way.Â  We affirm.[2] 
FACTS
South Fenwick Island is a remote island of approximately 500 acres
  located in Colleton County.Â  The Island has no paved roads or public utilities
  and is accessible only by boat.Â  Until the 1960s, several families lived on the
  Island, where they cultivated crops and raised livestock. Â A church and a
  public school were located adjacent to the Main Road.Â  Since 1960, portions of
  the Island have been sold, and today it is used primarily for hunting and
  fishing.Â  Although no one currently lives on the Island, some of the
  original owners still have property on the Island that they visit
  periodically.Â  
In 1984, Wise began purchasing property on the Island including
  Tract 10 on the south and center sections and Tract 3 on the north end.Â  Wise
  currently owns Tracts 1, 3, 4, 10, and 21.Â  He keeps farm equipment, trucks,
  and three-wheel vehicles on the Island, but does not have a residence there.Â  In
  1996, South Fenwick and Lavington Associates (collectively referred to as
  â€œSouth Fenwickâ€) purchased Tract 15 on the south end and subsequently purchased
  Tracts 18, 19, and 20 on the north end.Â  David Maybank, Jr., who manages the
  property held by South Fenwick, testified that Wise erected a gate in 2004 that
  blocked the Main Road and told Maybank to stop using that section of the Main Road.Â  
Wise and his witnesses testified that from
  1985 to 1997 they accessed the east side of Tract 1 by crossing Tracts 2, 19,
  and 4.Â  After Wise purchased Tract 4 in 1997, they continued to cross Tracts 2
  and 19 without seeking permission from the owners.Â  Wise testified there were
  no issues until South Fenwick purchased Tract 19 in March 2005 and erected a
  fence that blocked Wiseâ€™s preferred access to his property on Tract 1 along a
  pathway referred to as Spur Road.[3]Â 
  Wise erected a barrier across the Main Road at Tract 21 precluding South
  Fenwickâ€™s use of the road to access its Tracts 18, 19, and 20.Â  
Wise brought this action against South Fenwick seeking a
  determination that he had acquired: Â (1) a prescriptive easement over the Main Road and (2) a prescriptive easement or, alternatively, an easement by necessity over
  Tract 19 to access his property on Tracts 1 and 3.Â  South Fenwick
  counterclaimed, asserting the Main Road had been impliedly dedicated to the
  property or was a neighborhood road allowing general use by the public.Â  In
  addition, it denied Wiseâ€™s right to an easement over Tract 19.[4]Â  Wise replied and did not assert any
  affirmative defenses to South Fenwickâ€™s counterclaims.Â  
With the partiesâ€™ consent, the circuit court appointed Marvin
  Infinger as special referee.Â  The referee held:Â  (1) the Main Road had been
  impliedly dedicated to the public; (2) the Main Road was a public road under
  the doctrine of neighborhood road; (3) Wise did not have a prescriptive
  easement over the Main Road; (4) Wise must immediately remove obstructions he
  placed on the Main Road; (5) Wise did not possess a prescriptive easement or
  easement by necessity on the Spur Road (6) Wise was entitled to an easement by
  necessity running between Tracts 4 & 3 and across Tract 19, fifteen feet
  wide by twenty feet long.Â  Subsequently, both parties filed motions to alter or
  amend the final order.Â  On April 20, 2007, the referee denied Wiseâ€™s post-trial
  motions and granted South Fenwickâ€™s motion, clarifying that Wise was not
  allowed to block the Community Road.Â  Wiseâ€™s appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  determination of the existence of an easement is a question of fact in an action
  at law. Â Hardy v. Aiken, 369 S.C. 160, 165, 631 S.E.2d 539, 541 (2006). Â â€œHowever,
  the determination of the scope of the easement is a question in equity.â€Â  Id. Â â€œThe determination of whether a road has been dedicated to public use is one in equity.â€Â  Vick v.
    S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 347 S.C. 470, 477, 556 S.E.2d 693, 697 (Ct. App.
  2001). Â 
â€œIn
  an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of
  fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without
  evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  Townes Assocs.,
    Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  In an action in equity, this court may view the facts
  in accordance with our preponderance of the evidence.Â  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher
    Agro, Inc., 301 S.C. 229, 237, 391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1989).Â  However, we
  should not disregard the findings of the special referee, who was in a better
  position to weigh the credibility of witnesses.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Main Road 
A.  Indispensable
  Parties
Wise
  argues the referee erred in determining the Main Road is a dedicated public or
  neighborhood road without first requiring South Fenwick to add Colleton County and all owners of property or easements adjacent to the Main Road as
  indispensable parties.Â  We find this issue is not properly before the court.
The defense
  of failure to join indispensable parties is waived if not raised at trial. Â Kiriakides v. Atlas Food Sys.
    & Serv., 343 S.C. 587, 596, 541 S.E.2d 257, 262 (2001) (citing Rule
  12(h)(2), SCRCP).Â  Wise brought this action seeking a declaration of his rights
  to the Community Road.Â  As the complaining party, Wise named only South Fenwick and Lavington Associates as defendants.Â  In responding to South Fenwickâ€™s
  counterclaims seeking a determination that the Main Road had been dedicated to
  the public, Wise failed to plead the affirmative defense of failure to join
  indispensable parties pursuant to 12(b)(7), South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â 
  There is no indication in the record that the issue of the failure to add
  indispensable parties was tried by consent.Â  Wiseâ€™s attorney questioned
  whether Maybank represented Colleton County and asserted Maybank did not have
  standing or the right to accept a road on behalf of Colleton County.Â  However, Wise never asserted the action must fail due to the failure to add Colleton County as a party.Â  As the special referee
  noted in his order on the post-trial motions, â€œ[t]he issue of whether
  indispensable parties should be added was not raised by either party.â€Â 
  Instead, Wise raised the issue of the failure to add all of the neighboring
  landowners for the first time in his motion to alter or amend.Â  A party cannot
  use a motion to reconsider, alter or amend a judgment to present an issue that
  could have been raised prior to the judgment but was not.Â  Patterson v. Reid, 318 S.C. 183, 185, 456 S.E.2d 436, 437 (Ct.App.1995). Â Accordingly,
  we find the issue of failure to join alleged indispensable parties is not
  preserved for this courtâ€™s review. Â 
B.  Implied
  dedication
Wise
  argues the referee erred in determining the Main Road had been impliedly
  dedicated to the public many decades earlier.Â  Specifically, Wise states there
  is â€œscantâ€ evidence of intent to dedicate the road to the public and â€œno
  evidenceâ€ of the publicâ€™s acceptance of the implied dedication.Â  We disagree.
The
  party seeking to establish dedication must prove two elements:Â  (1) the owner
  must express in a positive and an unmistakable manner the intention to dedicate
  his property to public use, and (2) there must be, within a reasonable time, an
  express or implied public acceptance of the property offered for dedication. Â Tupper
    v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 326, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191-92 (1997).Â  Intent
  to dedicate may be implied from long public use of the land to which the owner
  acquiesces.Â  Hoogenboom v. City of Beaufort, 315 S.C. 306, 317, 433 S.E.2d
  875, 883 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  No formal acceptance by the public of an offer of
  dedication is necessary, and acceptance of the offer may be implied in various
  ways, including a showing of public use.Â  Van Blarcum v. City of N. Myrtle Beach, 337 S.C. 446, 451, 523 S.E.2d 486, 489 (Ct. App. 1999). Â Proof of
  dedication must be strict, cogent, and convincing.Â  Tupper, 326 S.C. at
  326, 487 S.E.2d at 192.Â  
The Main Road appeared on government maps and charts as early as 1919.Â  Arthur Buster Whaley,
  who was born on the Island in 1925 and lived there until 1965, testified in a
  deposition in another case that his family had owned property on the Island.Â  Whaley had inherited Tracts 7, 14, and 21; however, by 2003, he owned only Tract
  7.Â  Whaley stated about sixteen families lived on the Island during the 1940s.Â 
  According to Whaley, a road ran from the cut at the north end â€œstraight through
  the plantation,â€ and families used this road to walk to church, to visit each
  other, and to drive horse-drawn carts from the landing to their homes.Â  Whaley said the residents of the Island maintained the Main Road.Â  Whaley added
  that each family had its own wagon and it was not necessary for them to obtain
  permission to travel on the Main Road.Â  Everyone simply used the road.Â  Whaley
  stated that neither he nor Wise ever prohibited the other from using sections
  of the Main Road.Â  
Kenneth
  Hodges, a fifty-five-year-old Baptist minister, testified his great-great
  grandfather, Dave Smalls, once owned most of the Island.Â  Although Hodgesâ€™s
  family now owns only a small parcel, he visited the Island several times a
  year.Â  Hodges stated Island residents used the Main Road to reach the school,
  the church, and their individual properties.Â  According to Hodges, â€œThe
  properties are still there so the need [for the road] is still there.â€Â  
In
  1980, Willie Hopkins sold Tract 19 to Wiseâ€™s predecessors in title.Â  In a 1995
  affidavit, Hopkins stated: â€œ[T]here was a path wide enough for two ox carts to
  pass (about 20 feet) that was used by my family and neighbors to the east to
  get back and forth to the government cut.Â  We all used it and considered it a
  path for all persons.â€Â  
On
  October 30, 2002, Wise filed an action seeking a declaration that he was
  entitled to use the Main Road based upon the legal theory that the Main Road was a thoroughfare available to all property owners.[5]Â 
  In that action, Wiseâ€™s complaint asserted: 

	Their
  (sic) exists and has existed for well over 50 years, a dirt road running
  parallel to the Ashepoo River in a generally north to south orientation along
  most of the island.Â  The purpose of this road was to allow property owners to
  travel across the island.Â  Many former residents of the island including the
  Defendant Whaley, the Plaintiffs and their predecessors in title owned property
  on the island and used the road.Â  There was at one time located on South Fenwick Island both a school and a church.Â  Both were located adjacent to the road in
  question and the road in question was a common thoroughfare used by all to
  travel to the school and to the church and to visit their properties. 

We
  find the evidence supports the refereeâ€™s decision that South Fenwick had
  established an implied dedication of the Main Road.Â  The record is replete with
  evidence that the Main Road had been used for over fifty years by the residents
  and property owners of the Island as they traveled over the Island to go to the
  school, church, and each otherâ€™s residents, and to haul supplies from the main
  land to their homes.Â  This long-term use to which the owners of the property
  acquiesced establishes an intent to dedicate.Â  Similarly, the long-term use
  along with the residentsâ€™ maintenance of the road establishes an acceptance of
  the dedication by the public.Â  
C.Â 
  Neighborhood Road
As we find the Main Road was impliedly dedicated to the public, we need not address the doctrine of
  neighborhood road.Â  
D.Â 
  Abandonment
Wise
  additionally contends the referee erred in failing to find Main Road had been
  abandoned.Â  We disagree.
The
  supreme court found an unmaintained road that became public by dedication or
  through prescriptive or long-established use had not been abandoned because no
  interested person had instituted an action under the statutory process to
  effect an abandonment of the road.Â  It held, â€œThe circuit court correctly
  concluded [the] Road remains publicly accessible because no formal action has
  been instituted to abandon it pursuant to [statute[6]].â€
  Â S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp. v. Hinson Family Holdings, LLC, 361 S.C. 649,
  655-56, 606 S.E.2d 781, 785 (2004). Â In this case, there has been no action to
  abandon the Main Road.Â  We find the evidence supports the
  refereeâ€™s conclusion that the Main Road had not been abandoned. 
E.Â 
  Prescriptive easement
Wise
  asserts the referee erred in failing to rule Wise had obtained a prescriptive
  easement over the Main Road.Â  
We
  disagree.Â  This court held a plaintiff did not establish a private right under
  a prescriptive easement because he failed to produce evidence that his use was
  exclusive and was different from the right which could be asserted by members
  of the general public.Â  Cleland v. Westvaco, 314 S.C. 508, 511, 431
  S.E.2d 264, 266 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  As stated above, the Main Road had been
  dedicated to general public use.Â  Wiseâ€™s right to use the Main Road was no
  different than the publicâ€™s right.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the refereeâ€™s
  determination that Wise does not have a prescriptive easement.
II.  Spur Road
A.Â 
  Prescriptive easement
Wise
  argues the referee erred in holding he did not hold a prescriptive easement
  over Tract 19 to access the eastern section of Tract 1 from the Main Road on
  what is called the Spur Road.Â  We disagree.Â  
In
  order to establish a prescriptive easement, a party must prove:Â  

	Â (1)
  continued use for 20 years, (2) the identity of the thing enjoyed, and (3) use
  which is either adverse or under a claim of right.Â  When the claimant has
  established that the use was open, notorious, continuous, and uninterrupted,
  the use will be presumed to have been adverse.Â  

Boyd v. Bellsouth Tel. Tel.
  Co., 369 S.C. 410, 419-20, 633 S.E.2d
  136, 141 (2006).Â  
Wise
  purchased Tract 1 in 1985 and contends he created the Spur Road, which crosses
  Tracts 2, 19, and 4, to avoid the marsh when traveling from the Main Road to the eastern side of Tract 1.Â  
While
  Wise and his witnesses claimed they had used the Spur Road since Wise created
  it in 1984 or 1985, several witnesses testified the Spur Road had not existed
  until more recently.Â  Kenneth Hodges testified his family owned Tract 2 for
  generations and there was not a bush-hogged road across it since 1984 or 1985.Â 
  Similarly, Harold Rourk, who owned Tract 4 from 1979 to 1996, testified he had
  never seen bush hogging across his property.Â  Regarding the Spur Road, Rourk
  testified: â€œIs that road supposed to be on the property that I owned?Â  Iâ€™ve
  never seen that road before.â€Â  Rourk additionally testified, â€œThat was my
  property.Â  I would notice if somebody had been on it.â€Â  Robert Frank, who
  surveyed Tract 4 in 1995, stated he never saw â€œthe manmade Spur Road that is in
  dispute.â€Â  
The
  referee held that in order for Wise to claim a prescriptive easement, his use
  of the road must be open and notorious.Â  Considering the above testimony, the
  referee held the claimed pathway was not sufficiently visible and open to place
  South Fenwick on notice that its property was being invaded by Wise and thus
  Wise had acquired no right by prescription.Â  
Wise
  does not claim he did not have to establish his use was open and notorious.Â 
  Rather, he challenges the credibility of the above witnesses.Â  However, the
  credibility of testimony is a matter for the finder of fact to judge.Â  â€œCredibility
  determinations regarding testimony are a matter for the finder of fact, who has
  the opportunity to observe the witnesses, and those determinations are entitled
  to great deference on appeal.â€ Â Okatie River, L.L.C. v.
    Southeastern Site Prep, L.L.C., 353 S.C. 327, 338, 557 S.E.2d 468, 474 (Ct.
  App. 2003).Â  Wise also takes issue with South Fenwickâ€™s failure to call Harry
  Turner, the former owner of Tract 19, as a witness.Â  â€œIt is a well settled rule
  that if a party knows of the existence of an available witness on a material
  issue and such witness is within his control and if without satisfactory
  explanation he fails to call him, the jury may draw the inference that the
  testimony of the witness would not have been favorable to such party.Â  Duckworth
    v. First National Bank, 254 S.C. 563, 577, 176 S.E.2d 297, 304 (1970).Â  However,
  this rule only applies when the witness is in the control of the party and is
  available.Â  Id.Â  Here, there is no evidence Harry Turner was in the
  control of South Fenwick.Â  Therefore, no inference concerning his testimony
  could be drawn. Â 
Wise asserts his
  and his witnessesâ€™ testimony concerning the use of Tract 19 was uncontradicted
  because the South Fenwickâ€™s witnesses only testified about the lack of
  visibility of the Spur Road on the other tracts rather than on Tract 19.Â  We
  find it reasonable for the referee to find Wiseâ€™s use of Tract 19 was no more
  open and notorious than it was on the other tracts along which the Spur Road ran.Â  Furthermore, â€œthe fact that testimony is not contradicted directly does not
  render it undisputed.â€ Okatie River, 353 S.C. at 338, 557 S.E.2d
  at 474.
We
  find the record supports the refereeâ€™s finding that Wiseâ€™s use of the Spur Road was not open and notorious.Â  Therefore, we must affirm his ruling that Wiseâ€™s
  claim for a prescriptive easement fails.Â  
B.Â 
  Easement by necessity
Wise
  argues the referee erred in holding he did not possess and easement by
  necessity over Tract 19.Â  We disagree.Â  
The
  party asserting the right of an easement by necessity must demonstrate:Â  (1)
  unity of title, (2) severance of title, and (3) necessity.Â  Kennedy v.
    Bedenbaugh, 352 S.C. 56, 60, 572 S.E.2d 452, 454 (2002).

	Only reasonable necessity is
  required; thus, the easement must be more than merely convenient, but it does
  not need to be absolutely essential. Â However, the whole point of the easement
  by necessity doctrine is to ensure that landlocked parcels have access to a public
  road . . . .Â  The doctrine only provides reasonable access to the dominant estate when there is
  none; it does not provide a means for ensuring a preferred method of access to
  a particular portion of a tract when access to the tract is otherwise
  available.

Morrow v. Dyches, 328 S.C. 522, 529, 492 S.E.2d 420, 424 (Ct. App. 1997)
  (internal citations omitted).Â  

	The
  Special Referee held: 
	
		Reasonable
  access exists to Tract 1 via the [Main Road] to the western high land portion
  of Tract 1.Â  This being the case, additional access over Tract 19 to the
  eastern portion of Tract 1 would be tantamount to providing [Wise] â€œa means for
  ensuring a preferred method of access to a particular portion of a tract when
  access to the tract is otherwise available.â€ [quoting Morrow, 328 S.C.
  at 529, 492 S.E.2d at 424.]Â  Hence, imposition of a way by necessity can not be
  justified, as a matter of law.Â  
	

Wise did not
  challenge this ruling.Â  Accordingly, it is the law of the case.Â  See Charleston
    Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 338 S.C. 171, 175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871
  (2000) (finding that an unappealed ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the
  case and requires affirmance).
In addition, the
  referee found that the evidence respecting a total breach of Tract 4 is
  unclear, and a total, or at least essentially a total breach was essential for
  Wiseâ€™s claim.Â  
Although
  a sketch of the property prepared by Jerry L. Fowler for Wise in 2006 shows the
  marsh crossing Tract 4 into Tract 19, a 1995 boundary survey of Tract 4
  prepared by Robert Frank for Clarence H. Rourk, Jr. shows the critical area
  protruding into Tract 4 but not completely crossing it.Â  Similarly, a composite
  sketch of the Island by Robert Frank Surveying shows the marsh protruding into
  Tract 4 but also not obstructing it completely.Â  
Furthermore,
  in a letter Wise wrote prior to his purchase of Tract 4, he stated, â€œAttached
  to this fax will be found the most recent version of Colleton County Tax Map
  Number 345.Â  Looking at the tax map, it is apparent that the marsh area of my
  property does not intrude on the strip of land for Lot No. 4 which is contrary
  to what is reflected on the Robert Frank survey.â€Â  
We find evidence in
  the record supporting the refereeâ€™s determination that Wise had not established
  entitlement to an easement by necessity over the Spur Road to the eastern
  portion of Tract 1.Â  Considering our limited standard of review, we find no
  error in this ruling.Â  
III.Â  Easement of necessity
  to access Tract 3 
Wise
  additionally contends the referee erred in relocating an easement to provide
  access to his Tract 3. We disagree.Â  
â€œA
  court using its equity powers may relocate an easement when the relocation will
  not â€˜(a) significantly lessen the utility of the easement, (b) increase the
  burdens on the owner of the easement in its use and enjoyment, or (c) frustrate
  the purpose for which the easement was created.â€™â€Â  Goodwin v. Johnson,
  357 S.C. 49, 53, 591 S.E.2d 34, 36 (Ct.App.2003) (quoting Restatement (Third)
  of Property:Â  Servitudes Â§ 4.8 (2000)).
The
  relocated easement is approximately fifteen feet wide by twenty feet long,
  providing access to Tract 3 from Tract 4 by crossing Tract 19.Â  The
  refereeâ€™s placement of the easement properly balances Wiseâ€™s need to reach
  landlocked Tract 3 from Tract 4 with the resulting burden placed on South Fenwickâ€™s servient estate. Â We find the referee did not err in his placement
  of the easement.
CONCLUSION
For
  the foregoing reasons, the order of the special referee is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ. concur.Â  


[1] Island Preservation Company is a family limited
partnership.Â  Wise is the general partner.Â  
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] The Spur
  Road runs from the Main Road at Tract 2, across Tracts 19 and 4, to Tract 1; an â€œoffshootâ€ of the Spur Road runs from Tract 4, across Tract 19, to Tract 3.Â  
[4] On
  June 6, 2006, the court granted Wiseâ€™s request for a temporary injunction and
  directed South Fenwick to allow Wise access over Tract 19 until their dispute
  was resolved.Â  Subsequently, the court
  amended the injunction to state its findings of fact and conclusions of law
  related only to the grant of a temporary injunction and were not binding on the
courtâ€™s subsequent consideration of the issues between the parties.Â  
[5] On appeal, Wise contends the referee erred in holding
  he was bound by admissions made in his pleading from another case.Â  The referee
  specifically stated he did not apply the doctrine of judicial estoppel.Â  We
  find the referee properly admitted the excerpt, offered without objection, as
  an admission by a party opponent, pursuant to Rule 801(d)(2)(A), South Carolina
  Rules of Evidence.Â  See Young v. Martin, 254 S.C. 50, 58, 173
  S.E.2d 361, 365 (1970) (â€œIt is well established that an admission contained in
  a pleading in one action may be received in evidence against the pleader on the
  trial of another action, even though the former action involved a stranger to
  the subsequent one.â€) 
[6] S.C. Code Ann. 57-9-10 to -20 (2006).
