THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Mathesoya
      Management Corporation, Respondent,
				v.
				Clifford Danny
      Taylor, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Master in Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-315
Heard April 8, 2008 â€“ Filed June 25, 2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED 


	
		
			
				R. Thayer Rivers, Jr., of Ridgeland, for Appellant.
				Drew A. Laughlin, of Hilton Head, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Clifford
  Danny Taylor appeals from an award granting Mathesoya Management Corporation
  (Mathesoya) damages for breach of a commercial lease.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
Taylor owned a
  retail clothing business in Lake City, South Carolina.Â  To facilitate
  relocation of the business to the Hilton Head area, Taylor entered into an
agreement with Mathesoya to lease commercial space in Bluffton, South Carolina.
The lease agreement covered Unit 11 and Unit 12 of the
  Village at Sheridan Park in Bluffton, South Carolina for a term of sixty
  months, commencing on June 1, 2001.Â  Under the agreement, Taylor agreed to pay
  rent for the use of the two units in monthly installments. Â Additionally, the
lease agreement provided: 

	All alterations, additions, improvements and fixtures,
  other than trade fixtures, which may be made or installed by either of the
  parties hereto upon the Demised Premises, and which in any manner are attached
  to the floors, walls or ceilings, shall be the property of Landlord and at the
  termination of this Lease Agreement shall remain upon and be surrendered with
the Demised Premises as part thereof, without disturbance or removal.Â  Â 

Taylor commenced
  business in June of 2001; however, by
  December of that year, business had slowed down considerably. Â After Taylor failed to pay the December rent, Mathesoya instituted eviction proceedings on
  January 13, 2002, and the court scheduled a hearing on the matter for January
  15.Â  Prior to the hearing, Taylor delivered a check to Mathesoya for the
  remaining balance; however, the check was dishonored when Lance Brutschy,
  President of Mathesoya, presented it to the bank.
Taylor failed to
  make an appearance at the January 15 hearing, and the Magistrate Court for Beaufort County granted the eviction.Â  On January 18, Brutschy received a call from Taylorâ€™s attorney, who asked if Mathesoya would allow Taylor to stay if the money was
  presented that day in cash.Â  Brutschy agreed to allow Taylor to stay on these
  conditions; however, the money was never presented to Brutschy.Â  On January 23,
  Taylor filed an affidavit with the court stating he had cured all defaults in
  payment of the rent and did not owe any money at that time.Â  Upon receipt of
  this affidavit, the court stayed the ejectment and scheduled another hearing
  for February 25 of that year.Â  Prior to the hearing, Taylor vacated the
  premises, removing his inventory and the air conditioning units he had
  personally purchased.
After Taylor left, Mathesoya eventually was able to rent the premises to new tenants; however,
  their rent was lower than what Taylor had been paying under his lease.Â  Mathesoya
  brought a claim against Taylor for damages resulting from the breach of the
  lease agreement, including unpaid rent, lost rent, and costs.Â  Taylor answered, alleging: (1) the equitable defense of unclean hands; (2) Mathesoya failed
  to state a claim upon which relief could be granted; and (3) Mathesoya failed
  to mitigate his damages.Â  Additionally, Taylor counterclaimed for breach of
  contract.Â  Mathesoya prevailed at trial and this appeal followed.Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn
  action for breach of contract
  seeking money damages is an action
  at law.â€Â  R & G Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry Regâ€™l
    Transp. Auth., 343 S.C. 424, 430, 540 S.E.2d 113, 117 (Ct. App. 2000).Â 
  Furthermore, the interposition of an equitable defense in an action at law does
  not alter the nature of the action. Â Wright v. Craft, 372 S.C. 1, 19,
  640 S.E.2d 486, 496 (Ct. App. 2006) (internal citation omitted) (â€œ[A]
  distinction should be made between cases in which the defendantâ€™s answer
  asserts merely an equitable defense, and cases in which the answer seeks
  affirmative equitable relief.Â  In the case of an equitable defense, the nature
  of the action remains the same.â€); but see Brown v. Chandler, 50 S.C. 385, 391, 27 S.E. 868, 871 (1897) (holding an equitable defense in a
  legal action receives equity review).
When
  reviewing a judgment made in a law case tried by a master without a jury, the
  appellate court will not disturb the masterâ€™s findings of fact unless the
  findings are found to be without evidence reasonably supporting them.Â  Townes
    Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976); Karl Sitte Plumbing Co. v. Darby Dev. Co. of Columbia, Inc., 295 S.C.
  70, 76-7, 367 S.E.2d 162, 166 (Ct. App. 1988). However, â€œ[a] reviewing court is
  free to decide questions of law with no particular deference to the trial
  court.â€ Hunt v. S.C. Forestry Commâ€™n, 358 S.C. 564, 569, 595 S.E.2d 846,
  848-49 (Ct. App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS

I.  Excessive Damages
Taylor argues
  the master erred by granting monetary relief in excess of the amount prayed for
  in the complaint.Â  Specifically, Taylor argues Mathesoya only prayed for
  damages for lost rent in the amount of $92,682.27; therefore, the master erred
  in awarding $100,718 for these damages.Â  This issue is not preserved for our
review.Â  
â€œIt
  is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but
  must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for
  appellate review.â€Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d
  731, 733 (1998).Â  A party may not argue one set of grounds below and
  alternate grounds on appeal.Â  State
    v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 694 (2003).Â 
  Furthermore, a general, non-specific argument does not necessarily encompass
  the multitude of specific grounds which may support such a broad argument;
  rather a party must actually raise the specific grounds below in order to
  preserve the issue for review.Â  See Collins Entmâ€™t Corp. v. Coats
    & Coats Rental Amusement, 368 S.C. 410, 418, 629 S.E.2d 635,
  639 (2006) (â€œInitially, although American argued there was insufficient
  evidence of excess capacity [of machines] below, it made no argument with
  respect to the specific types of machines at issue.
  Accordingly, as this specific argument was not raised
  below, it is not preserved.â€); State
    v. Fletcher, 363 S.C. 221, 257, 609 S.E.2d 572, 591 (Ct. App. 2005) (internal
  citation omitted) (â€œIt is well settled that an objection must be on a specific
  ground.Â  To be preserved for appellate review, an objection should be sufficiently specific to bring into
  focus the precise nature of the alleged error.â€);Â  Wilder Corp. at 76,
  497 S.E.2d at 733 (â€œ[A]n objection must be sufficiently specific to inform the
  trial court of the point being urged by the objector.â€).Â  
While
  Taylor challenged the excessiveness of the award below both on alternative
  grounds and in a general manner, Taylor failed to specifically argue the masterâ€™s
  award could not exceed the amount prayed for in the complaint.Â  Accordingly,
  this specific argument is not preserved for our review.
II.  Unpaid Rent
Taylor argues
  the master erred in granting Mathesoya eight months of unpaid rent because
  Mathesoyaâ€™s efforts to re-lease the premises were insufficient to mitigate its
damages.Â  We disagree.
â€œA party injured by the acts of another is
  required to do those things a person of ordinary prudence would do under the
  circumstances, but the law does not require him to exert himself unreasonably
  or incur substantial expense to avoid damages.â€Â  Baril
    v. Aiken Regâ€™l Med. Ctrs., 352 S.C. 271, 285, 573 S.E.2d 830, 838 (Ct.
  App. 2002).Â  â€œMoreover, the party who claims damages should have been minimized
  has the burden of proving they could reasonably have been avoided or reduced.â€Â  Moore v. Moore, 360 S.C. 241, 262, 599 S.E.2d 467, 478 (Ct.
  App. 2004).Â  To meet the burden of proof, a tenant must present affirmative evidence
  showing how a landlordâ€™s damages could reasonably have been avoided, or how the
  landlordâ€™s efforts were unreasonable under the circumstances.Â  See Genovese
    v. Bergeron, 327 S.C. 567, 573, 490 S.E.2d 608, 611 (Ct. App. 1997)
  (â€œThe tenant failed to present any evidence showing what types of advertising
  would have been reasonable, how much sooner the landlords could have rented or
  sold the property through other methods, or that the landlordsâ€™ actions to rent
  the property were inadequate or improper. We conclude, therefore, the tenant
  failed to sustain her burden of proving the landlords could have reasonably
  avoided or reduced their damages.â€).
Here, Taylor failed to present any
  affirmative evidence of steps Mathesoya should have taken or that Mathesoyaâ€™s
  efforts were unreasonable under the circumstances.Â  As a result, Taylor failed to meet his burden of proof as a matter of law. Â Additionally, there is
  sufficient evidence in the record to support a conclusion that Mathesoya
  effectively mitigated his damages.Â  Brutschy testified he took multiple steps
  to re-lease the premises, including cleaning the premises, replacing the air
  conditioning units, advertising, replacing carpet, repairing a damaged wall,
  and repainting.Â  Accordingly, the masterâ€™s award of damages for the unpaid rent
  is affirmed.
III.  Mathesoyaâ€™s Installation of
  Carpet in Unit 11 
Taylor argues
  the master erred in granting Mathesoya damages for replacing the carpet in
  areas of Unit 11 because there was no carpet in these areas before he took
  possession of the premises, and the lease agreement did not require
installation of carpet.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
Upon breach of a lease agreement, a landlord may seek
  damages for unpaid rent and â€œsuch special damages as [the landlord] may plead
  and prove to have resulted from the breach.â€Â  Simon v. Kirkpatrick, 141
S.C. 251, 259, 139 S.E. 614, 617 (1927) (citation omitted).Â  
The lease agreement gave Mathesoya ownership of any
  improvements to the premises, including the installation of carpet.Â  Regardless,
  Taylor argues Mathesoya is only entitled to damages for the replacement of the
  carpet which Taylor actually installed and subsequently damaged because the
  lease did not require the entire unit to be carpeted.Â  This argument is
  misplaced because it narrowly focuses on the costs of replacing the carpet as
  damages to Mathesoyaâ€™s property.Â  Brutschy testified the carpet in Unit 11 was
  damaged and had to be replaced to re-let the premises.Â  He also testified areas
  of Unit 11 were uncarpeted due to a display case Taylor had placed in the
  premises.Â  The master specifically found Mathesoya replaced the carpet in Unit
  11 in his efforts to re-let the premises.Â  Taylor failed to address whether the
  cost of the new carpet was an expense incurred in mitigating the damages
  resulting from the breach of the lease agreement.Â  He also failed to provide
  evidence showing Mathesoyaâ€™s efforts to re-let the premises were unreasonable
  or installation of the carpet was an unnecessary expense.Â  Accordingly, there
  is evidence to support the masterâ€™s conclusion Mathesoya was entitled to
  damages for the costs of installing the carpet as an expense incurred in
mitigation of his damages.
IV.  Estoppel
Taylor argues
  he was entitled to rely on assertions that Mathesoya had a replacement tenant; therefore,
  Mathesoya should be estopped from recovering damages.Â  This issue is not
preserved for our review.Â  
â€œ[E]stoppel
  must be affirmatively pled as a defense and cannot be bootstrapped onto another
  claim.â€Â  Collins Entmâ€™t, Inc. v. White, 363 S.C. 546, 562, 611 S.E.2d
  262, 270 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Taylor failed to plead estoppel as an
  affirmative defense.Â  While Taylorâ€™s answer broadly asserted Mathesoya acted
  â€œinequitably and unfairly,â€ we decline to hold such a general assertion
  includes estoppel, a defense which requires a party establish multiple
  elements.[1]Â 
  Likewise, Taylorâ€™s assertion that Mathesoya acted â€œwith unclean handsâ€ is a
  separate defense to which estoppel cannot be â€œbootstrapped.â€Â  As a result, Taylor failed to specifically assert the defense, either by name or through its elements,
  and therefore Taylor failed to raise this issue before the master.Â  
Furthermore,
  even if we assumed, arguendo, Taylor had effectively pled estoppel, the master
  did not rule on the issue in his order, nor did Taylor address it in his 59(e)
  motion to reconsider.Â  Where a trial court does not explicitly rule on an
  argument raised, and the appellant makes no Rule 59(e) motion to obtain a
  ruling, the appellate court may not address the issue.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 460, 535 S.E.2d 438, 444-45 (2000).Â  Accordingly, the
  issue is not preserved for our review.
V.  Abandonment
Taylor argues the
  master erred in finding he abandoned the premises because in actuality he was
  evicted, which is distinguishable from abandonment; therefore, the master
  inappropriately emphasized abandonment as the justification for awarding damages
to Mathesoya.Â  We find no reversible error.Â  
â€œAn
  error not shown to be prejudicial does not constitute grounds for reversal.â€ Â Brown
    v. Pearson, 326 S.C. 409, 417, 483 S.E.2d 477, 481 (Ct. App. 1997). Â â€œAn
  error is not reversible unless it is material and prejudicial to the
  substantial rights of the appellant.â€ Â Visual Graphics Leasing Corp. v.
    Lucia, 311 S.C. 484, 489, 429 S.E.2d 839, 841 (Ct. App. 1993).
While Taylor is correct in his assertion that eviction
  is legally distinguishable from abandonment, the distinction does not have any
  bearing on this case because Mathesoyaâ€™s action is for damages resulting from
  the breach of a lease agreement.Â  Whether the master described the situation as
  abandonment of the premises, abandonment of the lease agreement through
  non-payment of rent, or eviction, Taylor breached the agreement when he failed
  to pay the rent required by the lease, and as a result, Mathesoya incurred
  damages.Â  Therefore, Taylor fails to illustrate how this distinction caused him
  prejudice because any error on the part of the master in describing the
  situation as abandonment of the premises was immaterial to the outcome of the
case.Â  Therefore, there is no reversible error.Â  
VI.  Removal of the Air Conditioning Units 
Taylor argues
  the master erred in granting damages for the replacement of the air
  conditioning units. Â Specifically, Taylor argues he went to great lengths to
  ensure the units would not become fixtures subject to the lease provision
  granting Mathesoya ownership of all fixtures installed on the premises; therefore,
the master erred in awarding damages for replacement units.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
A
  trial judge has considerable discretion regarding the amount of damages, both
  actual or punitive; thus, our review on appeal is limited to the correction of
  errors of law.Â  Mellen v. Lane, 377 S.C. 261, 275-6, 659 S.E.2d 236, 244
  (Ct. App. 2008). Â â€œOur task in reviewing a damages award is not to weigh the
  evidence, but to determine if there is any evidence to support the damages
  award.â€Â  Id.Â  
The
  lease agreement provides the air conditioning units at issue would become the
  property of Mathesoya if they were â€œin any manner attached to the floor, walls
  or ceilings.â€Â  The master found â€œTaylor removed air conditioning equipment
  consisting of two exterior condensers, an interior air handler, and the
  thermostat that had been installed by Taylor as a part of his improvements to the
  leased premisesâ€ and awarded Mathesoya the costs of replacement air
  conditioning equipment.Â  Taylor contends this conclusion was in error, pointing
  to his testimony that the air conditioning units were not attached to
  Mathesoyaâ€™s building, and he purposefully installed the units so they would not
  become Mathesoyaâ€™s property.Â  Additionally, Taylor emphasizes the testimony on
  the subject was not challenged during cross-examination.
Â Mathesoyaâ€™s
  apparent failure to challenge Taylorâ€™s statements on cross-examination does not
  amount to a wholesale admission to such statements, nor does it mean the finder
  of fact was obligated to accept them as true.Â  Additionally, while Taylorâ€™s testimony supports his argument the air conditioning units were not attached to the
  building, there is evidence in the record that supports the conclusion they
  were attached and subject to the provision of the lease agreement.Â  Brutschy
  testified elements of the air conditioning system had been suspended from the
  ceiling, and Taylorâ€™s removal of the system caused damage to the premises.Â 
  Mathesoya provided photographs of the areas where the air conditioning had
  existed, depicting the physical damage caused by the removal of the units.Â 
  Taylor himself testified about the permanent fixtures he used to suspend the components
  of the air conditioning system. Â Accordingly, there is sufficient
  evidence to support a conclusion the air conditioning units were attached to the
  premises, and therefore we affirm the masterâ€™s award of damages for replacement
  units.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the order of the master is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON,
SHORT, and THOMAS JJ., concur.


[1] See Strickland v. Strickland, 375 S.C.
  76, 84-85, 650 S.E.2d 465, 470 (2007) (listing the elements for establishing
  an estoppel defense).Â

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Gloria and
      Johnnie Wright, Appellants,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Social Services, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Fair Hearing Committee
Â Thomas J. Burkizer, Hearing Officer

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-316
Heard April 9, 2008 â€“ Filed June 25, 2008

APPEAL DISMISSED


	
		
			
				Michele R. Krize, of Florence, for Appellants.
				Delton W. Powers, Jr., of Bennettsville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Foster
  parents Gloria and Johnnie Wright (collectively the Wrights) appeal the Fair
  Hearing Committeeâ€™s (Committee) finding that the South Carolina Department of
  Social Services (Department) did not violate the Wrightsâ€™ due process rights by
  removing the Wrightsâ€™ foster child from their home.Â  We dismiss. Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The
  Wrights argue the Committee erred in affirming the Departmentâ€™s decision to
  remove their foster child from their home because substantial evidence did not
  support the Departmentâ€™s decision.Â  We find we lack jurisdiction to hear this
  matter.Â  Consequently, we dismiss.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Â â€œA
  foster parent has the right to appeal . . . the removal of a foster child from
  the foster home.â€Â  27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 114-140(A)(1)(c) (Supp. 2007).Â  The Department, and not the Administrative Law Court
  (ALC), hears appeals from the removal of children from foster homes.Â  27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 114-140(C)(1) (Supp. 2007).Â  After
  an aggrieved party â€œhas exhausted all administrative remedies availableâ€ within
  the Department, he may seek judicial review of the decision.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-380(A) (Supp. 2007).Â  â€œExcept as otherwise provided by law, an
  appeal is to the court of appeals.â€Â  Â§ 1-23-380(A) (emphasis added).Â  â€œAn
  administrative law judge . . . shall preside over all
  appeals from final decisions of contested cases pursuant to the Administrative
  Procedures Act.â€[1]Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-600(D) (Supp. 2007).Â  
The
  Legislatureâ€™s 2006 changes to section 1-23-380(A) of the South Carolina Code
  appear to give the Court of Appeals subject matter jurisdiction to hear this
  appeal.Â  However, as the Department observed, section 1-23-600(D) provides an exception
  to this rule.Â  Under that exception, the ALC has subject matter jurisdiction
  over an appeal of a decision of the Department.Â  Therefore, we lack
  jurisdiction to hear this appeal.[2]Â  
CONCLUSION
An
  appeal from the Departmentâ€™s decision in this matter should be to the ALC.Â 
  Accordingly, this appeal is 
DISMISSED.
HEARN,
C.J., PIEPER, J., and CURETON, A.J., CONCUR.Â  


[1] However, the ALC does not have jurisdiction over
  appeals from the Public Service Commission, the State Ethics Commission, the
  Procurement Review Panel, the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, or the
Employment Security Commission.Â  
[2] We note that since his removal from the Wrightsâ€™
  home, Child has bonded with another foster parent whom the Department approved
  to adopt Child.Â  By order dated June 2, 2008, the family court granted the
  adoption.Â  Consequently, were we to review this matter on the merits, we would
  nevertheless dismiss it as moot.Â  See Curtis v. State, 345 S.C.
  557, 567, 549 S.E.2d 591, 596 (2001) (appellate court will not consider moot
questions).Â

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Barry D. Mallek
      and Alice R. Mallek, Respondents,
				v.
				Delbert R.
      Tangeman, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Gordon G. Cooper, Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-317
Submitted June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed June 25,
2008Â Â Â  

REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Delbert R. Tangeman, of Duncan, for Appellant.
				Donald C. Coggins, Jr., Max Thomas Hyde, and Jack W. Lawrence, all
  of Spartanburg, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Subsequent
  to a supplemental proceeding, Delbert Tangeman (Tangeman) appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s
  order setting aside the transfer of real property from Tangeman to his wife as
  a fraudulent transfer.Â  We reverse and remand.[1] 
FACTS
Barry and Alice Mallek (the Malleks) received
  a general verdict against Tangeman following a jury trial in June 2002, which
  was affirmed by this court on January 14, 2005.Â  The Malleks sought to execute
  on the judgment against Tangeman; however, the execution was returned nulla
  bona on or about June 13, 2005.Â  
Thereafter,
  the Malleks sought an order of reference and rule to show cause for supplemental
  proceedings.Â  A supplemental proceeding was held before the master-in-equity on
  August 1, 2005.Â  During the hearing, Tangeman indicated that his business
  assets, as well as numerous pieces of real estate, had been transferred to his
  wife.Â  Tangeman did not have the documents regarding the transfers at the time
  of the hearing; thus, the hearing was adjourned and Tangeman was ordered to produce
  the relevant documents at a later date.Â  
The
  hearing was reconvened on January 17, 2006.Â  At the hearing, Tangeman returned
  to the stand and answered questions regarding the documents.Â  The documents
  included mortgage notes dated August 1, 1998, in the amounts of $20,000,
  $30,000, and $150,000.[2]Â 
  The mortgages securing these notes, although dated August 1, 1998, were
  notarized and recorded on April 26, 2000.Â  This date correlates to a document
  presented by Tangeman wherein he had transferred all of his assets, including
  all of his real estate, household furniture, construction business vehicles,
  equipment, and tools to his wife on April 25, 2000.Â  Tangeman testified that
  valid consideration for the transfers was given by his wife who, in addition to
  her personal service as secretary without compensation, had invested sums of
  money from her inheritance and otherwise into his business over the years. Â He
  also stated that a written agreement reflecting any obligation for repayment
  from either himself or from his business was not executed.Â  
At the
  close of the hearing, the Malleks asked the master-in-equity to set aside the
  transfers as fraudulent conveyances under the Statute of Elizabeth.Â  At this
  time, Tangeman requested an opportunity to enter into evidence documents which he
  alleged would prove the transfers were not fraudulent.Â  The master-in-equity
  refused and the following colloquy ensued:

	TANGEMAN:Â  Your Honor?
	THE COURT:Â  Yes, sir.
	TANGEMAN:Â  Donâ€™t I get an opportunity to - - -
	THE COURT:Â  Your opportunity was a long time ago.Â  You are here at the direction and the request to appear by [c]ounsel in an
  attempt to locate funds to pay his clientâ€™s judgment.Â  The issues relating to
  any other matters were tried in a caseÂ  - - -
	TANGEMAN:Â  They were - - -
	THE COURT:Â  In 2001 and those are not here.Â  Today, the only reason
  I am here, or the only reason we are here and I am hearing this, is to assist Mr. Coggins in having
  his client recover the money that was found to be due from you to
  the Malleks.
	TANGEMAN:Â 
  Your Honor, there are two very important documents that Mr. Coggins is not present
  here today.
	THE
  COURT:Â  Well, again - - - Excuse me, sir.
	TANGEMAN:Â 
  And they have been presented in the past.
	THE COURT:Â  Excuse me.Â  Mr. Coggins is handling his case for his
  client.Â  Now whether in his presentation he decided not to include documents,
  that is solely up to him.Â  But you are not handling his case and the sole
  purpose you are here today is to try to find funds to pay his clientâ€™s
  judgment.
	TANGEMAN:Â 
  There are two - - -
	THE
  COURT:Â  I understand.
	TANGEMAN:Â 
  There are two - - -
	THE
  COURT:Â  You didnâ€™t - - - You didnâ€™t hear me.
	TANGEMAN:Â 
  Yes, I did.
	THE COURT:Â  Alright.Â  And so that is the - - - That is the end of
  the conversation.
	TANGEMAN:Â 
  So I cannot make a motion?
	THE COURT:Â  No, you cannot.Â  If you want to have an attorney file
  some type of motion on your behalf, then you are welcome to do that.Â  Once the [o]rder
  has been signed, then if there is grounds for filing a motion or any type of
  responsive pleading, then the attorney would have to review the [o]rder that I
  have signed and at that point the [o]rder is subject to whatever attack that
  can be done.Â  But until then - - -
	TANGEMAN:Â  There have been two - - - May I share the two documents
  that are in evidence and that are not - - -
	THE COURT:Â  They are not.Â  The only evidence are here and I have
  reviewed these documents as they were handed up.
	TANGEMAN:Â  Okay.
	THE COURT:Â  Thereâ€™s eleven documents that were presented by Mr.
  Coggins during your testimony.
	TANGEMAN:Â  There is one side of that page that you have not
  considered, Your Honor.
	THE COURT:Â  I have looked at every document.
	TANGEMAN:Â  No, sir.Â  You have not.Â  It is on the back side of that
  one mortgage.
	THE COURT:Â  I have - Sir, I have looked at every document as it
  was handed up and Iâ€™ve looked at the dates.Â  Iâ€™ve looked at all the recording
  information and everything that is on the documents.
	TANGEMAN:Â  There is a [o]ne hundred fifty thousand ($150,000) [d]ollar
  mortgage that preceded all of these dates and it is in evidence.
	THE COURT:Â  I understand that.Â  I understand that.
	TANGEMAN:Â  And it will clearly take care of any fraudulent
  claims.Â  It is clearly - - -
	THE COURT:Â  Well, sir, I am not meaning to cut you short, but I
  am.Â  If, after the [o]rder is entered, you have an attorney who wants to file
  some type of motion relating to the [o]rder, then that is the time to do it.Â 
  Alright, sir?
	TANGEMAN:Â  Yes, sir.

Shortly after
  this exchange, the hearing concluded.Â  In the final order, the master-in-equity
  set aside the transfer of Tangemanâ€™s property to his wife as a fraudulent
  conveyance and appointed a receiver over all of his business and real estate
  properties until the Malleksâ€™ judgment was paid in full.Â  
Tangeman
  filed a motion to reconsider claiming he was not provided an opportunity to
  prove the transfers were valid and requested the master-in-equity consider
  certain documents he was not allowed to present at the hearing.Â  The master-in-equity
  denied Tangemanâ€™s motion. Â This appeal follows. Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Supplementary proceedings
  are equitable in nature.Â  Ag-Chem Equip. Co., Inc. v. Daggerhart, 281
  S.C. 380, 383, 315 S.E.2d 379, 381 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  In an equitable matter
  referred to a master-in-equity for final judgment, we may find facts in
  accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Van
    Blarcum v. City of North Myrtle Beach, 337 S.C. 446, 450, 523 S.E.2d 486,
  488 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  However, this court is not required to disregard the
  findings of the master-in-equity.Â  Friarsgate, Inc. v. First Fed. Sav. &
    Loan Assâ€™n, 317 S.C. 452, 456, 454 S.E.2d 901, 904 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  
The admissibility
  of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be
  reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error
  resulting in prejudice to the defendant. Â Wright v. Craft, 372 S.C. 1,
  33, 640 S.E.2d 486, 504 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when
  the ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion that is without
  evidentiary support.â€Â  Menne v. Keowee Key Prop. Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n, Inc.,
  368 S.C. 557, 568, 629 S.E.2d 690, 696 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  â€œTo warrant reversal
  based on the admission or exclusion of evidence, the appellant must prove both
  the error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice.â€Â  Fields v. Regâ€™l Med.
    Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Tangeman argues the
  denial by the master-in-equity of his request to present evidence of a valid
  conveyance was error.Â  We agree. 
The
  Statute of Elizabeth, as codified in section 27-23-10 of the South Carolina
  Code (Supp. 2007), provides in relevant part: 

	Every .
  . . conveyance of lands . . . which may be had or made to or for any intent or purpose
  to delay, hinder, or defraud creditors and others of their just and lawful . .
  . debts . . . must be deemed and taken . . . to be clearly and utterly void,
  frustrate and of no effect, any pretense, color, feigned consideration,
  expressing of use, or any other matter or thing to the contrary
  notwithstanding. 

Pursuant to this
  statute, conveyances may be set aside under two conditions: (1) where the
  transfer is made by the grantor with the actual intent of defrauding his
  creditors where that intent is imputable to the grantee, even though there is
  valuable consideration; and (2) where a transfer is made without actual intent
  to defraud the grantorâ€™s creditors, but without valuable consideration.Â  See Albertson v. Robinson, 371 S.C. 311, 316, 638 S.E.2d 81, 83 (Ct. App.
  2006). Â Where a conveyance is made without an actual intent to defraud but
  without consideration, the conveyance will stand if the grantor reserves a
  sufficient amount of property not merely at the time of the transfer, but an
  amount from which in the final analysis the creditors are able to collect their
  indebtedness in full.Â  Gardner v. Kirven, 184 S.C. 37, 41, 191
  S.E. 814, 816 (1937).Â  Moreover, â€œ[w]here transfers to members of the family
  are attacked either upon the ground of actual fraud or on account of their
  voluntary character, the law imposes the burden on the transferee to
  establish both a valuable consideration and the bona fides of the transaction by
  clear and convincing testimony.â€ Â Id. (emphasis added).Â  
In
  this case, the alleged fraudulent conveyance was between family members; thus, the
  burden to establish valuable consideration and the bona fides of the transaction
  was imposed upon the transferee.Â  See Id.Â  Â However, the
  transferee, Tangemanâ€™s wife, was not a party to the proceeding at issue.[3] Moreover, not only was the transferee not a party to the proceeding, but Tangeman
  himself was also denied the opportunity to introduce documentary evidence and
  to present an argument as to the validity of the transfer. Â Review of the
  record indicates the master-in-equity stated that the Malleks had exclusive
  control over the presentation of the case and Tangemanâ€™s involvement was
  limited solely to responding to their questions on direct examination.Â  The
  record further reveals that Tangeman sought to present testimony in response to
  the Malleksâ€™ presentation on direct examination and was repeatedly denied the
  opportunity.Â  The master-in-equity erred by precluding Tangeman the opportunity
  to present his position as to the validity of the transfer.Â  Moreover, we
  further express concern that the master-in-equity clearly stated that Tangeman
  may only respond by having an attorney file some motion after the issuance of
  the courtâ€™s order.[4]Â 
  We find Tangemanâ€™s inability to present his position prejudiced him.Â  
Therefore,
  we conclude a remand is appropriate to allow for a hearing in which Tangeman is
  provided an opportunity to address the validity of the transfer.[5]Â 
  Accordingly, we find it unnecessary to address Tangemanâ€™s remaining issues and
  arguments.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C.
  406, 423, 526 S.E.2d 716, 725 (2005) (holding that the court need not address
  additional issues if it is not necessary to the resolution of the case). Â 
Based
  on our reasoning herein, the decision of the master-in-equity is Â 
REVERSED AND
  REMANDED. 
WILLIAMS,
THOMAS, and PIEPER, JJ., concur. 


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Tangeman also produced his 2001 and 2002 Federal
  income tax returns, which list â€œDelbert Tangemanâ€ as the sole proprietor of his
  building contracting business.Â  The returns also indicated income received from
rental property in the names of both Tangeman and his wife.Â  
[3] We recognize the issue as to the transferee not being
  named as a party was not raised; therefore, we focus only on the decision to
preclude Tangeman from addressing the validity of the transfer.
[4] As to the Malleksâ€™ argument that Tangeman failed to
  proffer the documents into the record, the record clearly shows the futility of
  further attempts to preserve Tangemanâ€™s desire to introduce these documents in
  light of the comments of the master-in-equity.Â  See Staubes v. City
    of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 415, 529 S.E.2d 543, 547 (2000) (noting that
  this court does not require parties to engage in futile actions in order to
  preserve issues for appellate review).Â  Moreover, since the master-in-equity
  specifically indicated that Tangeman could only further address the court by
  way of post trial motion, we find Tangeman has preserved his arguments because
  he complied with the courtâ€™s specific instructions by way of a motion to
  reconsider.Â  Thus, in light of the courtâ€™s specific directions, we decline to
find Tangemanâ€™s arguments unpreserved.Â Â  
[5] On remand, consideration should be given as to
  whether the case should be postured as a declaratory judgment or other
  independent action and whether Tangemanâ€™s wife, as transferee, should be added
as a party.

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this action for breach of contract, Bernie Oâ€™Reilly appeals the trial courtâ€™s
  order granting respondentâ€™s motion for a new trial nisi remittitur.Â  
We affirm[1] the order of the trial court pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the
  following authorities: Weaver v. Lentz, 348 S.C. 672, 682, 561 S.E.2d 360,
  365 (Ct. App. 2002) (the trial court has wide discretionary power to reduce the
  amount of a verdict which it finds to be excessive);Â  Chapman v. Upstate RV
    & Marine, 364 S.C. 82, 88-89, 610 S.E.2d 852, 856 (Ct. App. 2005) (the
  grant or denial of new trial motion rests within the discretion of the trial
  court, and its decision will not be disturbed on appeal unless the findings are

  not have taken the same approach, we cannot say that the trial court abused its
  discretion because the nature and extent of the partiesâ€™ agreement was at issue

Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

      Department of Social Services, Respondent,
				v.
				Terrie C. and
      Clyde L., Defendants, of whom Clyde L. is Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Anderson County
Â Barry W. Knobel, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-319
Submitted June 23, 2008 â€“ Filed June 25,
2008

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Beth M. Harbin, of Piedmont, for Appellant.
				Dottie C. Ingram, of Anderson, for Respondent.
				John M. Oâ€™Rourke, of Anderson; Tara S. Taggart, of Blythewood, for
  Guardian Ad Litem.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: This
  appeal arises from the termination of parental rights (TPR) of Clyde L.
  (Father).Â  Father argues the family court erred in terminating his parental
  rights because 1) DSS failed to prove a
  statutory ground for removal enumerated in section 20-7-1572 of the South
  Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) by clear and convincing evidence and 2) DSS failed
  to prove termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights was in the Childrenâ€™s best
  interest.Â  
1.Â  We affirm the family
  courtâ€™s finding Childrenâ€™s presence in foster care for fifteen of the most
  recent twenty-two months amounts to a statutory ground for TPR.Â  See S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§20-7-1572(8) (Supp. 2007); Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Jackson, 368 S.C. 87, 101-02, 627 S.E.2d 765, 773-74
  (Ct. App. 2006) (finding the statutory ground of fifteen out of twenty-two
  months was met during appellant-fatherâ€™s incarceration, despite the fact DSS
  never contacted him or gave him an opportunity to suggest relatives with whom
  his son might be placed); Jackson, 368 S.C. 87, 102, 627 S.E.2d 765, 773
  (holding the appellate court is concerned with the childâ€™s perspective and not
  the parentâ€™s when determining whether a statutory ground is met); S.C. Depâ€™t
    of Soc. Servs. v. Sims, 359 S.C. 601, 608, 598 S.E.2d 303, 307 (Ct. App. 2004)
  (â€œA finding pursuant to section 20-7-1572(8) alone is sufficient to support a
  termination of parental rights.â€).Â  
2.Â  Based on Childrenâ€™s
  mental and emotional progress, as well as their favorable living situation, we
  agree with the Guardian ad Litem and family court and find TPR in Childrenâ€™s
  best interest.Â  Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. King,
  369 S.C. 96, 105, 631 S.E.2d 239, 244 (2006) (â€œ[W]hen the interest of the child
  and the parental rights conflict, the interest of the child shall prevail.â€).
AFFIRMED.[1]
HEARN, C.J., THOMAS, J., and CURETON, A.J. 


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


	
		
			
				In the Matter
      of the Estate 
				of India B. Hendricks
				
				Carl C.
      Hendricks, Jr., Appellant,
				v.
				William P.
      Hendricks, Individually, and as Joint Personal Representative of the Estate
      of India B. Hendricks, and Carol H. Waters, Individually, and as Joint
      Personal Representative of the Estate of India B. Hendricks, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Special Circuit Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-320
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 25,
2008

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Barry L. Johnson and Jason W. Ward, both of Okatie, for Appellant.
				Harley D. Ruff and Carol C. Ruff, both of Beaufort, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this action involving the probate of a will, Carl C. Hendricks (Carl) challenges
  the validity of his motherâ€™s will and seeks to set aside the probate of the will.Â 
  On appeal from the decision of the circuit court affirming the probate court, Carl
  argues the probate court erred in excluding testimony from an expert witness.Â 
  He also argues the probate court erred in excluding the proffer of an
  incapacitated fact witness and in denying his motion to extend the record.Â  He further
  contends the probate court erred in denying his motion to exhume his motherâ€™s
  body.Â  We affirm.[1]Â Â  
FACTS
On April 23,
  2002, Carlâ€™s mother, India B. Hendricks (Decedent), passed away in Beaufort County.Â  Decedent was survived by her three adult children: Carl C. Hendricks,
  Jr., William P. Hendricks, and Carol H. Waters.Â  On March 24, 1997, Decedent
  executed her last will and testament wherein she appointed Carol and William as
  joint personal representatives of her Estate.Â  Further, Decedent left $150,000
  to Carl, and instructed that the remainder of the Estate, which Decedent
  estimated was worth approximately $3 million at the time she executed her will,
  be split equally between William and Carol.
After Decedentâ€™s
  death, William and Carol (collectively the Estate), petitioned the probate
  court to be appointed as the personal representatives of the Estate and
  requested an informal probate of their motherâ€™s will.Â  Thereafter, on December
  19, 2002, Carl petitioned the probate court, challenging the validity of the
  will and seeking to set aside the informal probate of the will.Â  Specifically,
  Carl believed Decedent suffered from Alzheimerâ€™s disease and other
  incapacitating mental diseases for a number of years prior to her execution of
  the will.Â  Carl alleged the will was invalid because Decedent lacked the requisite
  mental capacity when she executed the will.
After extended
  discovery, the parties entered into a scheduling order, which the probate court
  extended several times.Â  Shortly before trial, Carl wrote the Estate and
  disclosed a new expert, Dr. T. Ray Sherbert (Dr. Sherbert), and provided a copy
  of the expertâ€™s affidavit.Â  In response, the Estate filed a motion in limine to
  preclude Dr. Sherbert from testifying as an expert witness, arguing the
  disclosure occurred twelve days prior to trial and more than two months past
  the extended deadline for expert witness disclosure.Â  The probate court granted
  the Estateâ€™s motion in limine.Â  
At trial,
  Carl examined eleven witnesses, including a previously disclosed expert
  witness, Dr. Edward McNeil.Â  At the conclusion of Carlâ€™s case, the probate
  court granted the Estateâ€™s motion for a directed verdict as to Carlâ€™s claim for
  undue influence.Â  After the Estate rested, Carl moved to extend the record of
  trial to include the deposition of Eugene Robinson, a proposed witness who was
  hospitalized during the trial and unable to appear on Carlâ€™s behalf.Â  After
  receiving a proffer of Robinsonâ€™s proposed testimony, the probate court denied
  Carlâ€™s motion to extend the record.Â  
The probate court found Decedent had the requisite mental capacity
  to execute a valid will and denied Carlâ€™s motions to extend the record to allow
  testimony from Eugene Robinson and to exhume Decedentâ€™s body in order to
  perform an autopsy. Â The circuit court affirmed the judgment of the probate
  court.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An
  action to contest a will is an action at law.Â  In re Estate of Cumbee, 333
  S.C. 664, 670, 511 S.E.2d 390, 393 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  If a proceeding in the probate
  court is in the nature of an action at law, review by the circuit court and appellate
  court extends merely to the correction of errors of law.Â  Bob Jones Univ. v. Strandell, 344 S.C. 224, 230, 543 S.E.2d 251, 253 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Furthermore,
  the circuit court and appellate court may not disturb the probate courtâ€™s
  findings of fact unless they are not supported by the evidence.Â  Cumbee,
  333 S.C. at 670, 511 S.E.2d at 393.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

Carl argues the
  probate courtâ€™s exclusion of Dr. Sherbert as an expert witness was in error.Â  Carl
  further contends the exclusion of Dr. Sherbertâ€™s testimony resulted in
  prejudice.Â  We disagree.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Pursuant to Rule
  33(b) SCRCP, there is a continuing duty on the part of the party from whom
  information is sought to answer a standard interrogatory, such as the one
  requesting the party to list any expert witnesses whom the party proposes to
  use as a witness at the trial of the case.Â  Bensch v. Davidson, 354 S.C.
  173, 182, 580 S.E.2d 128, 132 (2003).Â  This requirement of disclosure of
  information before trial is established to avoid surprise and to promote
  decisions on the merits after a full and fair hearing.Â  Id. at 182, 580
  S.E.2d at 132-33.Â  When a violation of Rule 33 occurs, the trial court has
  discretion to impose a sanction upon the violating party, such as the exclusion
  of a witness, if warranted.Â  Id.Â  Â In Jumper v. Hawkins, 348 S.C.
  142, 558 S.E.2d 911 (Ct. App. 2001), this court addressed the authority of a
  trial court to exclude the testimony of an expert.Â  The court in Jumper held the trial court is required to consider and evaluate the following factors
  before imposing the sanction of exclusion of a witness:Â  

	(1) the
  type of witness involved; (2) the content of the evidence emanating from the
  proffered witness; (3) the nature of the failure or neglect or refusal to
  furnish the witnessâ€™ name; (4) the degree of surprise to the other party,
  including the prior knowledge of the name of the witness; and (5) the prejudice
  to the opposing party. 

Id. at 152, 558 S.E.2d at 916.Â  
Application of the factors established in Jumper are essential to a determination of abuse of discretion as â€œthe sanction of
  exclusion of a witness should never be lightly invoked.â€Â  Barnette v. Adams
    Bros. Logging, Inc., 355 S.C. 588, 592, 586 S.E.2d 572, 574 (2003).Â  In Barnette,
  the South Carolina Supreme Court noted the importance of satisfying the Jumper factors in finding the trial court abused its discretion in excluding expert witnesses
  where there was no specific finding of the factor of prejudice to the opposing
  counsel other than necessity of further discovery and there was no disobedience
  of any order of the court.Â  Id. at 593, 586 S.E.2d at 575.Â  Similarly, in Arthur v. Sexton Dental Clinic, this court emphasized the importance of
  the Jumper factors in affirming the trial courtâ€™s sanction where,
  although not specifically enunciated, the trial court properly considered each
  of the factors.Â  368 S.C. 326, 628 S.E.2d 894 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  The Arthur court held the trial court properly excluded the testimony of three expert
  witnesses after making the appropriate inquiry and upon consideration of the
  requisite factors following an in-depth instruction on the Jumper factors from counsel.Â  Id. at 341, 628 S.E.2d at 902. 
As a
  threshold matter, we note that Carl failed to name Dr. Sherbert as an expert
  witness within the time limits established by the probate courtâ€™s amended
  scheduling order.Â  Given Carlâ€™s failure to comply with the scheduling order,
  the probate court had the discretionary authority to impose the appropriate
  sanctions if warranted.Â  See Arthur, 368 S.C. at 338, 628 S.E.2d
  at 901.Â  Thus, the question before this court is whether the probate court
  abused its discretion in excluding Dr. Sherbert as an expert witness.Â  See id.; see also Jumper, 348 S.C. at 150, 558 S.E.2d at 915
  (internal citation omitted) (stating â€œ[t]he decision of whether or not to allow
  a witness to testify who was not previously listed on answers to
  interrogatories rests within the sound discretion of the trial [court].â€). Â 
We
  believe the probate court properly considered the factors set forth in Jumper and find the probate court did not abuse its discretion in excluding Dr.
  Sherbertâ€™s testimony. Â The probate court did not lightly invoke its sanction of
  expert witness exclusion.Â  Rather, it imposed such a sanction after several
  extensions to the scheduling order.Â  Additionally, the probate court discussed
  each factor in depth in its order granting the Estateâ€™s motion in limine.Â  
As
  to the first factor, the probate court noted Carl proposed to use Dr. Sherbert
  as an expert witness at trial.Â  However, the probate court also outlined Carlâ€™s
  trial history regarding use of experts such as Dr. Geoffrey R. McKee, a
  forensic psychologist, who was â€œabsolutely necessary to [Carlâ€™s] caseâ€; the
  court cited another occasion, where Appellant stated, aside from Dr. Edward
  McNeil, Carl â€œdoes not now plan to use Dr. McKee as an expert witness.â€Â  Under
  the second factor of Jumper, the probate court recognized Dr. Sherbertâ€™s
  proffered testimony would demonstrate his opinion on Decedentâ€™s mental and
  physical conditions.[2]Â 
  In weighing this factor, the probate court stated Dr. Sherbertâ€™s opinion â€œwould
  be based on his review of medical records generated by others, and on his
  consultations with [Carl].â€Â  
As to the third
  factor, the probate court considered Carlâ€™s failure to furnish Dr. Sherbertâ€™s
  name as a proposed expert witness by noting the prolonged schedule of the trial
  and the prior extensions granted to Carl.Â  Carl first disclosed Dr. Sherbertâ€™s name on April 13, 2005, twelve days before trial
  and over two months past the already extended deadline for expert witness
  disclosure.Â  In addition, the probate court granted Carlâ€™s motion to extend the
  scheduling order from December 30, 2004, until February 1, 2005.Â  Moreover,
  Carl had previously indicated he did not plan on using any expert witnesses other
  than Dr. McNeil.Â  Noting that the time
  for disclosing experts had passed, the probate court stated that allowing Carl
  to proffer Dr. Sherbertâ€™s testimony would place Respondents with â€œthe
  unreasonable burden of choosing either to go to trial inadequately prepared, or
  to request a postponement of a trial that has already been delayed twice over
  their strenuous objections.â€Â  The probate court further described the late disclosure
  as â€œlast minuteâ€ under the third factor in Jumper.Â  
Under
  the fourth factor in Jumper, the probate court noted, â€œ[I]t appears that
  the April 13 disclosure of the proposed use of Dr. Sherbert as a witness took [the
  Estate] completely by surprise, thus compounding substantially the prejudice
  factor addressed below.â€Â  Finally, the probate court noted Carlâ€™s late
  furnishing of Dr. Sherbertâ€™s name as a witness prejudiced the Estate by further
  delaying trial, providing inadequate time for trial preparation, and adding personal
  distress from another protraction of litigation.Â  
Therefore,
  the probate court properly considered the factors set forth in Jumper in
  its decision to exclude Dr. Sherbert as an expert witness.Â  Additionally, we
  find no error in the sanction based on Carlâ€™s conduct.Â  We further note that
  Carl presented at trial an expert witness, Dr. McNeil, who testified at length.
  Â Dr. McNeil who, unlike Dr. Sherbert, had a doctor-patient relationship with
  the Decedent, testified that he had no concerns about Decedentâ€™s mental
  capacity until an event of transient amnesia that lasted only a short duration
  in December 1997 and a diagnosis of â€œprogressive dimentiaâ€ in January 1998.Â  Again,
  this medical concern arose after the execution of the will. 
Dr.
  Sherbert proffered testimony suggesting the Decedent may have suffered from some
  form of mental condition. Â However, Dr. Sherbert testified that he could not
  make this finding without an autopsy.Â  While we note the relevance of this
  testimony, we nonetheless conclude that the probate court did not abuse its
  discretion in light of the multiple continuances previously granted in this
  case.Â  We further note that Dr. Sherbert himself indicated that an autopsy by a
  forensic pathologist would be the most definitive means to confirm any
  diagnosis of Alzheimerâ€™s disease.Â  While Carl originally designated Dr. McKee,
  a forensic psychologist, to testify, that expert was not able to
  complete a report in time and Carl made the decision to proceed without a
  forensic psychologist. Â Carl made a voluntary decision to proceed with
  the testimony of Dr. McNeil only. Â Unless Dr. McKee qualifies, it is not clear
  that a forensic pathologist was ever named.Â  Accordingly, we cannot say
  the probate court abused its discretion; therefore, we affirm the circuit court
  in upholding the ruling of the probate court on this issue.[3]
Next, Carl argues the probate court erred in denying
  his motion to extend the
  record to include the deposition of
  Eugene Robinson.Â  We find no error. 
The
  decision whether to reopen a record for additional evidence is within the trial
  courtâ€™s sound discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of
  that discretion.Â  Brenco v. South Carolina Dept. of Transp., 659 S.E.2d
  167 (2008); Wright v. Strickland, 306 S.C. 187, 188, 410 S.E.2d 596, 597
  (Ct. App. 1991).Â  Furthermore, the trial judge is endowed with considerable
  latitude and discretion in allowing a party to reopen a case.Â  Spinx Oil
    Co., Inc. v. Fed. Mut. Ins. Co., 310 S.C. 477, 482, 427 S.E.2d 649, 651
  (1993), overruled on other grounds, Joe Harden Builders, Inc. v. Aetna Cas. and Sur. Co., 326 S.C. 231, 486 S.E.2d 89 (1997). Â 
The
  probate court denied Carlâ€™s request to hold open the trial record so Carl could
  supplement the record with Robinsonâ€™s deposition.Â  In so holding, the probate
  court noted Carl, a litigant in the matter, interviewed the witness himself.Â 
  The probate court described the proffer as â€œthe product of a private
  conversation between [Carl] and the prospective witness and with the transcript
  solely prepared by [Carl].â€Â  Additionally, the probate court was concerned with
  the manner in which Robinsonâ€™s proffer was prepared and â€œthe obvious number of
  holes in [Carlâ€™s] case, that [the proffer] conveniently attempts to plug.â€Â 
  Furthermore, the probate court stated another concern was that â€œthe ultimate
  result of this is to taint this witnessâ€™ prospective testimony.â€Â  In
  conclusion, the probate court held the prejudice that could result in such a
  delay is not outweighed by any possible benefit of his testimony.Â  Based on
  this decision, the probate court denied Carlâ€™s request to hold open the record
  so it could possibly be supplemented with the deposition of Robinson.Â  We find
  the probate court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to extend the trial
  after weighing Robinsonâ€™s proffer with the possible prejudice to the Estate
  pursuant to Rule 403, SCRE.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court did not err in
  affirming the decision of the probate court.
CONCLUSION
For
  the foregoing reasons, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS, J.,
  THOMAS, J., and PIEPER, J., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The probate court referred to Carlâ€™s letter as well
  as Dr. Sherbertâ€™s letter and affidavit in identifying the content of his
proposed testimony.Â  
[3] Carl also argues on appeal that the probate court
  erred in denying his motion to exhume Decedentâ€™s body in order to determine
  Decedentâ€™s mental capacity at the time she executed her will.Â  Specifically,
  Carl argues an autopsy of Decedentâ€™s body would either confirm or discredit Dr.
  Sherbertâ€™s opinion.Â  Our decision to affirm the circuit court in affirming the
  probate courtâ€™s exclusion of Dr. Sherbert as an expert witness is dispositive
  of Carlâ€™s third issue on appeal.Â  Therefore, we need not address it on the
  merits.Â  Even if we were to address the issue, we find it is without merit.Â 
  The probate court determined Decedentâ€™s testamentary capacity was established
  by sufficient evidence, and accordingly, the extraordinary measure of
  exhumation and autopsy is unwarranted.Â  In re Percivalâ€™s Estate, 101
  S.C. 198, 206, 85 S.E. 247, 248 (1915) (â€œ[E]xhumation ought not to be made
  except upon the most serious consideration.â€).Â  Furthermore, at issue was
  whether Decedent was of sound mind on March 24, 1997, the date she executed her
will, rather than the date of her death.Â

THIS

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				State of South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
				v.
				Rebecca M.,
      David M., Defendants, Of Whom David M. is the Appellant.
				In the interests
  of: Female Child DOB: 7/21/95; Female Child DOB: 5/11/96;Â  both minors under
  the age of 18.
			
		
	


Appeal From Florence County
Â William J. Wylie, Jr., Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-321
Submitted June 26, 2008 â€“ Filed June 27,
  2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				David B. Betts, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Newton I. Howle, Jr., of Darlington, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: David
  M. appeals a family court order issued
  subsequent to an intervention hearing.Â  After
  a thorough review of the record pursuant
  to Ex Parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354 S.E.2d 381 (1987) and S.C. Depâ€™t
    of Soc. Servs. v. Frederick Downer, Sr., S.C.Sup.Ct. Order dated February
  2, 2005 (expanding the procedure set forth in Cauthen to situations
  where an indigent person appeals from an order imposing other measures short of
  termination of parental rights), we
  affirm the family courtâ€™s ruling.
AFFIRMED.[1]
HEARN,

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Anne T.
      Persons, Appellant,
				v.
				South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles, Henry McMaster, in
      his official capacity as the Attorney General of the state of South Carolina,
      and the State of South Carolina, Defendants,
				of whom South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles is Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
James R. Barber, III, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-322
Heard June 6, 2008 - Filed June 27, 2008  
Withdrawn and Substituted September 4,
  2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Desa Ballard and P. Christopher Smith, Jr., of West Columbia, for
  Appellant.
				Frank L. Valenta, Jr., and Philip S. Porter, of Blythewood, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Anne
  T. Persons (Persons) argues the circuit court erred in finding no legal
  conflict exists between the administrative stay provisions of South Carolina Code
  Ann. sections 56-1-365(F) and 56-1-430 (2006), which govern the suspension of a
  driverâ€™s license, and the criminal stay provision of South Carolina Code Ann. section
  18-1-70 (1976), which governs the execution of a judicially-imposed criminal
  sentence.
We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following
  authorities: State v. Price, 333 S.C. 267, 271-72, 510 S.E.2d 215, 218
  (1998) (stating suspension of a license is non-punitive and non-criminal in
  nature and does not constitute a criminal penalty for purposes of double
  jeopardy); Yeargin v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 313
  S.C. 387, 390, 438 S.E.2d 234, 235 (1993) (explaining suspension of a license
  following a conviction for driving under the influence is not considered part
  of the punishment for the offense and recognizing mandatory revocation of a
  driverâ€™s license without an administrative hearing does not violate due process
  when there has been a prior hearing and conviction on the criminal charge
  causing the revocation); Brewer v. S.C. Highway Depâ€™t, 261 S.C. 52, 57,
  198 S.E.2d 256, 258 (1973) (holding the
  administrative suspension of a license is â€œa forfeiture of the privilege to
  driveâ€); Parker v. State Highway Depâ€™t, 224 S.C. 263, 271, 78 S.E.2d 382, 385 (1953)
  (holding a driverâ€™s license suspension is not part of the punishment fixed by
  the court, nor is it an added punishment for the criminal offense committed, as
  it is civil and not criminal in nature); Taylor v. S.C. Depâ€™t
    of Motor Vehicles, 368 S.C. 33, 36,
  627 S.E.2d 751, 753 (Ct. App. 2006) cert. granted, (Aug. 9, 2007)
  (citing Sponar v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 361 S.C. 35, 39, 603 S.E.2d
  412, 415 (Ct. App. 2004)) (holding a driverâ€™s license is not a property right
  but is a mere privilege subject to reasonable regulations in the interest of public safety and welfare); Page v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Pub.
    Safety, 329 S.C. 166, 169,
  495 S.E.2d 220, 222 (Ct. App. 1997) (implicitly holding administrative
  suspensions are independent of criminal sentences); see also S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 56-1-300 (2006) (stating the Department of Motor Vehicles may suspend or
  revoke a driverâ€™s license without a preliminary hearing when records or other
  sufficient evidence demonstrates the licensee has been convicted of an offense
  requiring mandatory revocation or suspension upon conviction); S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  56-1-400 (2006 & Supp. 2007) (indicating the purely administrative nature
  of a driverâ€™s license suspension and restoration by stating â€œ[t]he Department
  of Motor Vehicles, upon suspending or revoking a license, shall require that
  such license shall be surrendered to the Department of Motor Vehiclesâ€ and â€œ[t]he
  Department of Motor Vehicles shall not . . . restore a license which has been
  suspended for . . . driving under the influence of intoxicants . . . until the
  person has filed an application for a new license, submitted to an examination
  as upon an original application, and has satisfied the Department of Motor
  Vehicles . . . that it would be safe to grant [the licensee] the privilege of
  driving a motor vehicle on the public highwaysâ€). 
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS, THOMAS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Keith Rochester
      d/b/a Rochester Cab Company and South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund, Defendants,
				v.
				Arthur G.
      Roberts (deceased), Appellant,
				of whom South
          Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund is the Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Oconee County
J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-323
Submitted June 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 27,
  2008Â Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				W. Grady Jordan, of Easley, for Appellant.
				Amy V. Cofield, of Lexington, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Arthur G. Roberts (deceased), appeals the
  circuit courtâ€™s reversal of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s order
  finding Roberts was an employee of Rochester Cab Company (Rochester).Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Roberts
  was shot and killed while driving a cab for Rochester Cab Company.Â  The single
  commissioner found that Roberts was Rochesterâ€™s employee under the workersâ€™
  compensation statute.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-130 (Supp. 2007).Â  The appellate
  panel affirmed.Â  However, the circuit court reversed the appellate panel, finding
  it did not properly follow the four tests required to impose liability on as
  set forth in Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 349 S.C. 589, 564 S.E.2d 110
  (2002). Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Generally, a reviewing court will not overturn a decision by the
  appellate panel unless the determination is unsupported by
    substantial evidence or is affected by an error of law.Â  Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. S.C. Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 619, 611 S.E.2d
  297, 299 (Ct. App. 2005). Â However, the narrow nature of the question on appeal
  dictates a preponderance of the evidence standard.Â  â€œWorkersâ€™ compensation awards are
  authorized only if an employer-employee relationship exists at the time of the
  injury.Â  Whether or not an employer-employee relationship exists is a
  jurisdictional question. Â Where the issue involves jurisdiction, this Court can
  take its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€ Â Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 349 S.C. 589, 594, 564 S.E.2d 110, 112 (2002) (citations omitted).Â  However, â€œ[i]t is South Carolinaâ€™s policy
  to resolve jurisdictional doubts in favor of the inclusion of employers and
  employees under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act. Â Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
The analytical framework used by both the appellate panel and the
  circuit court involves the right of control and is set forth in the seminal
  case of Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 349
  S.C. at 594, 564 S.E.2d at 113. Â â€œThere are four elements which determine
  the right of control: 1) direct evidence of the right or exercise of control;
  2) furnishing of equipment; 3) right to fire; and 4) method of payment.â€Â  Id.Â  In Nelson, the court stated proof of any single element would be
  indicative of an employment relationship while contrary evidence would only be
  mild evidence of an independent contractor relationship.Â  Id. at 594-95,
  564 S.E.2d at 113.
Here, Rochester made many decisions which demonstrate its right or
  exercise of control, including:Â  deciding which car to lease to which driver;
  requiring drivers to keep the cars clean, to have the oil changed at the
  companyâ€™s expense, to be courteous, kind, and refrain from the use of
  profanity; and requiring drivers to have clean criminal records, to adhere to a
  dress code, to maintain the company sign on top of the cab, to charge city
  rates, and to keep their radio on if they wanted to keep their car.Â  Additionally,
  Rochester prohibited drivers from drinking alcohol or using drugs on the job.Â  
There is also evidence Rochester furnished the needed equipment,
  as it owned the cars which were leased to the drivers, paid for the car insurance,
  installed two-way radios, and provided business cards to the drivers.Â  Drivers
  paid for the lease of their car by providing Rochester with fifty percent of
  the fees earned.Â  This is an important distinction from the situation in Nelson where the driver paid a set lease fee and kept all fares and tips for his
  compensation.Â  Id. at 593, 599, 564 S.E.2d at 112, 115.Â  The arrangement
  in this case weighs heavily in favor of Roberts and a finding that an employer/employee
  relationship did exist.
Rochester also possessed the right to fire the drivers, as it would
  take a car away if the driver had a criminal record, used drugs or alcohol on
  the job, charged more than city rates, was not paying the full percentage of
  the fares he earned, or otherwise violated the requirements and prohibitions
  set forth above.Â  Moreover, Rochester specifically reserved the right to
  terminate the relationship if a driver did not complete his work in the
  expected manner.Â  Consequently, evidence of the third element in Nelson is present.
Finally, with respect to the method of payment, Robertâ€™s earnings
  consisted of fifty percent of his fares with the other fifty percent remitted
  to Rochester.Â  We find this is distinguishable from Nelson, where the
  driver kept all his fares and tips after paying a set amount to the cab company
  for lease of the vehicle.Â  Rochester required that city rates be observed, but
  the rate for fares outside the city could be determined by the driver.Â  In the
  case of checks or insurance voucher slips, the driver submitted the check or
  slip to Rochester as though it were cash, and Rochester was then responsible
  for collecting its fifty percent of the dayâ€™s earnings by cashing the check or
  seeking reimbursement from the insurance company.Â  Overall, the fact that
  Roberts was only entitled to fifty percent of his fares supports the contention
  he was an employee as opposed to an independent contractor.Â Â Â Â Â  
Some factors weigh in favor of finding Roberts an independent contractor;
  however, we find more evidence to support a finding he was an employee of Rochester.Â  Rochester controlled and disciplined the drivers, and it furnished their
  equipment, not under a contractually set arrangement, but rather based on a
  percentage of what the driver earned.Â  Furthermore, Rochester could terminate
  the employer/employee relationship based on a violation of how the work was to
  be performed by the driver, and the driver was only entitled to fifty percent
  of his earnings no matter how much he brought in driving the cab.Â  Because South Carolinaâ€™s policy is to resolve jurisdictional doubts in favor of the inclusion of
  employers and employees under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, and because there
  was ample evidence from which such a relationship could be found to exist, the
  decision of the circuit court is respectfully 
REVERSED.[1]
HEARN,
  C.J., and SHORT, J., and KONDUROS, J., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
