THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Celestine
      Parker, Appellant,
				v.
				Robert Brown, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-324
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 27,
  2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Kevin A. Hall and A. Mattison Bogan, both of Columbia, for
  Appellant.
				Robert Brown, of Fort Mott, pro se.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIAM:Â  In this landlord-tenant
  action, the magistrate found Celestine Parker wrongfully withheld a portion of
  Robert Brownâ€™s security deposit and awarded Brown treble damages.Â  The circuit
  court affirmed, and Parker appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On December 3, 2004, Parker and Brown entered
  into a six-month lease wherein Brown agreed to rent Parkerâ€™s house.Â  Brown
  agreed to pay Parker $575 a month commencing on January 1, 2005.Â  The lease
  also called for Brown to pay a security deposit of $550.Â  According to Parker, in
  an addendum to the rental contract, the parties agreed Brown would move in on
  December 18, 2004.[1]Â 
  However, Brown moved in on December 15, 2004. 
Under
  the terms of the rental contact, the lease expired on June 30, 2005, but
  testimony indicates Brown left personal items in the rental property until July
  6, 2005.Â  Following a final inspection of the property, Parker determined Brown
  was not entitled to a full refund of his security deposit.Â  Instead, Parker
  refunded Brown $269.64 of the $550 deposit, making several deductions.Â  
Brown
  filed a complaint in magistrateâ€™s court alleging Parker made unauthorized
  deductions from his security deposit and failed to return the deposit in a
  timely manner.Â  The magistrate awarded Brown treble damages of $1100, finding Parker
  did not itemize the deductions and send the cost of repairs or refund the
  security deposit in a timely manner.Â  The circuit court affirmed the award based
  upon its finding that substantial evidence supported the magistrateâ€™s order.Â 
  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On review from the
  circuit court, the appellate court is without authority to reverse findings of
  fact if there is any supporting evidence.Â  Vacation Time of Hilton Head Island,
    Inc. v. Kiwi Corp., 280 S.C. 232, 234, 312 S.E.2d 20, 21 (Ct. App.
  1984).Â  This court presumes an affirmance by a circuit court of a magistrateâ€™s
  judgment was made upon the merits when the testimony is sufficient to sustain
  the magistrateâ€™s judgment and there are no facts that show the affirmance was
  influenced by an error of law.Â  Parks v. Characters Night Club, 345 S.C.
  484, 490, 548 S.E.2d 605, 608 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Unless we find an error of
  law, the appellate court will affirm the circuit courtâ€™s holding if there are
  any facts supporting the decision.Â  Hadfield v. Gilchrist, 343 S.C. 88,
  94, 538 S.E.2d 268, 271 (Ct. App. 2000).
LAW/ANALYSIS

I.Â  Rule 208(a)(4), SCACR
Initially, Parker contends this court should reverse
  the circuit courtâ€™s order, pursuant to Rule 208(a)(4), SCACR, because Brown
  failed to file an initial brief.Â  We disagree.
Upon the failure of
  respondent to timely file a brief, the appellate court â€œmay take such action as
  it deems proper.â€Â  Rule 208(a)(4), SCACR.Â  South Carolina courts have
  recognized the failure of a respondent to file a brief could justify a reversal.Â  Turner v. Santee Cement Carriers, Inc.,  277 S.C. 91, 96, 282
  S.E.2d 858, 860 (1981).Â  Furthermore, when a respondent does not file a
  brief, this court has found it proper to address the issues as presented by the
  appellant.Â  Durham v. United Cos. Fin. Corp.,  326 S.C. 403, 404,
  483 S.E.2d 786 (Ct. App. 1997) revâ€™d on other grounds, 331 S.C. 600, 503 S.E.2d
  465 (1998).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Although
  Brownâ€™s failure to file a brief with this court could justify reversal, we do
  not deem it proper to reverse under these facts.Â  The record is sufficient to
  provide this court with an understanding of the issues on appeal.Â  
II.Â  Civil Relief Act
Parker next
  maintains the circuit court erred affirming the decision of the magistrate failing
  to stay the case because co-defendant Stanley Parker was on active military duty.Â 
  This issue is not preserved for our review.
An issue cannot be
  raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In order for an issue to be preserved for
  appellate review it must be raised to and ruled upon by the circuit court.Â  Staubes
    v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000).Â 
  â€œError preservation requirements are intended â€˜to enable the lower court to
  rule properly after it has considered all relevant facts, law, and
  arguments.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting Iâ€™On v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C.
  406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000)).Â  Where the circuit court has not ruled
  on an issue, â€œa reviewing court simply would not be able to evaluate whether
  the trial court committed error.â€Â  Id.
In the present
  case, the magistrate received a fax from Stanley Parker stating he was on
  active duty outside the state and could not be in attendance.Â  The record does
  not indicate a request to stay the proceedings was made pursuant to the Civil
  Relief Act.Â  Furthermore, even if we liberally construe Stanley Parkerâ€™s fax to
  the Magistrate as an application for a stay of proceedings, Parker did not
  appeal the Magistrateâ€™s denial of the request to stay to the circuit court.Â  Biales
    v. Young, 315 S.C. 166, 168, 432 S.E.2d 482, 484 (1993) (â€œFailure to [challenge a ruling] is an abandonment of
  the issue and precludes consideration on appeal.â€).Â  Accordingly, this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  Moreover,
  we fail to discern any prejudice because Stanley Parkerâ€™s name was not on the
  partiesâ€™ contract.Â  Accordingly, this issue is without merit. 
III.Â  Security Deposit
Parker maintains the magistrate erred in finding she
  improperly withheld deductions from Brownâ€™s security deposit and failed to
  return the balance in a timely manner.Â  We disagree.

	The South Carolina
  Residential Landlord and Tenant Act provides:
	
		(a) Upon
  termination of the tenancy, property or money held by the landlord as security
  must be returned less amounts withheld by the landlord for accrued rent and
  damages which the landlord has suffered . . . .Â  Any deduction from the
  security/rental deposit must be itemized by the landlord in a written notice to
  the tenant . . . within thirty days after termination of the tenancy and
  delivery of possession and demand by the tenant, whichever is later. The tenant
  shall provide the landlord in writing with a forwarding address or new address
  to which the written notice and amount due from the landlord may be sent.Â  If
  the tenant fails to provide the landlord with the forwarding or new address,
  the tenant is not entitled to damages under this subsection provided the
  landlord (1) had no notice of the tenantâ€™s whereabouts and
  (2) mailed the written notice and amount due, if any, to the tenantâ€™s last
  known address.
		(b) If the landlord fails to return to the tenant any prepaid rent
  or security/rental deposit with the notice required to be sent by the landlord
  pursuant to subsection (a), the tenant may recover the property and money in an
  amount equal to three times the amount wrongfully withheld and reasonable
  attorneyâ€™s fees.
	

S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 27-40-410(a)&(b) (Supp. 2007).Â  
Here, Parker
  determined Brown was entitled to the return of only $269.64 of his $550 security
  deposit.Â  Parker made the
  following deductions: (1) $24.72 for a June 2005 telephone bill; (2) $65.00 for
  landscaping; (3) $80.00 for carpet cleaning; (4) $54.99 for new locks; and (5)
  $55.65 in rental fees.Â  
The magistrate heard the partiesâ€™ testimony and determined
  Parkerâ€™s deductions were unauthorized for the following reasons:Â  Brown
  paid the June 2005 phone bill; Parker failed to produce a receipt for landscaping
  the rental property; the receipt for carpet cleaning was post dated August 8,
  2008, and indicated a charge of only $60; it was Parkerâ€™s responsibility to
  change the locks after Brown moved out; and Parker was not entitled to rent for
  three days in December 2004.Â  Each of these findings is supported by evidence
  in the record; therefore, the circuit
  court properly upheld the findings of the magistrate.
The magistrate
  also concluded Parker failed to return the security deposit in a timely
  manner.Â  Although Brown vacated the property on June 30, 2005, it appears some
  of his possessions remained there until July 6, 2005.Â  At the hearing, Parker stated
  she returned part of Brownâ€™s security deposit on July 6, 2005.[2]Â 
  However, the evidence presented indicated Parker did not mail the check to Brown
  until August 6, 2005.Â  In addition, Parker contended she could not refund the
  security deposit because she did not have the proper forwarding address,
  although she admitted to the circuit court on appeal she possessed the address
  Brown claimed was his permanent address.Â  As a result, the magistrate and the
  circuit court did not err in finding Parker returned a portion of Brownâ€™s
  security deposit more than thirty days following the termination of the tenancy
  and in awarding treble damages.Â Â  
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the
  magistrateâ€™s findings is
AFFIRMED. [3]
HEARN, C.J., and
  SHORT, J., and KONDUROS, J., concur.


[1] The addendum was not signed by either party.Â  
[2] On appeal to the circuit court, Parker stated Brownâ€™s
  mother removed personal items from the rental property on July 7, 2005, which
  would have made Parkerâ€™s mailing of the security deposit timely.Â  However, the
  record does not show this argument was raised to the magistrate.
[3] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Savannah Architectural Supply, Inc., Respondent,
				v.
				James R. Brady,
      d/b/a Brady Builders, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Special Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-325
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 27,
  2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Thomas J. Finn, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
				Leo A. Dryer, Jr., of Columbia, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  James
  Brady appeals the trial courtâ€™s order finding him liable on a contract with Savannah Architectural Supply, Inc.
  (Savannah Architectural).Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In 1986, Brady and another
  individual formed Boru Enterprises, Inc., which did business under the trade
  name Brady Builders.Â  Brady was also president of Boru Enterprises.Â  In
  1999, Rick Bohrer, an employee of Boru Enterprises, requested a quote from
  Savannah Architectural on behalf of Brady Builders.Â  As a result,
  Savannah Architectural opened an account for Brady Builders. Construction
  materials amounting to $43,602.47,[2] were ordered
  on the account between June 21, 1999 and March 21, 2001.Â  No payment was
  made and Savannah Architectural brought suit against Brady personally.Â  Brady
  answered asserting he was employed by Boru Enterprises, and thus, not
  personally liable.Â  Brady also stated Boru Enterprises was no longer actively
  conducting business.Â  
At trial, Chester Gayheart, the president
  of Savannah Architectural, testified Brady had been a customer of Savannah
  Architectural since 1995.Â  Additionally, Gayheart testified he believed
  he was dealing with a sole proprietorship Brady owned and was unaware of the
  existence of Boru Enterprises.Â  As evidence, Savannah
  Architectural offered (1) draw requests submitted by Brady Builders and signed
  by Brady with no corporate designations regarding the project for which the
  materials Savannah Architectural provided were used; (2) copies of a cashierâ€™s
  check issued jointly to Brady Builders and itself by one of Brady Builderâ€™s
  customers, which did not reference Boru Enterprises; and (3) several of its
  invoices addressed to Brady Builders for the construction materials.Â  Further, Brady testified he regularly signed his name without designating himself as
  a corporate officer.Â  However, Gayheart admitted Savannah Architectural
  had not seen the draw requests at the time it provided the construction
  materials to Brady Builders.
The trial court found Boru Enterprises was
  an undisclosed principal, and thus, Brady was liable as an agent for the amount
  due and interest.Â  Approximately a month after the trial court issued
  its order, Brady filed a Rule 60(b), SCRCP, motion for relief from judgment.Â  Brady asserted he had newly discovered evidence in the form of a check paid
  to Savannah Architectural that noted Brady Builders was a division of Boru
  Enterprises.Â  The trial court denied the motion finding the check was not newly
  discovered evidence because it was in Bradyâ€™s own records and he was aware of
  its existence prior to trial.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn
  action on an open account is an action at law.â€Â  Spartanburg Regâ€™l
    Med. Ctr. v. Bulsa, 308 S.C. 322, 323, 417 S.E.2d 648, 649 (Ct. App.
  1992).Â  On appeal of an action at law tried without a jury, this courtâ€™s review
  is limited to correction of errors at law.Â  Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home v.
    Beasley, 365 S.C. 157, 164, 616 S.E.2d 710, 714 (2005).Â  The
  trial courtâ€™s findings are equivalent to a juryâ€™s findings in a law action.Â  King
    v. PYA/Monarch, Inc., 317 S.C. 385, 389, 453 S.E.2d 885, 888 (1995).Â 
  Questions regarding credibility and weight of evidence are exclusively for the
  trial court.Â  Sheek v. Crimestoppers Alarm Sys., 297 S.C. 375, 377,
  377 S.E.2d 132, 133 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  â€œWe must look at the evidence in the
  light most favorable to the respondents and eliminate from consideration all
  evidence to the contrary.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS

I.Â  Liability
Brady
  contends the trial court erred in granting judgment against him after finding
  Bohrer was an agent for Boru Enterprises, an undisclosed principal.Â  We
  disagree.
â€œAn agent is one appointed by a principal as his
  representative and to whom the principal confides the management of some business to be transacted in the principalâ€™s name, or on his
  account, and who brings about or effects legal relationships between the principal and third parties.â€Â  Colleton County Taxpayers Assâ€™n v. Sch. Dist. of Colleton County, 371
  S.C. 224, 239, 638 S.E.2d 685, 693 (2006).Â  If an agent did not disclose
  his principal when making a contract with a party, the party, upon discovering
  the principal, may hold either the agent or the principal liable.Â  See Goodale
    v. Page, 92 S.C. 413, 416, 75 S.E. 700, 701 (1912); see
      also Broom v. Marshall, 284 S.C. 530, 540, 328 S.E.2d 639,
  645 (Ct. App. 1984) (Gardner, J. dissenting) (quoting 3 C.J.S. Agency Â§ 369 (1973)) (â€œAn agent . . . if he contracts as agent for an undisclosed principal, will be personally liable unless
    there is a mutual intention of the parties to the contrary.â€); Restatement
  (Third) of Agency Â§ 6.03 (2006) (â€œWhen
    an agent acting with actual authority makes a contract on behalf of an
    undisclosed principal, (1) unless excluded by the contract, the principal is a party to the
      contract; [and] (2) the agent and the third party are parties to the contract .
      . . .â€).Â  â€œA principal
        is undisclosed if, when an agent and a third party interact, the third party
        has no notice that the agent is acting for a principal.â€Â  Restatement
  (Third) of Agency Â§ 1.04(2)(b) (2006).
Brady routinely did
  business with Savannah Architectural as an agent of Boru Enterprises.Â  However,
  Savannah Architectural had no indication Brady was acting on behalf of a corporation.Â 
  Therefore, Boru Enterprises was an undisclosed principal, and thus, Brady can
  be held liable as its agent.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in
  finding Brady personally liable for the debt.
II.Â  Rule 60(b), SCRCP,
  Motion
Brady maintains the
  trial court erred in failing to grant his Rule 60(b), SCRCP, motion.Â  We
  disagree.
The
  decision to deny a motion under
  Rule 60(b) is within the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion.Â  Raby Constr.,
    L.L.P. v. Orr, 358 S.C. 10, 17, 594 S.E.2d 478, 482 (2004).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the
  trial courtâ€™s decision is controlled by an error of law or is based on factual
  findings lacking evidentiary support.Â  Degenhart v. Burriss, 360 S.C. 497, 500, 602 S.E.2d 96, 97 (Ct.
  App. 2004).
On
  motion and upon such terms as are just, the court may relieve a party
  from a final judgment, order, or proceeding for newly discovered evidence that
  by due diligence could not have been discovered in time to move for a new trial
  under Rule 59(b), SCRCP.Â  Rule 60(b)(2), SCRCP.Â  

	To
  obtain a new trial based on newly discovered evidence, a movant must establish
  that the newly discovered evidence: (1) will probably change the result if a new trial is granted; (2) has been
  discovered since the trial; (3) could not have been discovered before the
  trial; (4) is material to the issue; and (5) is not merely cumulative or
  impeaching.

Lanier v. Lanier, 364 S.C. 211, 217, 612 S.E.2d 456, 459 (Ct.
  App. 2005).Â  When the party knew of and possessed evidence at the time of trial,
  it is not newly discovered for the purposes of Rule 60(b)(2).Â  Lanier,
  364 S.C. at 218, 612 S.E.2d at 459.
â€œRule
  60(b)(2) allows the court to grant a new trial only if the newly discovered
  evidence could not have been discovered by due diligence prior to trial.â€Â  Lanier,
  364 S.C. at 220, 612 S.E.2d at 460.Â  Due diligence is the â€œdiligence reasonably
  expected from, and ordinarily exercised by, a person who seeks to satisfy a
  legal requirement or to discharge an obligation.â€Â  Id. â€œDiligence looks
  not to what the litigant actually discovered, but what he or she could have discovered.â€Â  Id.Â  Accordingly, when parties could
  have discovered the new evidence prior to trial, they are not entitled to
  relief under Rule 60(b)(2).Â  See Raby Constr., L.L.P., 358 S.C.
  at 21, 594 S.E.2d at 484 (citing Bowman v. Bowman, 357 S.C. 146, 152, 591
  S.E.2d 654, 657 (Ct. App. 2004)).
In
  the present case, the check was in Boru Enterprisesâ€™ records.Â  Simply because
  those records were in a state of disarray does not change the fact Brady had
  access to them before trial.Â  This court has previously found â€œ[w]hen a party
  simply misplaces evidence at home, the court will treat the failure to discover
  it as a failure to exercise due diligence.â€Â  Lanier, 364 S.C. at 220,
  612 S.E.2d at 461.Â  Here, Brady testified as to the existence of such a check
  at trial.Â  Accordingly, he knew of the check and had access to Boru
  Enterprisesâ€™ records.Â  Therefore, the check did not constitute newly discovered
  evidence.Â  Further, because Brady could have discovered the check prior to
  trial, he failed to exercise due diligence.Â Â  Consequently, the trial court did
  not err in denying Bradyâ€™s Rule 60(b), SCRCP, motion.
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, the order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The parties stipulated to this amount.

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    Sung Windham
    Appellant,
  

v.

  
    Rolling Green Village, Employer and American Home Assurance Co./Gallagher Basset Services, Inc.,
      Carrier
    Respondents.
  
  
     
     
  
  
     
     
  

__________
Appeal From Greenville County
G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
__________
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-326
Submitted June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed June 27,
  2008 
__________
AFFIRMED
__________
Kathryn Williams, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Weston Adams, III, Jillian M. Benson, and
  Ashley B.
Stratton, of Columbia, for Respondents.
PER
  CURIAM:Â  Sung Windham appeals from a
  circuit court order affirming the denial of continuing medical treatment for
  her psychological injury.Â  Windham argues the circuit court erred in holding
  substantial evidence supported the finding of the Appellate Panel of the
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission that Windham is not entitled to continuing
  medical treatment for her compensable psychological claim.Â  Windham further
  asserts that the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision is affected by an error of law.Â  
We
  affirm[1] the order of the circuit court pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the
  following authorities: Â Anderson v. Baptist Medical Ctr., 343 S.C. 487,
  492, 541 S.E.2d 526, 528 (2001) (the findings of the Appellate Panel are
  presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial
  evidence on the record); Â Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535
  S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000) (â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence
  nor evidence viewed from one side, but such evidence, when the whole record is
  considered, as would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the
  [Appellate Panel] reached.â€).Â  As to the error of law issue:Â  Elam v. South
    Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 23, 602 S.E.2d 772, 779-80 (2004)
  (holding that issues and arguments are preserved for appellate review only when
  they are raised to and ruled on by the lower court).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  AFFIRMED.
Â WILLIAMS, THOMAS, and PIEPER, JJ., concur.

  215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Jason H.
      Parker, Appellant,
				v.
				R. David Plexico,
      Ronald Plexico, and Karl Waschkolup are, Defendants,
				Of Whom Ronald
      Plexico is, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
Â S. Jackson Kimball, III, Special Circuit
  Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-327
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 27,
  2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Ivan N. Walters, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
				Joshua B. Vann, and Lucy L. McDow, both of Rock Hill, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: In
  this trespass action, Jason Parker appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary
  judgment in favor of Ronald Plexico.Â  Specifically, Parker argues the trial
  court erred in finding dams Plexico constructed were not a continuing trespass
  and Parkerâ€™s claim was barred by the statute of limitations.Â  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS
Plexico owned property located on Lake Wylie. He observed stream drainage from the neighboring property entering his
  property.  Over time, the steam drainage caused his land to erode. 
  He received permission from the owner of the neighboring property to construct
  two retention ponds and dams (collectively, â€œthe damsâ€), which were completed
  by 1990.  Ten years later, Plexicoâ€™s son, David, purchased the Lake Wylie property.
In June 2002, Parker acquired the neighboring property as
  co-tenant with his father.Â  Parker later acquired his fatherâ€™s interest and
  began developing the property. Â Parker attempted to obtain permits but
  halted development because of conflicting positions regarding the dams taken by
  the Army Corps of Engineers, York County, and Duke Energy Corporation.Â  Consequently,
  Parker brought an action against Plexico seeking damages for civil conspiracy
  and a continuing trespass caused by the dam construction.Â  In response,
  Plexico filed a motion for summary judgment asserting: (1) Parker has no claim
  for trespass because he did not own the property at the time the dams were constructed;
  (2) Parker is barred from proceeding on his claim under the statute of
  limitations; and (3) Parker has no evidence of a civil conspiracy to prevent
  the removal of the dams on his property.
The trial court granted Plexicoâ€™s motion, finding the dams
  â€œconstitute a permanent, one-time alteration of the property, and any injury in
  regard to them occurred at the time they were constructed.â€Â  The trial court
  also found Plexico could not have had intent to harm or damage Parker when the
  dams were constructed because Parker did not own the property at that time.Â 
  Further, the trial court concluded Parkerâ€™s claim was barred by the statute of
  limitations.Â  Thereafter, Parker filed a motion to alter or amend judgment,
  which the trial court denied. Â This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is
  proper when no genuine issue exists as to any material fact and the moving
  party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Hurst v. E. Coast Hockey League, Inc., 371 S.C. 33, 36, 637 S.E.2d 560, 561
  (2006).Â  On appeal from a grant of summary judgment, the appellate court
  applies the same standard governing the trial court.Â  Id.Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact
  exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences drawn therefrom must be
  viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Law v. S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).Â  â€œA court considering summary judgment neither makes factual
  determinations nor considers the merits of competing testimony; however,
  summary judgment is completely appropriate when a properly supported motion
  sets forth facts that remain undisputed or are contested in a deficient manner.â€ Â David v. McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 250, 626 S.E.2d 1,
  5 (2006). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Continuing Trespass
Parker
  contends the trial court erred in finding the dams constructed by Plexico were
  not a continuing trespass.[2]Â  We disagree.
Trespass
  is defined as â€œany intentional invasion of the plaintiffâ€™s interest in the
  exclusive possession of his property.â€Â  Hedgepath v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co.,
  348 S.C. 340, 357, 559 S.E.2d 327, 337 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Thus, actual or
  constructive possession by the plaintiff at the time of the trespass is a
  necessary element to maintain an action for trespass.Â  Daniels v. Coleman, 253 S.C. 218, 229, 169 S.E.2d 593, 598 (1969).Â  Accordingly,
  a purchaser who acquires title after the act of trespass has no action for
  trespass, unless his title is retrospective in nature and dates back to the
  time of the trespass.Â  75 Am. Jur. 2d Trespass Â§ 29 (2007).Â  However, an
  exception exists when a trespass is continuing and has not ceased by the time
  the purchaser acquires title to the property.Â  Id. 
A
  continuing trespass is intermittent or periodical and occurs so often it is
  said to be continuing, although it is not necessarily constant or unceasing.Â  Silvester
    v. Spring Valley Country Club, 344 S.C. 280, 286, 543 S.E.2d 563, 566 (Ct.
  App. 2001).Â  Typically, a trespass is continuing if
  abatement is reasonably and practically possible.Â  Id. at 287, 543
  S.E.2d at 567. Â On the contrary, a permanent
  trespass â€œmay be expected to continue but is presumed to continue permanently,
  with no possibility of abatement.â€Â  Id. at 286, 543 S.E.2d at 566-67.Â  When a permanent trespass has occurred, the injury is fixed
  and goes to the whole value of the land. Â Id., 543 S.E.2d at 567.Â  
In
  the present case, Parker misconstrues the nature of the dams constructed by
  Plexico as a continuing trespass.Â  Even assuming the dams were wrongfully
  constructed, the dams represent the damage caused by the trespass, not the
  trespass itself.[3]Â  As noted by the trial
  court, â€œThe dams are not a continuing inference with Parkerâ€™s possession; they
  represent damage to the land of which he now has undisputed exclusive
  possession.â€Â  Furthermore, removal of the dams would not abate any repeated
  intrusion upon Parkerâ€™s property; rather, removal would simply eliminate the
  offending condition.[4]Â  Because the record
  reflects no new occurrence of injury after Parkerâ€™s purchase of the property,
  Plexico did not commit a continuing trespass.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did
  not err in refusing to submit Parkerâ€™s continuing trespass cause of action to
  the jury.Â  
II.  Statute of Limitations
Parker
  further maintains the trial court erred in finding his claim was barred by the statute
  of limitations.Â  We disagree.
In order to attack Plexicoâ€™s statute of limitations defense, Parker
  seeks to characterize his property damage claim as a continuing trespass.Â  When
  a trespass â€œis permanent and only one cause of action may be brought for
  damages, the statute of limitations bars the action if it is not brought within
  the statutory period after the first actionable injury.â€Â  Hedgepath,
  348 S.C. at 357, 559 S.E.2d at 337.Â  However,
  when the trespass is characterized as continuing, â€œthe expiration of the
  limitations period after the first actionable injury does not effect a complete
  bar as each new injury gives rise to a new cause of action and a landowner may
  at any time recover for an injury to his land which occurred within the statutory
  period.â€Â  Id. at 358, 559 S.E.2d at 337.
As previously noted, we find the dams constitute a permanent
  trespass as opposed to a continuing trespass.Â  Indeed, Parkerâ€™s claim is premised entirely on the
  construction of the dams and not any continued operation, use, or recurring
  activity by Plexico.Â  Thus, under settled precedent, the statute of limitations
  has run as to the trespass of which the dams are a remaining condition.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  15-3-530(3) (2005) (requiring a plaintiff bringing a cause of action for
  trespass to file suit within three years from when the cause of action arose).Â  Therefore, the trial court did not err in granting summary judgment to
  Plexico under the statute of limitations. 
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, we find the trial court did not err in granting Plexicoâ€™s motion for summary
  judgment.Â  Accordingly, the decision of
  the trial court is 
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., and
  SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Parker asserts the trial court improperly relied on
  nuisance and inverse condemnation jurisprudence in deciding if the dams were a
  permanent or continuing trespass.Â  This court has previously utilized these
  types of cases in analyzing continuing trespass situations. See Knight v. Waggoner, 359 S.C. 492, 496, 597 S.E.2d 894, 896 (Ct. App. 2004); Whitfield
    Constr. Co. v. Bank of Tokyo Trust Co., 338 S.C. 207, 218, 525 S.E.2d
  888, 894 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the trial
  courtâ€™s reliance.
[3] Contrary to Parkerâ€™s contention, the record does not demonstrate
  an unauthorized entry upon his property; the only evidence indicates the
  previous landowner authorized Plexicoâ€™s entry onto Parkerâ€™s property.
[4] Parker argues this court should treat the abatability
  of the dams as a factual issue and remand for a jury determination of whether
  the dams are removable.Â  However, because Parker failed to raise this argument
  to the trial court, it is not preserved for our review.Â  See In re Michael H., 360 S.C.
  540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may not be
  raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In order to preserve an issue for appeal,
  it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€).

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				David R. Meeks, Appellant,
				v.
				Bobby Lee
      Goings, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-328
Submitted June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed June 27,
  2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Thomas A. Killoren, Jr., of Harrison, of Spartanburg, for
  Appellant.
				Robert Eric Davis, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: In
  this civil case, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s denial of David Meeksâ€™ motion for
  a new trial nisi additur. Â 
FACTS
On February 23, 2000, David Meeks (Meeks) was stopped at the
  intersection of Floyd Road and Highway 221 in Spartanburg County, South Carolina.Â  Bobby Goings (Goings) was attempting to make a left turn onto Floyd Road from the southbound lane of Highway 221.Â  Goings collided with a vehicle
  traveling north on Highway 221.Â  As a result of this collision, Goingsâ€™ vehicle
  collided with Meeksâ€™ vehicle.Â  
Meeks sought to recover medical expenses allegedly incurred as a
  result of the accident and the cost of a future, unscheduled surgery to his
  ribs.Â  In August 1998, Meeks was injured when he was kicked in his ribs by a
  deer.Â  The deer kick was in the same area as the alleged injury Meeks sustained
  in the automobile accident.Â  
In 2002, approximately four years after the deer kick and two years
  after the automobile accident, Meeks was referred to Dr. Michael Zhadkevich, a
  board certified heart, lung, and general surgeon.Â  Dr. Zhadkevich and Meeks
  discussed surgical options in 2002 and 2003 to correct his alleged injuries.Â  However,
  Meeks never scheduled surgery, but he did return to Dr. Zhadkevich in 2007,
  seven years after his automobile accident.Â  Dr. Zhadkevich testified Meeks was
  â€œdoing pretty well.â€Â  
During the trial, Meeksâ€™ wife, Lucia, testified.Â  During cross-
  examination, Goings asked Lucia the cost of tuition associated with educating
  their child in a private school.Â  Meeks objected, arguing the question was
  irrelevant.Â  The trial court overruled this objection.Â  
At the close of the trial, the jury returned a verdict in favor of
  Meeks for $3,548.25.Â  This amount represented Meeksâ€™ actual medical bills.Â  The
  jury did not award Meeks the approximate $24,430 he was seeking for the
  unscheduled, future surgery.Â  Meeks filed a motion for a new trial nisi additur.Â 
  Meeks argued the jury award was insufficient because the jury failed to award
  him the cost of the future surgery.Â  The trial court denied this motion.Â  This
  appeal follows.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Meeks argues the trial court committed reversible error in two
  respects: (1) denying his motion for a new trial nisi additur,
  and (2) overruling his objection to questioning concerning the cost of his
  childâ€™s tuition.Â  
A. New trial nisi additur[1]
Meeks
  first argues the trial court erred in denying his motion for a new trial nisi additur.Â  We disagree. Â  
Our decision in Howard v. Roberson succinctly sets out the
  law regarding a new trial nisi additur. 

	A new
  trial nisi is one in which a new trial will be granted unless the party
  opposing it complies with a condition set by the court.Â  The grant or denial of
  new trial motions rests within the discretion of the trial judge, and his
  decision will not be disturbed on appeal unless his findings are wholly
  unsupported by the evidence or the conclusions reached are controlled by error
  of law.Â  The trial court alone has the power to grant a new trial nisi when he finds the amount of the verdict to be merely inadequate or excessive.Â 
  However, compelling reasons must be given to justify invading the juryâ€™s
  province by granting a new trial nisi additur or remittitur.Â 
  The consideration for a motion for a new trial nisi additur or 
	remittitur requires the trial judge to consider the adequacy of the verdict in light of
  the evidence presented.Â  Great deference is given to the trial judge who heard
  the evidence and is more familiar with the evidentiary atmosphere at trial, and
  who thus possesses a better-informed view of the damages than this Court.Â  

376 S.C. 143,
  155-56, 654 S.E.2d 877, 883-84 (Ct. App. 2007) (internal quotations and
  citations omitted). 
The record contains ample evidence to demonstrate the trial court
  did not abuse its discretion in denying Meeksâ€™ nisi additur motion.Â  Meeks was kicked in his left ribs in 1998 by a deer, which Meeksâ€™
  family physician noted may have caused â€œa rib fracture on [his] left side.â€Â  This
  kick was in the same area as the alleged injury Meeks sustained in the
  automobile accident in 2000.Â  Based on this, the jury could have easily
  concluded Meeksâ€™ injury was not the result of the automobile accident but rather
  a result of the deer kick.Â  
Additionally, from June 2003 to January 2007, Meeks was actively
  working and did not require any medical attention.Â  When Meeks returned to Dr.
  Zhadkevich in 2007, seven years after his automobile accident, Dr. Zhadkevich
  concluded Meeksâ€™ â€œphysical exam reveal[ed] a robust gentleman who look[ed] much
  younger than his age.Â  His pain in the area of the previous fracture has
  significantly improved with only minimal discomfort . . . .â€Â  Relying on this
  evidence, the jury could have concluded Meeks would not need surgery in the
  future because he did not suffer any apparent injury from the automobile
  accident.Â  Based on the foregoing, we cannot say the trial court abused its
  discretion in denying Meeksâ€™ nisi additur motion.Â  See id. (â€œThe grant or denial of new trial
  motions rests within the discretion of the trial judge, and his decision will
  not be disturbed on appeal unless his findings are wholly unsupported by the
  evidence . . . .â€).
B. Admission
  of evidence[2] 
Meeks also
  argues the trial court improperly allowed Goings to inquire into the cost of
  tuition associated with educating his child in a private school.Â  We disagree. 
The admission or exclusion of evidence is
  within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Burroughs v. Worsham,
  352 S.C. 382, 391, 574 S.E.2d 215, 219-20 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  The exercise of
  this discretion will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that
  discretion.Â  Id.Â  We may reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision only if the
  appellant shows both an error in the ruling and resulting prejudice.Â  Id.
In this case, even if we assume the trial courtâ€™s decision was
  erroneous, Meeks has failed to show prejudice.Â  Meeks argues the jury
  envisioned him as an affluent individual who could afford to pay for his own
  surgery.Â  Meeks contends he was prejudiced because even though Goings was found
  liable, the jury failed to award him the cost of the surgery to correct his
  alleged injuries.Â  However, as explained above, the jury could have concluded Meeksâ€™ injury
  to his ribs was not the result of the automobile accident.Â  Likewise, the jury
  could have concluded Meeks would not need surgery in the future.Â  Since we find
  no prejudice, we conclude there is no reversible error.Â  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.[3]
WILLIAMS,
  THOMAS, and PIEPER, JJ., concur.


[1] Goings argues this issue is not preserved for our
  review.Â  We disagree. Meeks filed a motion for a new trial nisi additur, and the trial
  court ruled upon this motion.Â  Thus, this
  issue is preserved for our review.Â  Wilder Corp.
    v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731,
  733 (1998) (holding for an issue to be preserved for appeal it must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court).
[2] Goings argues this issue is not preserved for our
  review because the trial courtâ€™s evidentiary ruling was not contained in Meeksâ€™
  notice of appeal.Â  We disagree because Meeks properly preserved this issue by
  objecting during the trial. Lancaster v. Fielder, 305 S.C. 418, 421, 409
  S.E.2d 375, 377 (1991) (â€œ[A] party need not challenge
  the final judgment itself in order to contest an intermediate judgment.â€).
[3] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				First South
      Bank, Appellant,
				v.
				Selective Project
      Management, Inc. d/b/a Selective Project Management, LLC, J. Michael Leath,
